PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.
Consideration resumed from 6 October.
Schedule 3.
Department of Transport and Communications
Proposed expenditure, $1,189,592,000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall Mr R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In debating Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88 this morning, I want to raise briefly the question of the surveillance of our coastline. In so doing I refer for just a few moments to the failed contract which has so embarrassed the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) because of the actions of his predecessor, the Minister for Resources (Mr Peter Morris). I have noticed with some amusement that his predecessor has sat back whilst the Minister has been taking the brunt of the criticism over that failed contract. One of the problems about this failed contract is that it rather takes the heat off the Government in relation to the overall question of coastal surveillance. We know that the Government, for a very odd and peculiar reason, awarded the coastal surveillance contract to a company which had no planes, no expertise and obviously no future in fulfilling the requirements set out so clearly for it.

SPEECH.PARA: However, that is a diversion from the real question of what is happening with coastal surveillance in Australia. One has to go back years to understand the problems facing this country. Over a number of years Australia has become slowly aware of the problem of drugs coming into this country and fauna being exported from this country-an illegal trade which is a shame visited on this nation. A dereliction of duty by governments has allowed this to develop to the degree that now exists. One of the dismaying things about the growing drug trade in Australia and the growing incidence of crime based on it is that over the years all of us have known of the rumours that have developed and the information that has been available to the general community, to members of the police forces and to members of parliament in serving their electorates and moving around this country. We have become aware of a general pool of crime which we have been unable to attack because of the want of proof to be able to pin down those who are responsible for this nefarious trade.

Over the last few years we have been pleased to see the development of the National Crime Authority at least giving a national direction to the fight against crime in this country. But, as I have said, all of us have known, from rumours and information which has been available, that something has been drastically wrong in this country. Today we in our respective States know of information, some of which must be based on fact because of past revelations, which causes a great deal of concern to us all. The matters which are now being pinpointed in Queensland illustrate yet again how defective Australia's surveillance is in relation to protecting the public from this area of crime.

As far as coastal surveillance is concerned, we know that planes are entering this country across our northern coasts. We know that drugs are being dropped from ships that pass well-known ports in Australia. For instance, in my State of South Australia, the soft underbelly of the coast of this country, there are plenty of well-based rumours that drugs are being dropped off the coast and are being picked up and brought through ports in the south of the State. Rumours are rife about Port Lincoln and other ports in South Australia. If this is occurring in that part of Australia, one can imagine how rife it is in Sydney, off the coast of Queensland and in the northern parts of Australia.

It therefore becomes a matter of will and of how much determination exists in this Government to attack this problem which has developed to such an enormous degree in Australia. Why are we arguing about a simple defect in awarding a contract to a company to conduct a series of surveillance flights which all of us know are ineffective? Why is the argument centred on that matter? Why is it not centred on the wider question of what we will really do in Australia to survey our coast properly and to prevent the ingress and egress of illegal goods and fauna? Until this question is properly addressed, we will argue around its edges.

We will effectively combat the importation of drugs into Australia across our coasts only when we can prove to those who would come to this country that we can intercept their activities. It is no good our flying over creek beds or signs in the sand and reporting to the naval authorities that they can send a patrol boat there two or three days later to investigate some manifestation of landing on Australia's coast. Those who perpetrate these activities have to be intercepted within Australian waters. The Government must address itself to this question. I believe that it will have to look overseas to find out what other countries do to safeguard their coastlines effectively. Australia will have to develop a coastguard or at least a command under one of the services not only to develop effectively the organisation of personnel but also to acquire the hardware to intercept and prevent the illegal trade across our coasts.

I notice with great interest that the Indian Government has placed enormous emphasis on not only its navy but also its coastguard service. It has under its coastguard service a system of organisation which is backed up by a tremendous amount of hardware-boats, planes and helicopters-to a degree which shames Australia, which has a coastline far greater than that of India and therefore presents far greater opportunity than many other countries to those who transgress. We have a responsibility to our future and to our young people to ensure that the drug trade is kept to as low a level as can possibly be maintained. This Government must look far beyond the meagre and totally ineffective operation it now has and, as I have said, must establish a single command to put in place proper surveillance forces.

I do not criticise the Australian Federal Police, the Army, the police forces of the various States involved, Customs officers or the Royal Australian Navy. We have people who genuinely in the interest of Australia are doing their best to protect our future. What is lacking is the determination of government to give them the necessary organisation and equipment to carry out their duties. I strongly urge the Minister for Transport and Communications to lift his sights beyond the current failure in relation to the Amann contract and to consult his colleagues to establish an attitude to coastal surveillance which will be effective, understand the priorities and provide funds to back up the organisation which hopefully will be set up in the next few years. This could totally turn around the Government's ineffective attitude and provide the protection on which so many of our young people in future will depend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address a few remarks to the communications side of this rather extensive portfolio which we are now considering under the Appropriation Bill (No. 1). I wish to draw attention to the affairs of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS), Australia's two national broadcasters. I support unashamedly some form of amalgamation of these two broadcasters. It is ludicrous to continue to support through public funds two completely separate broadcasters. I have long put the view that if the present situation is allowed to continue, we will see at some time in the not too distant future, within 10 years or so, the SBS network withering on the vine. If the present situation continues that will happen because a government down the track-it may not be this Government but a government in about 10 years' time-may well say, `We will not front up with a couple of hundred million dollars'-as the figure will be by then-`out of the public purse, for a separate broadcasting authority to run in competition with the ABC'.

SPEECH.PARA: I have made many speeches in this House in my seven years here stating that Australia should have a dual national broadcaster under the one board-a little like the ABC has with its radio network, Radio 1 and Radio 2. Speaking as a Melbournian, in that city it is 3LO and 3AR and one station is directed more to popular entertainment, the other specialising in more particular aspects of broadcasting. I think that this is the only way to go and I believe that it will occur; it is only a matter of time before sanity prevails. The SBS has done a marvellous job. What I propose will ensure that multicultural broadcasting continues. If we allow the present situation to continue and let that network stand out by itself, multicultural broadcasting will hit the fence somewhere down the track, lock, stock and barrel.

Dual national broadcasting under the one board is the only economically sensible system under which we can have planning incorporated into a dual broadcaster. It will enhance Australia's independent programmers and producers as they look to producing programs for the second network, such as the Channel 4 system in Britain. There is no network like that in Australia at present, except for the occasional example of such programming on ABC or SBS. Because each acts independently, neither broadcaster has come near the Channel 4 position in Britain. Neither broadcaster has enhanced the lot of Australian program producers or independent producers one iota in the last seven or eight years since the introduction of the SBS. I believe that this will come about and I think that sanity will prevail.

Despite all the people who are saying, `What about all the ruckus?' and all the people who were dead against the merger and caused so many problems when the Government announced its original decision, I really believe most of that opposition came from professional ethnics. In the last Parliament I was Chairman of the Government's communications committee and I am still waiting for the first person to come into my office and complain. I received two letters about the amalgamation; one was against it and the other came from an ethnic organisation which was in favour of it. Apart from that I am still waiting. I have opened my doors and I was willing to put a sign out the front for all the protesters to come, but no one fronted. Indeed, the vast majority of the ethnic communities could not care less. It is mainly the professional ethnics, who want to sit on various boards and put their hands in the bickie tin, who are really complaining about it. It is a selfish attitude because the SBS will hit the fence in another 10 years if it is allowed to float along in the way that it is. This is notwithstanding the fact that it has done a very good job.

The other issue I want to raise relates to the prescribed interest in regard to television in particular. Because of the quite substantial changes that the Government made earlier this year-the biggest changes in television in the 30 years since its introduction-the old 15 per cent prescribed interest in a television station went by the board. At present it sits at 5 per cent which means that there are several people who are in breach of the existing law and who are waiting, believing that the Government may lift that back to the old, traditional 15 per cent rate. There have been rumours that the Government is looking into that. It has not come before the Government at this stage, but I am sure there will be a vigorous debate within the Government about it. I put it on notice quite strongly that I will be dead against any lifting of the rate above 5 per cent. Indeed, on the issue of cross media ownership I quote the Treasurer (Mr Keating) who said, `You are either a prince of the print or a queen of the screen'. If one is to have a genuine cross media ownership, the figure should really be zero. But I will give in to 5 per cent. No one has put one argument to me-not one solitary argument-as to why it should be 15 per cent. Why should the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), with all his millions of dollars or whatever he has in the bank, be able to buy up to that amount of interest in a company? Why should Rupert Murdoch, Kerry Packer or whoever be able to buy into stations? Whilst they will not have control, they have a significant influence because, if they want to, they will have a position or two on the board. They are not there doing it for nothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are undermining the principle.

—As the honourable member for Aston has said, they are undermining the principles that the Government introduced in this legislation earlier this year. As I said, it is interesting that no one has put such a proposition to me. In fact, the only proposition that has been put to me is that the interest was always traditionally 15 per cent. I consider that the Government really turned the rules on their head earlier this year when it did a complete turnaround and changed the system completely. In changing the system, the Government ensured that a number of things went out the window. The 15 per cent rate, to my mind, went out the window. To alleviate the concerns of institutional investors exemptions can be made-we can set a certain limit for them. That situation exists now; it does work and there is no reason why that should not continue. I am not against institutional investors buying into a company, but individuals should not be allowed to buy in above the 5 per cent rate that presently exists. If someone wants to own half of Australia's newspapers et cetera, so be it. But, as the Treasurer once said, `You can't have both'. If the proportion were raised to 15 per cent it would be a complete undermining of the spirit of what the Government was on about earlier this year in respect of cross-media ownership. I think there will be a rather vigorous debate about that. I am still waiting for a reasonable proposition to be put to me for why we should move to lift the proportion to 15 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: One could raise many other matters, including Telecom Australia, Aussat Pty Ltd, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission and, indeed, the possible extension of radio licences-which I am also against-but they will have to wait for another time because they would involve rather lengthy discussions. I am quite certain that such discussions will be held within the Government and I hope they will also be held within this chamber. I support the Government's estimates and I trust that the Committee will, too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to follow the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles) in this debate and, indeed, to express my own concern about the future ownership of some of the media outlets in Australia. I know that I do not agree with every honourable member on my side of the chamber on the matter of the new bidding system that is being proposed for new licences in the electronic media field. Before we proceed right down that track, I think that we should be very careful indeed to make sure that we know exactly what we will be getting ourselves in for. I think some of the points raised by the honourable member for Isaacs impinge on that. One of the real worries is that we will have more and more in the electronic media in Australia a greater command by the big members of that particular community; that we will see bigger and bigger companies gaining more and more control of our electronic media. I think that is particularly relevant in the case of radio and it must be of particular concern to a great number of members of this chamber that we are likely to see a diminution of the amount of creative talent, of the creative broadcasting, that for so many decades now has been associated with commercial radio in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a fact that commercial radio around Australia is under real pressure and, in many cases, a lot of those stations are having real problems-not at the moment because of the bidding for a licence system but because of the technology involved. It is fairly well established that in most of the markets where FM radio stations are operating the FM stations have the audience and their share of the revenue. I know that Brisbane in my home State has one FM station which has about 26 per cent of the audience and commands about 32 per cent of the revenue that is spent on commercial radio in that city. That has put tremendous pressure on the AM operators there. They are struggling now to make a living. What has happened is that the amount of money that they would previously have spent on creative broadcasting has now been put aside. Basically, we are finding that the AM radio stations of Australia-not all of them but a great number of them-have had to revert to being no more than electronic juke boxes. One puts on the record and announces the time and that is all there is in it-because these stations do not have the money to spend on creativity. That is a great shame.

It will also be a great shame if we find a preponderance of the big operators taking over so many of these new licences, because I am afraid that they are in it for the financial return that they can get rather than to make a creative contribution to the electronic media industry in Australia. We should be very careful indeed to ensure that we do not see our whole commercial radio operation come under the control of perhaps three or four operators, as has probably happened with the Press and television. We have probably gone so far down the track that we will find ourselves in Australia completely networked by virtue of the latest moves in the television industry. There is a great argument for networking around Australia, but it does mean that the whole of Australia will get very much of the same television and that we have the possibility of losing some of that creativity in the television industry. But we still have a chance with radio to be one of the leading countries in the world in terms of the quality of the broadcasts being put out. I hope we do not allow the present situation to go on much longer because, as I understand it, there are more than 40 AM radio stations around Australia that are presently in a loss situation, and many of those commercial radio stations are in fact in our capital cities. I think we should be very careful to try to preserve that very special part of Australia and those very special services, especially in the rural areas, and are contributed to by the AM radio operators.

As this particular debate today covers both transport and communications, could I turn now to the area of transportation and a couple of things that I would like to raise briefly. The first one is the situation regarding the new Brisbane International Airport, which I understand was going to open originally in September of this year. At this time we do not have an official opening date, despite the fact that Australia is heading towards its bicentenary operations, that Brisbane will host Expo 88 in April next year, that we have had the most incredible increase in the number of international tourists coming to Australia, and that at many times during the week Brisbane International Airport cannot handle the present traffic that is flowing in there. I ask the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan) whether he can give us a definitive date as to when Brisbane International Airport is going to open. Most importantly, can he spell out the timetable for the construction of the new Brisbane International Airport terminal?

I have been in this place long enough now and have spoken in debates such as this about the desirability of that airport terminal. But the plain facts are that we have been caught with our pants down because the decision not to proceed with that international terminal was made before the increase in the traffic for the Commonwealth Games; it was made before the tourism boom took off; it was made before Expo was given to Brisbane for 1988, and we really have got a farcical situation now where Brisbane International Airport terminal, which was originally designed as a store shed, is trying to handle the most incredible increase in the number of visitors coming through that city. I would like to stress to the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support the need now to get everything into operation and get that new international terminal building not only to handle the present traffic but to overcome a number of the technical difficulties that will come about once the new airport is opened and we are still operating from the old international terminal.

International jets will have to taxi up to 14 or 15 kilometres at Brisbane to reach their take-off point. There will be some technical difficulties in terms of the heating of brakes of international jets which are going to use that particular airport and the cost that will be involved. My suggestion would be that as the Government already has the plans for the new Brisbane International Terminal it should look as fast as it possibly can to turning the whole thing over to private industry. I suggest that the Government should call for tenders from the private sector for the construction of that terminal. It would probably be completed and up and running in time for Expo 88 next year. Rather than go through all the difficulties we have had in the construction of Brisbane Airport over the last decade, for once let us ask the Government to hand it over to private enterprise and get the airport up and operating.

Already Brisbane has seen what the dithering of the Government and the construction authority has meant in terms of loss of traffic. British Airways, on two occasions, has said that it was told that the airport would be operational in September. It put together its schedules for operation into the new curfew-free Brisbane Airport, but now that the airport cannot operate I understand that Australia is losing four services a week from British Airways alone through Brisbane because of that dithering. I ask the Minister, too, in light of the fact that Senator Evans in the other place today will make a major statement about deregulation of Australia's domestic airlines, when is there a chance of the Government making an investigation into possible further deregulation and loosening up of the system of international operations into Australia.

Despite some of the garbage that we read in the newspapers-and, unfortunately, some of that emanates from Qantas Airways Ltd-regarding the United States routes, there is very great difficulty on a number of those routes getting seats into Australia at the moment. At a time when better than 60 per cent of the traffic coming into Australia consists of foreign visitors, I think the time is ripe now to start loosening up some of our agreements and allowing some additional capacity on selected routes. We know the story about Japan, and an announcement was made this week that Qantas was going to provide more services on the Tokyo-Australia run. But even those additional services are not enough. If we are really going to go out for this tourism boom we have to make sure we capitalise on it as much as we can as fast as we can. We are not going to do that when seats into Australia are not available at certain times of the year. I sincerely hope that the Government will try to overlook some of the intransigence of the people in the Department of Transport and Communications and sometimes of Qantas-but not always-and will allow a greater capacity on some of those routes. The Japan route is building up well and the routes out of Asia are also building up well. It is almost impossible to get a seat over the Pacific at the moment because of that traffic. The European traffic is also building up.

I hope that, after the statement which the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) will be making today, both he and the Minister at the table will look very closely at opening up a greater variety of air services, perhaps away from Sydney and Melbourne, into his home city of Adelaide, where airlines want to operate at the moment but cannot, and into Perth, into Brisbane and into north Queensland, in particular. If the airlines want to go there and can justify the international traffic, I believe those rights should be guaranteed so that we can get maximum benefit out of that inflow of international tourists.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Saunderson Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a number of concerns about broadcasting, in particular, one about the changes which the Government has made to the ownership rules. What has concerned me and, I think, a lot of people has been the way in which, with the freeing up of the rules, the purchase of television stations and the transfer of the ownership of those stations have on two or three occasions happened before the organisations have been able to settle down properly. We have seen a rise in the value of some stations. People would argue that in many instances they are overvalued. My main concern is that the role played by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in determining the correctness or otherwise of people in a position to be owners of licences is being subverted by the process of transfer of ownership prior to any approval by the Tribunal. The Government has held discussions in relation to this. I know that my colleagues have supported the view that I have put-that we should revert to the position of approval being given prior to the actual transfer of the licences.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe it is essential to ensure that the integrity of the broadcasting system and its service to the community is maintained in a fashion that we expect. It is also essential, in my view, to ensure that the licences do not simply become assets available for transfer for quick capital gain by people who have no interest in broadcasting or in providing a long term service to the community. If we do not do something about this, we will leave ourselves open to a drop in standards of service which will not be appreciated in areas where there is less choice, particularly the rural areas.

Another thing which concerns me and which was mentioned by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), is the decision to go to auctioning of licences. I have some serious reservations about the way in which that would be handled. I think that in the end the Government should rethink its position on this. It is not a good situation to be in if we say that the person who is most cashed up at a particular time is the most suitable person to be involved in broadcasting. I do not walk away from the fact that there are profits in broadcasting. Certainly in some areas people are doing very well out of it, but in other areas it is not necessarily super-profitable. It is not necessarily good for the industry overall to be in a situation in which the wealthiest people automatically obtain the licences simply because they can out-bid everybody else. In the past people have applied for a licence and, after a hearing, the Tribunal has made a judgment as to the best applicant. That is an appropriate way to go. It may well be argued that the Government should be gathering more money from licences, because there is no question that a new licensee has an asset which becomes a commodity. I would not object to some form of bonding system whereby people pay bonds for the licence which would be transferable upon some future sale.

Another area of my concern is the print handicapped. There are a substantial number of such handicapped people in Australia. Some are totally blind; other have a partially handicapped reading capacity. They have great difficulty following the news and keeping up with current affairs. In a number of capital cities radio stations have been set up providing what is called radio for the print handicapped. It is unfortunate that the Government has not given them as much support as we would have hoped. I know they had hoped to receive substantial assistance in the Budget, and it is a great pity that we have not paid greater attention to providing better services for those attempting to help the handicapped.

I would like to take up another question which also relates to handicapped people, that is, Telecom Australia's attitude to serving the community. Many honourable members would know that, as an ex-Telecom employee, I have been a fairly staunch supporter of Telecom. However, over the last few years I have become very disappointed with Telecom's attitude to the social concerns it ought to have. One area in particular is the provision of telephone services for the hearing impaired. Telecom has consistently refused to provide services for the hearing impaired in the form of telephoning typewriters. These instruments enable people who have a severe hearing difficulty to communicate with other people via the telephone system. As Telecom refuses to assist these people by providing these telephones via the normal rental service, they are forced in many instances to spend thousands of dollars to be able to communicate with members of their families. Telecom spends thousands of dollars providing services for people in the remote outback-which it should do. It subsidises, by cross-subsidy means, telephone services in regional areas. In many suburban areas people receive subsidised telephone services. So it is a great pity that Telecom refuses to provide a service for this small group of people spread throughout Australia who suffer greatly from isolation, even though many of them live in capital cities, simply because they cannot communicate via the normal system. The service would not cost a substantial amount of money in relation to Telecom's overall turnover. It is something Telecom ought to pick up as part of its community service.

Another area which disappoints me is Telecom's attitude to its customers and to face to face contact with the public. Telecom has begun a program of closing down its business offices, which are the only public forum in which people can come to Telecom and talk face to face with a person who knows the system and who can help them with problems with their accounts and with advice on Telecom instruments they may wish to utilise. Telecom has an appalling record in consumer affairs. It is a backward step for Telecom to close down its only public forum and provide only telephone contact for the public to communicate their problems to Telecom and obtain services from it.

It is something that is not done by any other organisation providing public services to the community. Certainly people in private industry would not operate in the same way. I think it shows an appalling attitude to the community. Telecom should be made to reverse that decision and begin to open itself up to the community which is, after all, its customer. I am most concerned about the way Telecom is turning itself into a monstrous bureaucracy which is uncontactable by the community other than through its telephone service. If one reason for contacting Telecom is because your telephone service is not working well, it is not much good that one must contact Telecom by telephone. If your telephone is not operating then you must find a public telephone.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, it is my pleasure this morning to speak in the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1). In doing so I commence by supporting the comments made by the honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson) regarding the proposed auctioning or calling for tenders of FM radio licences. Suddenly the Government seems to want to take this new initiative. I am unsure why the extra revenue is needed as the Government has been long winded in espousing the fact that the 1987 Budget is a balanced Budget, although many millions of dollars had been borrowed from overseas in the meantime before this point has been reached. However, in the last few days we have had a number of people in the House who are interested in getting into the business of establishing FM radio stations throughout Australia, but who suddenly find that the Government wishes to introduce a tendering system whereby the rich get richer and the poor get poorer.

SPEECH.PARA: I thought this Government was concerned about equalisation in the community. That is what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is on about all the time in rhetoric, but in fact things do not work out that way. It is the Prime Minister's big mates in big business who seem to get their bellies scratched. This is happening again in the field of radio. If this type of situation continues, rural Australia will be disadvantaged. It will kill regionalisation. Similarly to the new television arrangements, the big operators will have the dollars to put up front to gain the FM radio licences. When the envelopes are opened, the big operators will have the greatest number of dollars in the envelopes and they will get the licences. As the honourable member for Aston said, it does not matter how good they are at broadcasting or how good they are in the long term with providing radio services; it is the money that will talk.

I like to think that the National Party of Australia is opposed to this type of operation, in the same way as it opposes the auctioning of oil exploration licences and the up-front taxing of coal exports. The honourable member for Aston mentioned Telecom Australia. The total appropriation of $1.15 billion for the Department of Transport and Communications is a reduction of 3 per cent over the previous year. It is not as if the Government is gung ho in this area of communications, although it should be. What we have witnessed in Telecom is a cutback and we are forcing it to pay sales tax for the first time. Indirectly Telecom has grabbed at tax by forcing the people, the users of the telephone service, to pay more for their telephones. Hundreds of thousands of people in my electorate still do not have access to a subscriber trunk dialling (STD) telephone. The digital radio concentrated system now being used-an Australian invention for which I congratulate Telecom-is being installed throughout my electorate in the far south-west of Queensland. I have recently visited Thargomindah, Innamincka, Noccundra and Jackson.

TALK.START.PARA: —They would be pleased to see you.
—They were. It is not often they see me but they were pleased to see me on this occasion.
—How is Innamincka?

—Innamincka is very good. Telecom is operating out of Thargomindah into Innamincka with the digital radio concentrated system, but because this Government has imposed even more taxes on Telecom, the whole program has been put back at least two years. Many of these people do not have phones at all. They are waiting for Telecom to put in new equipment. Those who do have the old earth return system that hardly ever works these days are waiting for the new equipment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party is supposed to represent all Australians, but again it is slamming the people in remote areas into the ground and forcing them to wait. It is all very well for most of Labor's constituents who live in the capital cities and who have STD phones that work probably 99 per cent of the time. They operate on an untimed call system. They do not have to pay for any operator assisted long distance calls. Most of their business is done within the city limits. These people have all the advantages of this technology, but people in inland Australia who continue to produce the commodities for export in an attempt to improve the balance of payments position and maintain our standard of living find that they cannot get a decent phone system to carry out their business. They are not able to keep up with the rapidly changing technology.

I would also like to congratulate the Department of Transport and Communications for completing, at long last, the construction of the radio station in Charleville. Jim Corbett, my predecessor in the electorate of Maranoa, was instrumental in getting the funding for this stat- ion back in the 1970s. At long last a station is operating out of Charleville. It means that people in that area can hear some radio. Some parts of Australia are so isolated that one is able to drive completely out of contact with radio communications, especially in the day time. So people in the far south west, in the Channel Country, who are within two or three hundred miles of Charleville, are now able to get a better Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) radio service. I congratulate both the previous Government and this Government on continuing to fund this project and at long last completing it. No doubt I will be attending the official opening of this station in some months time.

Whilst I am on communications, I would like to mention the lack of any reference in the Budget Papers to remote area television. I asked the previous Minister for Communications, the present Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy), to support Australians who still do not get any commercial television service. At long last we have a satellite system, for which taxpayers have paid half a billion dollars, which provides an ABC service throughout Australia, but there are still no commercial services for some areas of Australia. Yet we have seen this Government, and our Party in the Senate, support the previous communications regulation which called for the aggregation of existing commercial television stations. People in regional areas who had one service will now have three. My great beef has always been that those who live in real isolation in this country do not have proper services although we have the technology and we have launched yet another satellite, only three weeks ago, from Guyana. We now have two satellites that we can use. There is plenty of transponder space available, yet this Government fails to do anything about giving a commercial service to the inland. It is an abomination and it is something I will not stop talking about until these services have been provided. Although the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan) who is at the table had a rocky start, I suggest that he up his act and talk to Biggles about getting some action taken in this area. It is high time he did.

The other thing I would like to mention is the subsidies that are provided for inland air services. They have been whittled down. We have the local aerodrome ownership development program which was granted $7m. It is a continuing function that councils are involved with. I point out to the Parliament that this Government seems to be able to hand out money willy-nilly to all sorts of welfare organisations and to its mates, yet funding for roads, the infrastructure of this country, has not increased for the last four years. There has been zero growth for road funding. The level of funding remains at $1.2 billion. As the shadow Minister for Local Government, it is my intention to howl from the rooftops until the Government increases the amount of funding made available for the road system of this nation. There is no point in our talking about wanting to lift exports and balance the Budget if we let the infrastructure fall to bits. We need to be able to take our wool, wheat, produce, cattle and sheep to the ports in this island nation of ours. If the whole road system collapses during this Government's term of office it will be a disgrace.

Yet we see in the Budget an item for a subsidy for the bus service in this fair city of Canberra. The subsidy on the ACTION bus service has gone up by 10 per cent and is now at $19.2 million. Canberra probably has the best road service of any city in Australia and yet we see fit to continue to subsidise that service. There does not seem to be any user pay principle applied. Great long buses run around and around in circles in the city, with hardly a soul on them, at a cost to the taxpayer of nearly $20 million, and I believe it is a disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating in committee Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88 and dealing with the estimates for the Department of Transport and Communications. I support some of the concerns raised by the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron).
—He's a good member, too.

—I would not like to be confused with the honourable member for Maranoa. I will never forget when the Canberra Times attributed to me a statement that was made by the honourable member for Maranoa because of the slight similarity in the names of our electorates. But I do support him on a number of issues, particularly on the important issue of feral animal control, on communications in country areas and on a wide range of other matters about which we share a common concern.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson) also raised concerns about Telecom Australia. The Managing Director of Telecom Australia, Mr Mel Ward, has recently announced the principles driving what he terms the new Telecom. I believe there is some room for optimism in the attitude of Mr Ward. First of all, the new Telecom will be truly customer driven. It will have the principle of differentiated service to different customer groups. It will give full account to the dual imperatives of financial success and service quality and it will operate through units focusing on achievable results, with each manager truly accountable. This will involve quite a change in management style and a strong management information reporting system. Responsibility and accountability will be taken into full account to the lowest level in the organisation. Telecom will be decentralised to make it closer to its customers. So, while I share the concerns of the honourable member for Manaroa and the honourable member for Aston, I point out to them that Telecom intends to change.

The honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) raised problems, as he saw them, with coastal surveillance. All I say to him is that the present operating format for civil coastal surveillance is substantially the same as that put in place by the then Liberal Government in mid-1978. It was changed only marginally in 1982. So, while things may not be all that we desire, and I believe we have a lot more to achieve, we certainly should take into account the fact that this Government is relying mainly on the previous Government's record in development of coastal surveillance. However, we are building on that.

For instance, in 1983 there was a review by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) of civil coastal surveillance arrangements, which concluded that there was no benefit in giving the task to the military on the grounds that there is no substantial correlation between peacetime civil and contingent defence surveillance requirements. The different targets and the basically different nature of the threat being confronted lead to a divergence between the type of surveillance operation needed in peacetime and that needed in a situation of military threat.

But, at the same time, I believe we ought to take into account the substantial role of voluntary groups in coastal surveillance. You, Mr Chairman, have traversed with me much of the electorate of Eden-Monaro when we looked at lightstations at Green Cape and Montague Island as part of an inquiry by the Standing Committee on Expenditure. You will have realised that local community groups and the lightstations play an extremely important role in coastal surveillance. The lighthouse keepers and the people in the voluntary coastal patrols get messages from the Australian Customs Service, the Australian Federal Police who have responsibility for civil coastal surveillance vested in them, and the State police. But I mention particularly the voluntary organisations which take seriously the work that they do not only in safety but also in providing information which is required by Customs and other organisations to deal with the important matters raised by the honourable member for Boothby, particularly the possibility of smuggling, especially drug smuggling.

The honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) raised problems with the Brisbane Airport. I just briefly mention that there was protracted negotiation of lease terms and conditions for Brisbane Airport. I hope that the Government will take into account the fact that a busy school holiday period is coming up. With the change from the old to the new airport in Brisbane, it is very important that adequate time is allowed for staff to be trained and familiarised with the new airport. Even more importantly, there has to be an internationally agreed date for the promulgation of new or revised aeronautical information. I know that the security and the processing of passengers arriving on flights have to be looked at. We have to look at representations made by the Australian Federation of Air Pilots on that matter. It is important that the Government, while proceeding as quickly as possible, take those important matters into account.

I point out to the honourable member for Fadden that there have been other instances where construction has been substantially in the hands of private contractors and where there have been overruns of completion times and low standards of workmanship. I was not particularly happy with the record of the Canberra Airport--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a shambles.

—It is a shambles. That airport services not only Canberra but also my electorate of Eden-Monaro and the electorates of Gilmore and Hume. Neither the Government, representing the taxpayers, the consumers, the users, nor the people involved in employment there should have had to put up with the overrun on completion time and the standard of workmanship of the contractor involved.

SPEECH.PARA: Another matter that I will just briefly mention is the new Federal Airports Corporation, which will assume responsibility for Australia's 17 major civil airports, including the international terminals, as early as possible in 1988, bringing a new coherence to the administration of the nation's aviation infrastructure.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought you were going to sell them off.

—The Government's decision, which was incorporated in the Budget, to proceed with the Corporation and to retain public ownership of the international terminals really reflects the Government's determination to enhance the efficiency of airport operations, to encourage innovative and commercial use of airport terminals by airlines and to put in place the most efficient possible regulatory regime. I am sure that members of the National Party of Australia, who could be described as agrarian socialists or bad weather socialists, agree with me that it is very important that those aspects are properly looked after, particularly in country areas.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the most exciting areas of policy in the next year or so will be the area of transport and communications. The Government's policy committee, which I chair, has an exciting and very busy year ahead. In the past couple of weeks it has dealt with today's statement on domestic aviation and to come in the next year are serious considerations about the future of telecommunications in Australia and our overseas telecommunications network, vital waterfront issues and national broadcasting issues. Important considerations will also crop up about media ownership, about safety-not only at sea, but also in the air and on the road-and about important road programs.

As the honourable member for Maranoa said, it is important that we look at road programs, but I point out to him the substantial increase in road funding, in real terms as well as in money terms, that has occurred since 1983. There was a substantial input in road funding in 1983 and 1984 and the Opposition is being quite unfair when it overlooks that substantial increase. Even in the past year there had been no reduction in road funding in money terms.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I want to talk basically about roads. I was interested in the comment that the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) has just made. None of us would disagree that there has been an increase in road funding over the last four to five years, but this has been brought about by the bicentennial road funding program, a program which was initiated under the previous Administration by the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) when he was Minister for Transport. I was on the committee which talked about this matter for months. It is an innovation which has certainly been of tremendous assistance to the country and city roads of Australia. As has been stated, there has been an increase in road funding.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is terribly dependent on transport and communications. We in the Opposition respect the necessity for some expenditure restraint, but it all comes back to basic priorities-what we believe should be the priorities for Australia and what the Government believes they should be. The Opposition, particularly the National Party of Australia, of which I am a member, believes that there should be increased expenditure in the Department of Transport and Communications compared with what is given to other departments.

This morning I want to mention roads specifically because I believe they are of great importance to Australia. They are our life-blood in getting our products to market, our children to school and our goods to the waterfront for shipping, but particularly in the actual community and social life of people who live in the various parts of the outback of Australia. The honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron), the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) and the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar), who are all in the chamber this morning, all represent far-flung electorates in this great continent of ours.

It concerns me that this year the Budget Papers show a reduction from $1.323 billion to $1.313 billion in land transport funding. The funds available to administer the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Act were $848.841m last year but are only $739.35m this year. There has been a reduction in the funds available for the maintenance and building of roads in this country. It is important to realise, irrespective of what the honourable member for Eden-Monaro says, that this Government has brought about a reduction in road funding in Australia.

The Pacific Highway is in my electorate. I travelled it at the weekend. It needs a dual carriageway. Many other main arterial roads throughout our continent are badly in need of upgrading. The ordinary arterial roads that serve rural communities and the rural and urban roads have to be upgraded to cope with the number of vehicles that are travelling on them. Today the amount of goods being carted over our roads is greatly in excess of what it was years ago, simply because the manufacturer and receiver of the goods are looking for expediency and efficiency in transport.

Our railway systems are not meeting our transport needs, so industry has to depend upon our main arterial and national roads; and they are unable to cope with the very great demand placed on them today. I press that point: We are very dissatisfied indeed that the Government has seen fit to reduce the basic funding for roads in Australia. This is not necessary when one looks at priorities. If I am wrong, I hope that the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan) will point out where my figures, which I cited from the Estimates, are not correct. If he looks at page 352 he will find those figures. This year there has been a reduction in road funding, and that is what I criticise. I appeal to the Government to help local government and the States with this issue. Today we are loading local governments with lots of responsibilities which they argue are not theirs. They now have to look after more things than they had to previously, but what matters to local governments is that they must provide roads, kerbing, guttering, drainage and sewerage-the basic services and amenities that are so essential for people living within the community.

Australia is a growing and developing country. I am sure that our friends in the gallery are very dependent on trade with Australia. They want us to produce our goods cheaply so that we are able to compete with other countries. Our friends have to look after their economies. They want to deal with Australia and that is why they are here. They are looking to us to provide them with goods which we are able to produce efficiently. That is why roads are an important issue.

I want to raise the matter of our fuel freight subsidy. According to the Budget Statements, the total outlay for the subsidy will be cut by $8.5m this year. That is a 52 per cent cut on the 1986-87 level. Actual outlays will amount to $7.8m as opposed to $16.3m last year and $21m the previous year. What this adds up to is that the differential between the cities and the country has virtually gone, so we will place an extra burden on those people who are producing particularly primary, agricultural and mining goods in outer parts of Australia. I raise this matter because it involves increases in costs to the consumer of at least 4c a litre to 10.2c a litre. This is patent discrimination against people living in the country areas of Australia. The National Party remains firmly committed to reintroducing a meaningful and equitable fuel freight subsidy scheme for people living in the outback of Australia.

I turn to communications. I do not know much about FM radio stations. There are two in my area and they appear to be efficient. But what impresses me about them is the fact that local people were able to start them. The other night in Forster, the Great Lakes Area, 2GLA celebrated its birthday. I was there and it was a wonderful party of 600 local people. All of the community had got behind the station and put in the money, and today it is thriving. What will the Government gain by the auction system it is talking about? Will it deprive those people of their own FM station? Will it give it to the bigger boys, who will be able to outbid the local people, the business people and others who live within the community? I sincerely hope that will not be the case.

I want to raise the subject of the provision of telephones in caravan parks. My electorate is on the coast and is similar to areas along the whole coastal belt of Australia. There must be a change in policy as to the provision of services to permanent dwellers in caravan parks. They must be offered a service at the same standard rate paid by other people in the community, but at present that is not happening. I would like the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support to examine this matter which is most important for permanent caravan park dwellers. Yesterday the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) said that 450,000 people lived in caravan parks. Most of those people are aged people or young family folk who are working and who require telephones. I wish to say a few words about public telephones, too. I know that vandals are pulling them to pieces but they are an important facility in our community. Why cannot a credit card system for phones be introduced on the same lines as that used in the United Kingdom? In such a system money does not have to be put into the machine. This might be a way to discourage the vandals.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUNCAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to only a couple of points in this debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) dealing with the Department of Transport and Communications. The point made by the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) about the provision of telephones to people living permanently or temporarily for a reasonable period of time in caravan parks was a very good one. I do not know the details of Telecom Australia's policy on that matter, but I shall certainly take up the point to see that something is done to ensure that those people can be provided with telephones. That is eminently sensible and I see no reason why such people, assuming that they are living in caravan parks on a fairly permanent basis, should be deprived of telephones. That is a worthwhile suggestion and I shall look at it.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the opening of the Brisbane Airport terminal, I can now tell the Committee it is expected that the opening will be in February next year. There are two matters delaying a final decision on the date. One is that the fit-out by the domestic carriers is under way, but as yet the Department has not been advised when that fit-out will be properly completed, although it is anticipated that a date in February would be appropriate. The second reason why a decision is being delayed is that, even if it were possible to open the terminal earlier, in other circumstances that might be desirable but because Christmas is the heaviest period of use of these facilities it is felt that, in order to arrange a proper transfer from the old domestic terminal to the new one, that process should not take place in the heaviest traffic period of the year. Rather than to open it earlier if the terminal is ready then, my advice is that it would be desirable to wait until February next year to avoid that rush period of the year.

On the issue of road funding, I would like to see an increase in such funding, as would everybody in this place. It is easy for Opposition members to rail at length against the Government because we have not been able to increase road funding in real terms this year. On the other hand, members such as the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) are very happy to get up in this chamber and congratulate the Government on the fact that it has balanced the Budget. They cannot have it both ways, as everybody knows. I am saddened by the fact that we cannot give a higher priority to road funding, but it is fair to reflect on the fact that this Government has spent far more on roads than has any previous government. That is a well-known fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, through the bicentennial levy.

—Of course it was part of the bicentennial program. We intend to continue that program, and details of the new program will be announced shortly. The Government's record on roads is second to none. I ask people as they drive around Australia to cast their minds back four or five years and recall what our road system was like then. They should compare that recollection with the present state of our roads, which is demonstrably better. Anybody who drives around the roads of this nation can see that under the Hawke Government the situation has improved dramatically. We have a very good record on roads and we are proud of it. We shall continue to ensure that roads are given high priority. I hope that we shall see a return to an increase in road funding in future, but the need now was to ensure a balanced Budget. We have achieved that balanced Budget, and I believe that the Government should be congratulated on what it has been able to achieve overall.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs
Proposed expenditure, $196,653,000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to examine the immigration program announced at the time of the Budget by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Young), and a couple of other factors in this area of Government responsibility. In announcing the 1987-88 immigration program the Minister said, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: The program therefore will continue to place a sharper focus on the economic benefits of migration while at the same time maintaining its commitment to social and humanitarian needs.

In fact, the Government has consistently steered away from the basic economic factors in its immigration program. If one examines the proposals for the current year, one notices that family migration is up but that the skilled labour, business, independent and concessional program is down as a percentage of the total program. Those factors are altering the balance of our immigration program.

The coalition parties have argued consistently in this Parliament that it is beneficial to Australia to maintain a consistently high immigration program. However, we will not convince Australians to maintain that program unless it takes into account economic factors. Despite the Minister's statement, the Government has not maintained those economic factors this year. Sure, in raw figures the program is up in economic terms, but as a percentage of the total it is not. I believe that this drift should be examined by all Australians. I am pleased that there is to be a review of immigration factors and the immigration program, and that the Immigration Review Panel will report to the Minister and the Parliament by March next year. I hope to make a contribution to that process, but I am disappointed that the Minister continues to press the Government line that the underlying factors are economic. They are not. If this country is to grow, develop and accept a large immigration program, the community needs to be assured that people's jobs and opportunities are not threatened by a substantial unskilled migration flow. That is the concern in the community at the moment.

We on this side of the chamber have the shared objective-shared to a greater extent on this side than among Labor members-that a large immigration program is good for Australia. That shared view will be presented effectively only if we can explain to the Australian community that immigration is beneficial, that the reviews and surveys conducted by the Government are sound and are being expanded. One review commissioned in 1986 by the previous Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs indicated that only 5 per cent of immigrants admitted to Australia because of their high skills are unemployed, compared with 18 per cent for all recently arrived immigrants. That is according to the Department's survey. So there we have it. That survey showed that the total program produces unemployment at a level of 18 per cent whereas the economic factors produce an unemployment level of 5 per cent.

If we were to look at various sections of the program, we would find that unemployment is higher than that 18 per cent for some categories of migrants. I am not mounting an argument that we should preclude family reunions from consideration, nor should we endeavour to change the processes of family reunion. I am making a sustainable argument on economic grounds that the Government can honestly present. It is no good giving this matter the flick pass with smart words because the Government will not convince Aussies that way. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs in his statements has tried to gloss over the change in balance that has continued since this Government came into office. That will not be convincing to the Australian community and the sons and daughters of those Australians who are currently employed and who wish to see their young people employed. I am concerned about this matter. I want to warn the Government that it should not follow that path, because it does not help the debate on immigration.

If we are to press forward and take advantage of the technology, the skills, the entrepreneurial spirits and the drive of new arrivals in Australia, we must go forward in a way that the Australian people can accept and understand. I want the Minister to look at the program after the review is finished and see whether adjustments should be made to it. We would argue for an increased program drawing more people here who are job creators. In that way we would balance the immigration program. I argue that the only way to balance the program is to increase it with people who can make a major contribution. They are available and there are no shortcomings. One only has to look at this year's figures to suspect that there is a shortage of business migration applicants. That is not true. There are plenty of business migration applicants around the world. They are being delayed inordinately-17 months for a business application from Cologne. What is the Government on about? Is it concerned that a terrorist businessman might want to apply from central Europe? We are talking about some of the financial capitals of the world. A delay of that sort is just unconscionable and gives a false impression about the degree of business investment that could be available to Australia.

I have noted and included in the calculations I have made the independent and concessional immigration program because that in part is economic-not completely, but in part. In my call to the Government to give greater emphasis to economic factors by an expanded program, I have considered the new independent and concessional immigration portion of the program. Also in these estimates I wish to draw to the attention of honourable members the strange arrangements that may exist following the Minister's decision to authorise work for genuine applicants for residence or refugee status. We had a long running debate here on the identity card, and the constant argument of the Government was that illegal immigrants take work away from Australians. By his discretion, the Minister has given the capacity and opportunity to work to those people awaiting the determination of their status. No one knows on what basis a bona fide application will be assessed. Will there be a three-assessment process: pre-assessment on whether the applicant is allowed to work, a second assessment made by the Department, and then a determinative assessment made by an immigration review panel? How many processes does the Government want?

The situation has arisen where it is possible for someone to come to Australia, marry, seek to stay here, get divorced, enter into a de facto relationship, run the gamut of appeals right through the system and three or four years later be allowed to stay on compassionate grounds because he has built a family, a house and a whole series of contacts. That system has to stop. I trust that the review will give its attention to the inordinate delays that have brought about the Minister's decision to allow people awaiting a decision to work in Australia. If there was a pinching of jobs process, this must be it. In order to solve the delay problem, the Minister has decided to allow people to work. On what grounds? Will they be issued with a temporary visa or a conditional temporary visa? I think not a conditional temporary visa, but a temporary visa to allow them to work. That almost certainly will qualify them for Medicare and for a stronger consideration of their claim for permanent residency. That Press statement, which was issued to solve the problem of a few refugees who went off social security, due to the May economic statement, has now come home and is creating problems.

Finally, I wish to warn communities around Australia that their opportunities will be somewhat restricted under the Government's decision-making process. There was not a line in the Budget about funding for the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia. I believe that the Government basically mistrusts migrant community groups because during the election campaign they ran a campaign on the English as a second language program which the Minister did not like.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is in the Prime Minister's Department.
—Well, it did not appear in the Budget Papers.
—It is not in my Department.

—The Minister says that it is not in his Department, but he felt strongly enough about the situation to suggest to these councils that they should moderate their criticism of the Government in order to gain consideration from the Government. It may have been more veiled than that but I am concerned that there is that threat that these groups should accommodate themselves to the Government.
-Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been sitting here listening to the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) and I feel that he is a little bit unfair-in fact, grossly unfair-when he says that this Government is not serious about its policies on immigration. It seems to me that over the last couple of weeks the Opposition has been very strong on rhetoric but, when it comes to the facts, it does not particularly like to acknowledge them. I see from the Budget allocation to the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs that the Government is very conscious of the part that immigration plays in the community. In fact, the Budget allocation is positive proof of the Government's commitment to the area of immigration and ethnic affairs. There will be an obvious general expansion of the level and quality of services provided to the community. Of course, it will cost a little bit more but I think we all understand that these costs are not something that will be taken lightly by the clients or the people who require these services. But by the same token I think we all know that we are in a situation of budgetary constraint. The actual increase in the level of services that will be given to people will more than adequately compensate for the increased receipts. I am certainly against a lot of the increases, as the Minister knows, but by the same token I think the increased efficiency and the delays that will be scrubbed out as a result of the extra receipts will more than adequately compensate those people who will feel a little bit hurt by the extra moneys that will be taken off them.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the major initiatives relates to the immigration review committee which advises the Government on Australian immigration policies. Again, the Government has done something substantive to look at the problems that we have with our immigration policies and to see whether they can be improved. I, for one, would like to see an increase in the family reunion program. People of my own ethnic background-I understand there are about 10,000 of them-are waiting to come over but they do not come within the guidelines of the family reunion program. Of course, in some continental families, European families in particular-and that is the area in which I have most knowledge-sometimes one's first cousin, uncle or auntie is just as close as one's father or mother, or son or daughter. Obviously this is something which the review committee will look at, and I am sure that it will come up with some recommendations.

The Government has actually increased funding in a lot of areas. In addition it has increased the migrant intake for the 1987-88 year from 115,300 to 120,000. That is nearly 5,000 more. I would like to see a lot more than that. Obviously many of us who believe in migration would-by all means. But by the same token we cannot do everything straight away. It is a step in the right direction. The fact is that we are bringing in an extra 5,000, and this matter will probably be looked at even more closely again by the new immigration review committee that is being set up.

One matter I find very interesting relates to the recognition of overseas qualifications and the Fry Committee of Inquiry into the Recognition of Overseas Qualifications. Extra funding has been allocated to that area. Probably there is nothing worse than highly qualified migrants coming to this country and then finding that they cannot get their qualifications accepted by the Australian authorities. In many cases their qualifications are probably higher than those required for Australian conditions. But again the Government is looking at that matter and it is prepared to see whether there is some way in which the mechanics can be improved so that we can arrange to have these qualifications looked at and, in some cases, accepted. I have to commend the Government and the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Young) in that regard. I think it is a very worthwhile exercise.

The matter of receipts, as I said, is certainly one which I find unpalatable. I am sure many members of the migrant community will also find it unpalatable. But while the fees for the various services have increased, obviously those fees do not represent the actual cost to the Department to provide those services. The receipts will grow sharply as a result of the new fees. But, whilst the Government regrets the increases, I am sure that the faster and more efficient service to clients which will flow from that measure will please most users of the services. I take up the point made by the honourable member for Mitchell about delays. We cannot bury our heads in the sand. There is no doubt that the delays have been very bad, particularly in respect of immigration review panels. We know that. But by the same token the Government has done something concrete to try to fix that up.

TALK.START.PARA: —It took them three years.

—This Government has done more in 3 1/2 years than the previous Government did in 10 years. The fact is that it is prepared to do something and it is doing it. It is putting the money where the mouth is, so to speak. We are actually bringing these services in. The staffing levels will be quite significantly increased, again as a result of the extra budgetary allocation that has been made.
—Ten people.

—The honourable member says, `Ten people', but let us have a look at the immigration review panels. This is one of those areas in which there are great delays. We all know that. They can be anything up to 18 months. But the fact is that the Immigration Review Panel membership will be increased by a massive 125-from 32 to 157. Panels will be established for the first time in Brisbane, Adelaide and Perth, in addition to the ones that already exist in Canberra, Sydney and Melbourne.

SPEECH.PARA: At this particular stage I would like to say that I was most upset when recently I saw in one of the local Brisbane newspapers some strong criticism from one of the migrant groups. The spokesman actually criticised the membership of the panel in Brisbane. I want to say that I know three or four of those fellows personally. I can say that they have the highest qualifications and I am sure that they will prove excellent people for that immigration review panel. I refer actually to the previous member for my seat, Mr Keogh, and also a gentleman by the name of Jim Fouras.

TALK.START.PARA: —Jim is a good member, a good bloke.

—He certainly is a good member and a good fellow. He is the sort of person who has the qualifications to do that job. This touches on one thing that the Government is very good at. It does not do what the Queensland Government often does. In fact, in Queensland, unless one is a friend of the Queensland Government, one cannot get on to any statutory body. But this Government even put Greg Chappell on the immigration review panel in Queensland. The honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) would be happy to know that.
—He's a gentleman!

—Yes, but he is certainly someone who supports the honourable member's side of politics. We do these things because we want to make sure that we have the best possible people on those immigration review panels. It is an area on which I think the whole of the community will congratulate the Government. It makes nonsense of the statement of the honourable member for Mitchell that the Government is not serious. It is serious and the increase is an incredible increase. I am told that the backlog of cases will probably keep the Immigration Review Panel membership busy for some 12 months. But I am sure that we can then knock down the 18-month delay to something like six months. I am sure that is what the Government wants and I hope that that is in fact what happens.

SPEECH.PARA: Another matter on which the Government ought to be congratulated is the fact that it has actually allocated $1.3m for the State-based language services. Unless one deals with migrants who have these language problems one does not understand just how much this particular service is of value to them. Of course, the Commonwealth Government already funds the telephone interpreter service, and this $1.3m will go a long way to helping the situation. In addition, I understand that a review process has already been begun to see whether there can be an improvement in the area of co-operation between the States and the Commonwealth.

There can be no question that the Government is serious about improving immigration policies. We are looking at this matter; we have set up the review committee. There are many people out there in the migrant community who are waiting with a great deal of anticipation to see what is in the report that it will bring down. I commend the Government for its improvements in its immigration policies, and I commend it particularly for what it is doing in respect of increasing the number of immigration review panels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak this morning to the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88 at the committee stage, particularly to the area of local government. Unfortunately, we do not get many immigrants out in Maranoa these days. We did once upon a time under the assisted passage scheme and the subsidy scheme whereby property owners used to give them jobs and encourage them to work. These schemes no longer operate and generally migrants all end up in Newcastle, Fremantle and Sydney, I suppose.

SPEECH.PARA: But those of us who still live in inland Australia have to be very interested in local government. I am very pleased to have been appointed from our side of politics as the shadow Minister for Local Government. It is an interesting and responsible position. Local government represents 900 councils in Australia and probably something over 100,000 councillors. They serve a very useful purpose in the third tier of government. Having served on the Tara Shire Council in my own area for nine years, three terms, I am very keen to support this level of government. I believe it is most important. It carries out very vital day to day functions in the lives of all Australians-basically, the maintenance of their road systems and providing most of their essential services. This is something that continues. We have complained earlier in the Budget debate about the funding of this area. Unfortunately, although the appropriation for the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs is $197m, up 11 per cent, that is for the Department. I guess, as with all good governments, departments tend to grow from strength to strength; whereas funding for the more essential things like roads tends to diminish.

There has been quite a bit of debate on road funding. I ask the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Young), who is at the table, whether I may table a graph from Budget Paper No. 1. It was prepared by the Government's Treasury people. It shows that there was no increase in funding in 1985-86 or 1986-87.
