It shows also that there has been no real increase in total road funding from the Commonwealth since 1983-84. So, in effect, there have been five years now in which there has been no real increase.

There was quite a substantial increase in 1982-83. Honourable members might like to do an arithmetical computation and take into consideration the fact that there should have been an increase due to inflation. I always argue that bush inflation runs about 10 per cent higher than the so-called consumer price index figure that is given to us. There is nothing more costly than maintaining and building roads in isolated areas. With the enormous costs of fuel to cart all the metal and with the work involved in carting the material and housing people, it is a very expensive exercise. These days one does not get much length of road for $1m expended.

This graph covers a five-year period including 1987-88. The Australian land transport program is shown in black with the Australian bicentennial program on top. If they are added together, the figures show that there has been absolutely no increase in five years. That is a disgrace. I do not know how any Government can expect local authorities to continue to maintain the road system, let alone construct new roads, under this sort of funding arrangement. If a reverse calculation were made, one would find, in effect, that councils are worse off now in real terms than they were in 1982-83 when the Government increased the funding. That is a fact of life. One only has to spend a bit of time in the bush to see that.

This Government wastes money on employment programs trying to create jobs. If the Government gave local authorities adequate funding, they would pick up and employ all the people around every small country town and every metropolitan city throughout Australia. In most towns in Australia the local authority is by far the biggest employer of people, which is important for families. If the local authority had to close down, the town would practically fold up and we would lose this most essential facet of maintenance of our road system, our sewerage system and our water system. The local authority has to do all these things for the people. Mr Chairman, I would like permission to table this graph. That should put to rest any argument we had in the previous debate about the fact that real funding has not increased for the last five years.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The other things that I would like to touch on in particular are the new general grants to councils and the new criteria that this Government has put in place. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs sits opposite with a big grin on his face. It is a bit like his redistribution Bill. It was very well done. Of course, it helps his side of politics. The same thing has happened with the new criteria for funding. The old 2 per cent of general revenue funding that came from our personal tax fund-although it is not done in quite that way, but that is the way it was introduced-disadvantaged country councils, and under the new criteria this Government will do that again.

SPEECH.PARA: In Queensland alone 11 councils have been disadvantaged. After much negotiation during the local government conference that was held recently at Surfers Paradise with the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds), the Government decided to take the 11 councils that were funded under last year's allocation back to what last year's allocation was by increasing their funding by 5 per cent. The new criteria will be introduced over a period of six years. Some rural councils in Australia will be disadvantaged more than 50 per cent at the end of that six years. I do not know how anybody could call that good government. I think it is a disgrace that new criteria should be introduced.

Councils have employed people; they have purchased machinery and put in place equipment for doing the jobs that they have been doing under this funding arrangement, and all of a sudden the rug is pulled out from under them. They have no means of raising revenue other than continuing to increase rates. Things have not been good in the bush. It has been very dry. Many industries, particularly the grain industry, have been severely affected by the recession. Honourable members hear the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) every day in the House talking about the world recession and how bad things are and that is why Australia has been running up horrendous debts.

The new funding arrangement will apply in Queensland, although the Queensland Government has not yet agreed to the new criteria, but in the Labor States, which have agreed to the new criteria under the Grants Commission, basically rural shires will be disadvantaged. Of course, this Labor Government is moving its funding away from areas of need, away from the area of real productivity in this nation, to the area of people. The only determinant seems to be the number of people that live in a particular area. It is much cheaper to operate a council in a highly populated area than it is to do so in rural areas. Under the new criteria, no allowance is made for isolation, the fact that there might be a new oil field or the establishment of a new coal mine. Nothing in the criteria allows for extra funding to help councils get on with the job at this very important level.

I must say that it is important for us also to remember that under the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services other programs are in place. There is a $2.7m allocation to the local government development program, which is the same as last year. There is quite a deal of funding available to the Albury-Wodonga Development Corporation-$430m. I am not quite sure why that Corporation continues. It seems to have been put in place and the Government cannot get rid of it. That is a hangover from the Whitlam era. He was going to regionalise every area in Australia and do away with local government, but fortunately he was put out of office just in time and that did not come to pass.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —From the outset I would like to take the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) to task. It may be only a small pedantic point, but as he is the shadow spokesperson on local government I think it needs to be brought up that he referred earlier in his speech to local government as the third tier of government. Having previously been a local government practitioner myself, I think there is a greater need to recognise the role that local government has by talking about local government as a sphere of government. By referring to it as a tier, it conjures up in one's mind a hierarchical thing, and that is not quite appropriate. The honourable member for Maranoa might like to take that on board. Local government should be seen as a partner with the other spheres of government at State and Federal level.

SPEECH.PARA: The Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88 provides for an expansion in the service to the community provided under the portfolio of immigration, local government and ethnic affairs. There is an increase in outlays of some $20m. The Budget implements a number of promises made in policy statements in the run-up to the election. It also contains an announcement of a modest increase in the migration program from some 115,300 in 1986-87 to some 120,000 in 1987-88 and, importantly, the statements indicate that this increase in the migration program will be matched by a commensurate increase in post-arrival services.

The definition of post-arrival services and when the responsibility of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs ceases is a vexed point. That is a matter of debate amongst ethnic communities. Post-arrival services conjure up in a lot of circles different periods of time. Some believe that the care of aging European migrants, especially those who came here in the immediate post-war period, could be catered for under post-arrival services. If we used the wider definition of post-arrival services and perhaps called them settlement services, that point of view could be sustained. This is a vexed question that the Government has to come to grips with, because there is an expectation that perhaps we need to look at those post-arrival services in that wider immigration policy context.

I wish to spend some time discussing three of the programs that are indicated under our settlement services. The first is the grants-in-aid scheme. I note and welcome the increase of $140,000 which will provide an additional eight grants. Of course, we can always say that that is insufficient, but at least it is a move in the right direction. The grants-in-aid scheme enables many ethnic communities to have a greater degree of self-help in catering for their welfare needs and is an important part of our post-arrival services.

Another program that has had an increase in funding is the migrant resource centre program. I welcome the continuing Government support for those centres. Again, in an ideal world, we would like to see more centres as a tool to enable those ethnic communities that see the need to develop a greater degree of self-help. I thank the Minister for his visit to the Broadmeadows migrant resource centre last week and for taking the time, in a busy schedule, to sit down with the members of the committee of management of that migrant resource centre to discuss problems that they saw both with the program and with the wider issues in the immigration and ethnic affairs field.

One of the important increases in this Budget is the 17 per cent increase in funding for the adult migrant education program. Figures accompanying the Budget estimate that, of the new migrant intake this year, 27,900 visaed settlers over 16 years of age will have poor or no knowledge of English. The increase in funding for this program is an indication of the Government's commitment to ensuring that new migrants are given the opportunity to learn English. It is also complementary to the initiatives in the English as a second language program for children which are being undertaken as part of the Government's national language program. Again these are areas where, if we could, we would perhaps give more resources. But at least this Budget helps to improve the situation.

In June this year I was pleased to attend the opening of the Broadmeadows English language centre at Broadmeadows High School. I note the presence in the chamber of the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), who was also present at that opening. I think we should acknowledge the efforts of the honourable member for Calwell, previously the honourable member for Burke, in that regard. He was quite a driving force in getting that language centre off the ground. In many ways the community education centre is a unique development, and it is a great credit both to the Federal and State departments and to the school community at the Broadmeadows High School that it was put in place. This centre caters for not only adult migrant education but also child migrant education, the home tutor scheme and various ethnic schools conducted by local ethnic communities, such as the Turkish, Arabic and Spanish communities. This is a good and fine example of an ability to maximise the use of scarce resources. I think that all those who are connected with the Broadmeadows English language centre should be congratulated.

I look forward to the Government's response to the Fry Committee of Inquiry into the Recognition of Overseas Qualifications and acknowledge the $200,000 as a special Budget allocation which will help to improve the procedures used to assess the professional qualifications of migrants. There have been some delays in this area and I think it is important that the Council on Overseas Professional Qualifications continue to play its important role in assessing overseas qualifications and skills and ensuring that those assessments enable migrants to obtain jobs where their skills can be best put to use to help the economy. It is widely recognised that the non-acceptance of overseas qualifications is a constant factor in the under-employment and unemployment of immigrants, and that is simply a waste when we are trying to maximise the potential human resource that our migration program gives us. In fact, many of the migration cases that I deal with in my office concern the problem of the acceptance of overseas skills and this has an impact by delaying assessments of applications.

I welcome the announcement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), put down in the policy statement before the election, that there would be an increase in staffing for immigration review panels. The panels that will be established in Brisbane, Adelaide and Perth are also welcomed. They will enable a higher degree of service to be given in those cities. I note that the departmental staff that will be involved in the review processes have been increased by 85. I think that the Government needs to get the message across that the increase in the staff numbers in the immigration review process, et cetera, has been enabled, in part, by the increase in fees and by the institution of new fees. I think we have to acknowledge that those fees for the review panels have been introduced on a user-pays basis. The modest increases in the other fees are again on the basis of the user-pays principle, and I think it is important to get that message across.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse very much what my colleague the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) had to say about the difficulties faced by those who seek recognition of their qualifications. I think all of us have experienced the problems of advising people who have settled in Australia and who find that qualifications which would be regarded as outstanding in their own country are not recognised here for a variety of reasons. I think that situation demands a good deal of advocacy, particularly amongst the professions that are notoriously conservative about recognising overseas qualifications. I commend the honourable member for his remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: In a speech that may be full of bouquets and brickbats I suppose I ought, in the 10 minutes I have, to get on to the brickbats. The first relates to the Government's announcement during the election that it would establish a committee to conduct a review of immigration. In the context of immigration, where we have achieved an element of bipartisanship, which I think is very welcome and important, I regret that the Government has put aside, for the time being, its advocacy of immigration programs for an inquiry, which would suggest that many matters that might otherwise have been beyond doubt can be reviewed. I have looked carefully at the terms of reference. I wonder why we are having an inquiry when the Government seeks to circumscribe the terms of reference, as it has, although I must say that I welcome that circumscription, particularly when the Government has emphasised that the inquiry, in carrying out its work, must `have regard to the principles that Australia's immigration policies are non-discriminatory in respect of national or ethnic origin, race, sex and religion and that it is a sovereign right of the Australian Government to determine who should enter'. Having raised in an election context expectations that the wider issues of immigration might be examined by some form of inquiry, then to circumscribe it is certainly not going to meet the criticisms of those who do not believe in immigration. It means that the efforts that the Government, along with the Opposition, ought to put in place to ensure that there is a proper understanding of why active immigration policies are important for Australia's interests are put to one side. I hope that the Committee will work through its report quickly and that it will be helpful in developing the Government's resolve once more to become a forceful advocate of high levels of immigration in Australia's national interests.

In my efforts to offer bouquets I take the opportunity to commend, for the second occasion in a debate in the Parliament, a report by an honourable member opposite on a particular aspect of immigration. I am glad that the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) is in the chamber. I am still carrying with me his report entitled The Tragedy of Kampuchean Refugees. I regard the report as a very thorough, well-prepared and important document which I would like to see the Government respond to. I strongly believe that unless the Kampuchean question is addressed we will be creating in our own region a problem of enormous dimension for ourselves as a nation. The dispossessed people of Kampuchea will become the Palestinians of Indo-China in the generations ahead unless the problem is overcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —Operating out of Site 2.

—Operating out of a number of sites on the border. I have visited a number of those sites. Site 2 might be one. As we know, the Khmer Rouge are in a number of other sites. They are no slouches when it comes to, I guess, undermining the situation in Kampuchea, so far as those who are in charge there now are concerned. Whilst one does not want to ascribe motives to those who are involved, those who have seen the situation where this difficulty, this dilemma, that we face remains unresolved, one suspects that there are wider political motives involved in ensuring that this position continues because of the prospective destabilisation in the area. I think we ought to be doing our part to address the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the questions which I hope the Government will answer-I will raise it in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade estimates debate when the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) might be able to comment-concerns its view of Hun Sen's statement that the Kampuchean Government might now be prepared to negotiate with Khmer Rouge leader Khieu Samphan to seek a political settlement of the Kampuchean war. It is important to know the Government's view of that situation because we need to work on the political front as well as on humanitarian aspects when addressing this problem.

What has concerned me-this is another brickbat, in a sense-is the extent to which the Government has been exhibiting what in South East Asia is called compassion fatigue. We have seen a continual rundown in Australia's commitment to deal with the Indo-China refugee problem. Under the refugee program for 1983-84 we took 15,485 people; in 1984-85 we took 14,207 people; in 1985-86 we took 11,700 people; and in 1986-87 the figure was 11,300. It does not take a wizard to understand that there has been a reduction each year in the refugee program under this Government.

Not only have we seen a reduction in the number of people taken as refugees but we have seen also a reduction in the number of people we have taken from Indo-China, from Vietnam, Kampuchea and Laos. We have a continuing emphasis on the part of the Government to run down the Indo-Chinese refugee program and to build up the numbers we take from other parts of the world. I do not want to suggest in any way that there are not situations in which there are refugees whom we ought to be viewing compassionately but I think we must have regard to the particular problems in our region and to our future. We have to recognise that there is an ongoing problem in Indo-China that needs to be addressed. We need determined action on the Government's part to ensure that the ongoing problems of Kampuchean refugees in particular are addressed.

The report of the honourable member for Calwell highlights the problem we face in our region. I commend to the Minister the recommendations by the honourable member for Calwell. In his report he highlighted the rundown in the number of Kampucheans being brought to Australia. On page 17 it states that, in 1983, 4,399 Kampuchean refugees were brought to Australia. These figures are recorded by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR). In 1984 the figure was 816; in 1985, 1,082; and in 1986, 736. His recommendation-it is one that I support strongly-is that the Government should announce as soon as possible that it will sustain at least the same level of Kampuchean refugees in the 1987-88 and 1988-89 immigration programs as that adopted for this year. He said that that recommendation should be communicated to the UNHCR. He went on to refer to the closure of the camp at Khao-I-Dang. That is a matter of ongoing concern, particularly the large numbers of people who were moved out of Khao-I-Dang and back to Site 2 and whom we do not know whether we will be able to process as refugees to Australia.

The Minister has lists, provided by the Kampuchean community, of relatives who ought to be capable of sponsorship. I would like the Minister's undertaking that those lists will be properly assessed and expeditiously dealt with, and that the Government will be making efforts to ensure that those families will be reunited in Australia under a humanitarian program which pays proper regard to the urgency of the situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) on his continuing interest and concern in the Kampuchean refugee issue. He has spoken to me privately about it, as well as having publicly promoted the cause of those refugees. The report entitled The Tragedy of Kampuchean Refugees, which the honourable member referred to, has been considered by the Government and by the Caucus immigration and ethnic affairs committee. Most of the report's recommendations which related to administrative arrangements have been adopted. Some of the recommendations-the honourable member referred specifically to the recommendation concerning the proportion of refugees to come from Kampuchea-are part of the overall immigration program and can be announced only within that context. However, as I said, the recommendations relating to changes in administrative arrangements have been adopted. I understand that changes have been taking place.

SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member will know, the Kampuchean situation is that the border camps are not recognised by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees as refugee camps. That is the problem. Our officials-this is stated in the report-have great difficulty even in interviewing people in these camps. They have to pretend to be doing something else in order to get to interview people. So we have a political problem which has to do with the classification of these people. It is also a problem which has to do with the general politics of the Kampuchean situation. I believe that we ought to be taking it up. Through the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden), we have continued our attempts to find a resolution to the complex crisis of Kampuchea.

Without such a resolution there is no future for those people, especially those on the border. This was the point I made in the report and the point which is being made continuously. I understand the Minister will soon be visiting Kampuchean refugee camps, where he will be able to see with his own eyes the problems referred to in the report. I urge that we as a parliament must in a bipartisan way not only ascertain what we can do to assist those people, especially those with relatives, to come to Australia, but also see what we can do to resolve the problem and ensure that those 300,000 people return to their homeland, rather than be stuck in a no-man's land situation.

Mr Ruddock, I know that you have been there yourself, but I assure honourable members that the situation is dreadful. At Site 2, for example, there are 140,000 people at a camp that has no electricity, no water and no market-place. Day after day people must line up to receive food and water. It is outrageous that people should have to live in such conditions. Australia has done a great deal to try to resolve the position, through the actions of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and through the humanitarian assistance given to the United Nations program to assist those people on the border. But let me say that I hope the Government will continue to regard the plight of the Kampuchean refugees as a priority. I believe their situation is in some ways more desperate and more serious than that of many other groups. On those points I certainly agree with your comments, Mr Ruddock.

In the time available, I wish to refer to a couple of other points about the Budget allocation for the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. In some ways the immigration aspect of this Budget is probably the most comprehensive and the most generous towards multiculturalism that we have seen for a number of years. Let me say this: many of the congratulations for this achievement must go to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Young) for the work he has done. Prior to the recent election, many people considered that some of the changes being made in multiculturalism and ethnic affairs were cosmetic, that they were only for election purposes, and so on. What has been proved since the election is that this is not the case, but the Government has an unshakeable commitment to multiculturalism and to a sustained and growing immigration program. In this context the Minister deserves congratulations on all that has been done.

The immigration review which has been announced is extremely important as it will look at immigration within the context of economic policy, population policy, and humanitarian considerations and obligations. In that context it will be the most important review for many years of where this nation is heading in terms of its composition. I congratulate the Government on establishing the review. I wish the review committee well, especially Dr Stephen FitzGerald, its eminent Chairman. One of the things I find extraordinary is the little publicity given by the mainstream media to the announcement of the establishment of the review. The review will look at what is probably one of the most important aspects of our future as a nation, yet it has received almost no publicity.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a deafening silence.

—As the honourable member says, there has been a deafening silence. All I can say is that I believe we should be supportive of the inquiry. I urge the community to make submissions and representations to the inquiry. Let us make it a comprehensive review. Anyone interested in any aspect of the immigration program-whether it be the composition of the program, a points system, review procedures, or overall factors such as how many people we will have in Australia, where they will be located and how to cater for them-should make representations to the inquiry. Even people opposed to immigration, those who do not want any more immigration-such as Dr Bob Birrell with his continuous comments-should make representations to the inquiry and let them be analysed and scrutinised. Let their facts be brought forward and analysed and scrutinised by the committee secretariat. As far as I am concerned, very often Dr Birrell and others make statements against immigration which have no foundation in economic or population terms.

SPEECH.PARA: The other aspect I wanted to refer to briefly, and on which the Government should be congratulated, is the national language program. That program, which was funded to a considerable degree in a difficult budgetary situation, is proceeding. It is an exciting program that will transform the teaching of languages in this country. It is about time Australia had a sustained national language program which ensures that every person can be taught English and which at the same time will give Australians generally an opportunity to learn other languages, whether they be the major community languages, the major Asian languages of our region, or the Aboriginal languages which are unfortunately beginning to disappear. Undoubtedly this is one of the most important cultural programs introduced by the Government. The Government should be congratulated on its actions.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr YOUNG
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Ruddock, I wish to thank the honourable members who have participated in the debate this morning on the departmental appropriations and to reply to some of the comments made, including some of your comments relating to the refugee program. Perhaps I could deal with those first, as you are at present in the esteemed position of Deputy Chairman of this Committee. The figures do not lie; it is true that there has been some slight reduction in the overall migrant intake. However, when talking about the Indo-Chinese refugee intake, one must take into consideration the program commenced by the previous Government to try to cement orderly departure from Vietnam, as against giving the impression that our future programs were to be based completely on just taking people out of the refugee camps in Indo-China.

SPEECH.PARA: To some extent we have been successful in the orderly departure program from Vietnam, so those figures do not show up as part of the refugee program. Australia has always placed emphasis on orderly departure. We recognise the importance of our humanitarian programs. As indicated yesterday by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in some ways we are frustrated in seeking approval from the Soviet Government for the departure of people who have already received approval to migrate to Australia. In some cases we do not have complete control over the numbers or the people to whom we have given approval to migrate to Australia, as the governments of the countries from where they emigrate do not give approval for them to depart.

When one is talking about the Indo-Chinese refugee program and the numbers involved, I think one must take into consideration the number of people who might be leaving Vietnam under the orderly departure program, through family reunion, and other aspects of the total migration program. As you would expect, Mr Deputy Chairman, I have had several meetings with the Indo-Chinese communities around Australia. I am more than aware of the frustrations they face in relation to the programs. In some cases I have been present when there has been discussion between them about who should be given the greater priority.

As honourable members know, the Laotian and Kampuchean people think that too much emphasis has been given on some occasions to the Vietnamese and on others to the Laotians. It is a very hard formula to unravel. The Government, of course, in the final analysis remains committed to a refugee and special humanitarian program which pro rata, I think, is second to none in the world. If we look at other settlement countries, none is doing more or better than we are. But we have to put the program in its total context. We are not just talking about a separate refugee program for Indo-China. When I meet with people from the Afghan community they say they would like greater consideration given to applicants from the refugee camps in Pakistan. When I talk to the Timorese community they have the very peculiar and unique problem of the many people who were taken out of Timor at the time of the Indonesian takeover and who have gone to Portugal. They are considered Portuguese citizens and now cannot be interpreted as refugees. They were for some time, under a special humanitarian program, given the right to come to Australia. That has not been in place for some years, so we have some members of families here and some members of families in Portugal, and we have some people still trying to come here from Timor. They would like special consideration.

There is the continual civil strife in Lebanon. The Lebanese communities, whenever and wherever one meets them, say that they would like greater consideration given to their people to come here. We do not even have an office in Beirut because of the security problems. People have to travel to Damascus to put in their applications. Processing takes much longer than we or the communities would like. When we talk about these refugee and special humanitarian programs, we have to understand the enormous pressures that are building up in Australia and our capacity to deal with them. We now have a very large Spanish-speaking community. People have come from trouble spots in Central America; in some cases from camps in Honduras, Costa Rica and other places.

We have to be able to say about this aspect of our migration program, as well as about every other aspect, that we are not discriminating in favour of or against any group. If the United Nations, with which we work closely on these issues, declares a certain group of people to be refugees, it expects the United States of America, ourselves, Canada and other settlement countries to help out. The final word about all this is that whatever the correct number is, whether it be 10 million, 15 million or 20 million refugees around the world, the settlement countries are never going to be able to solve the problem. We can never talk in terms of all these people being settled.

The only way we are going to be able to solve these problems is by political solutions. If Gorbachev decides to take the Russian Army out of Afghanistan and the Afghan refugees return to their homeland, in one swoop the vast problem of the Afghan refugees now situated in Pakistan will be overcome. If the Vietnamese Army gets out of Kampuchea we might solve a great deal of the problem of people in the camps in Kampuchea. This is the only way in which we will get a final solution to the problems of the refugee question around the world.

But in terms of what we are doing, it is incorrect for people to speculate that we are not doing as much as other countries or that we could be doing more. When the Government decides on the migration intake each year, it has a system of calling for submissions from over 300 organisations around Australia in order to get their views. Their views range from cutting out migration altogether to taking in 350,000 or 400,000 migrants. So the Government has to make up its mind about what it thinks is right and wrong and about the various categories. Many of the comments have been on the refugee question. Whilst the Liberal Party put out a policy statement before the last election saying it would have an intake of, I think it was, 145,000, I do not recall the Party saying that there would be any increase in the refugee program. I think it was basically the economic area which--

TALK.START.PARA: —We would maintain our responsibilities.

—Yes, but the Party was basically proposing increases in areas where it was thought that skills may be needed. Our view, of course, is that there is a two-pronged approach to the skills area. We recognise that there will be gaps in the Australian work force that can be closed by bringing in skilled people, but foremost we do have a responsibility to do whatever we can to provide training for people who are already in Australia to fill those jobs. To that extent, we have done an enormous amount by increasing the number of apprenticeships, investing in training and in education. Whilst we will never reach the zenith of being able to fill every job that may be required in Australia, our first and foremost responsibility is our investment here to train people to do the jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a skilled labour intake and we have an employer sponsorship intake. But we have mechanisms that deal with these things. We have employer and trade union representatives who look at the make-up of the labour market, agree on the shortfalls and agree on the intake. That is a mechanism that has worked very successfully under previous Liberal governments and under this Labor Government. It is not something that should be interfered with easily by saying that we are going to bring in a whole range of skilled people in the hope that they will find jobs here, thus overriding the mechanism which has worked so successfully for governments in past years. We do not intend to interfere in that mechanism.

I could not quite grasp the point you were making, Mr Deputy Chairman. I understood that you thought I had put some restrictions on the review of our migration program that will now take place. The only restriction I put on it-and I think this is the rock upon which the Parliament has made the policy about migration-is that there will be no discrimination. I do not think the Parliament should say to a committee, `We are asking you whether we are right or wrong in our non-discriminatory migration program'. I certainly was not, as the responsible Minister, going to recommend to the Government that we hand that power over to a committee; not that I think for one instant that the committee that has been appointed would do other than what the Parliament decided many years ago. Nevertheless, the Parliament has decided. I say `the Parliament' quite consciously because it is the Parliament, not just the government of the day, that made this unanimous decision not to have a discriminatory migration policy. It is not up to some committee to tell us otherwise. Apart from that matter, the terms of reference are very wide.

I expect that a lot of interested parties will come forward with their views. There are many people with very strong views about migration. I know that my friend the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) thinks our migration intake should be much more than it is at the moment. Nevertheless, we do have these problems and they are not just problems of the refugee program, the pressures that are building up or the problems coming out of Lebanon. I must say, from my experience, that some of the most acute criticism of the present system comes from some of the older established communities in Australia, such as the Greek community and the Italian community, which are very critical of the present system. They feel that it is discriminating against them. When people have these points of view-and it has been so long since we have had a total review and so much has changed in Australia-it is obviously time we reviewed the system again. Hopefully this review will take us well towards the end of the century. It is an important aspect of government administration in Australia. I hope that what comes out of it will be of great benefit to the country.

I agree with the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins). He raised a question which is not directly attributable to this portfolio. People who are interested in this area of immigration will know that if they ever go to a meeting of any of the communities, all issues are raised. They are not necessarily restricted to discussing matters which may be directly under my portfolio. One of the biggest issues the communities now have is care for the aged. That is continually raised with me and I have raised this with the responsible Minister. Apart from the package, which was announced last year, of some $40m for care of the ethnic aged through nursing homes, hostels and so forth, those people are facing an enormous problem. At every function that I go to, and in every group of community leaders that I meet with, which I am doing almost every day of the week, this issue is raised. It is something that governments will have to face up to more and more.

My good friend the shadow Minister for Local Government, the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron), was saying that some of us should visit the bush more often and get the feel of how local government operates in some of the remote areas. I must tell the honourable member that when I was 15 years of age I worked in his electorate at Cunnamulla, so I am well aware that the roads are much better now as a result of what we have done than they were in those days. I cannot see how he can legitimise his criticism of this Government's contribution to and recognition of local government. I do not think there is any person in the national Parliament more respected by local government than the former Minister, the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren), who had great influence in the Government in making sure that general purpose grants in particular were kept at a maximum level. The figure for general purpose assistance to local government in 1983-84 was $461m. This year it will be $642m. That is an enormous amount of commitment to local government throughout this country.

Another point about the recognition of the role of local government that people sometimes do not realise is that local government receives money from this Government through a number of programs, including those involving nursing homes, home and community care, Meals on Wheels, aged and disabled persons' homes, handicapped persons' assistance and children's services. In the children's services area, in 1983-84 local government received $21m. In 1987-88 it will receive $73m for children's services-an increase of 350 per cent in just four years, which is a significant indication of the importance that this Government places on children's services being provided through local government. There are lots of other grants made to local government in recognition of the role it plays in Australia. I agree with the honourable member for Scullin about the importance of local government.

I reiterate that, although the committee which I have set up to review migration programs is a very small committee, I nevertheless thought it important that a member from local government be on it. Mr Jim Hullick, who is the administrator of local government in South Australia, is a member of the committee which we have set up. So, local government will have an input into the final report that will be handed down to me. Some people have said that the committee may take a long time. I have given the committee roughly 26 weeks in which to carry out its work. As you, Mr Ruddock, know from committees of this Parliament, that is not a long time in which to carry out its task. It will be a very intensive task. The committee will have to meet with as many of the communities as it can and talk to all the interested parties.

I emphasise that this is not an exercise merely for the ethnic communities; it is an exercise for the Australian community. It is so important to the future of this country that any person-or group-who is interested should have the opportunity either to put in a written submission or to appear before some members of the committee to make his views known about what the continuing policy ought to be. It is an enormously important exercise. Hopefully, the final report will give us a lead on where the Government ought to be going in the years ahead. The policy is not something which changes every time we have an election. We try as much as possible to see that it can last for many years.

I thank those honourable members who have participated in the debate. I want to make a point about the Khao-I-Dang camp. Following upon the notice that we received that closure was anticipated, we immediately went into the camp and got special permission from the Thai authorities to interview card holders. The intake from Khao-I-Dang increased by 40 per cent. In raw figures that probably does not represent many people, but we were able, to the satisfaction of the Kampuchean community in Australia, to move quickly to get those people shifted out of the Khao-I-Dang camp and settled here in Australia. But people who are looking for long term solutions to the refugee problems in the world have to look for political solutions because we will never be able to solve them through migration, refugee programs or settlement programs when 10 million, 15 million or 20 million people are involved. We have to remember that a lot of community groups in this country would like special priority from this Government, but it is just not possible to give the priority that our hearts would like to give to all of those groups. The problems of settlement in Australia would be just overwhelming.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Department of Administrative Services
Proposed expenditure, $1,355,369,000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Millar Mr P.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —With your indulgence, Mr Ruddock, I would like to extend my appreciation to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Young) for his co-operation in a rather urgent situation. We are addressing the estimates for the Department of Administrative Services and I think it would be fair to say that at first blush the title of the Department could be described as innocent. It requires a more studied examination of its function to appreciate that the Department, by its very nature, could well be the instrument by which a great deal of mischief could be perpetrated. Indeed, in a statement in the handbook entitled Portfolio Programs 1987-88, the Department describes itself as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Commonwealth's major design and construction agency, the Department provides public facilities and structures central to the nation's continued development.
The Department operates some of the largest business undertakings in Australia through the provision of support services to Government departments and agencies.
Some of these undertakings, such as the Transport and Storage program are commercial enterprises.

Those are just some facets of its total operation. This brings me to what I essentially wanted to say in the limited time available to me about the role of the Joint Committee on Public Works as against those obligations that the Department must address. As honourable members will be aware, there is a requirement that all capital works programs in excess of $6m be referred to the Public Works Committee under ordinary circumstances. It has concerned me somewhat that there has been an increasing tendency through the 1980s for the Government to seek exemption from this requirement. I am pleased that the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) is at the table because he has been involved first hand in a number of these requests for the House to exempt from scrutiny by the Public Works Committee various projects, for reasons advanced to the House and found acceptable by the House.

Prior to 1980 it was a very rare circumstance for such exemption to be sought. As a consequence, since 1913 the Public Works Committee has addressed itself to protecting-it can be described in that simple term-the interests of the Australian taxpayer and the reputation of the Parliament. If these exemptions are to be sought with increasing frequency, or even the present frequency, we must be increasingly at risk. The reputation of the Department and its efficiency and effectiveness in all areas must suffer.

The Commonwealth Public Works Committee has been around since 1913 and is very highly regarded. It had predecessors in the State parliaments. It was Sir Henry Parkes who in 1888, if my memory serves me correctly, was instrumental in establishing the first Public Works Committee whose function he described in language appropriate to the day. I would like to read to the chamber what he said:

I conceive that it is our duty to preserve the power of this Parliament as unimpaired as possible over the whole province of the public expenditure. I think there can be no higher duty, no more sacred obligation, cast upon us, and I have sought in the Bill, the second reading of which I have just moved, to preserve the full and unfettered power of Parliament, and at the same time to throw around the expenditure of the public revenues the strongest security I could invent to prevent extravagance or misdirection in the expenditure of public money.

Whilst the language is quaint and in the style of the day, it was most forceful and appropriate. Whilst it was said a long time ago, it invites serious consideration by the Parliament of how the Public Works Committee should function. I know that there is a division of opinion as to how far the Committee should go in the area of capital works. Former Minister Killen took serious umbrage in his book at the Committee presuming to challenge the fitness of a Cabinet decision in respect of a particular project. He took the view that, if the Cabinet of the Government of this country should decide to do something, it was inexcusably presumptuous for the Public Works Committee to challenge the wisdom of that decision.

We have seen that situation occur quite recently in Canberra with the aviation training college being relocated from Melbourne. I will not regurgitate what the House debated at the time it addressed that matter, but it would be fair to say that members of the Committee expressed genuine concern as to whether the college should be relocated in Canberra. They argued that it could be more effectively located in another place in closer proximity to a major airport and that cost savings would accrue. However, the Government-maybe properly, maybe improperly-decided that it would be moved. No doubt the decision was made on advice from the Department of Aviation, which invariably is of a persuasive nature and which would ordinarily prevail if there were not an instrumentality such as the Public Works Committee which, within the terms of its charter, could properly address the project on the basis of whether the works were needed, whether the means proposed to achieve the objective were appropriate and whether, in the view of the Committee, it was regarded as wise and judicious expenditure of public moneys.

TALK.START.PARA: —Standing up to the Sir Humphreys.

—Precisely, even though some of the Sir Humphreys are pleasant and per- suasive gentlemen in their own right and their competence is beyond dispute, it is simply a question of how they are using it. In that respect, the representatives of the people of Australia are fully entitled to express a view, singular though it may be.

SPEECH.PARA: I have referred to the arguments for exemption, some of which are not unpersuasive. Recently we exempted from the Committee's scrutiny the Royal Australian Navy's survey motor launches. The exemption of the provision of new submarines almost imbues me, a past Vice-Chairman of the Committee, with a sense of relief. To conduct an inquiry into the submarine project in toto would be a daunting undertaking and perhaps there are valid reasons why it should have been exempted: there are only 30 hours a day and nine days a week! The Committee could have spent a long time on that project.

The rationalisation and redevelopment of property holdings in Tokyo was a rather unique project and could well have invited, indeed demanded, the close attention of the Committee. There are a whole list of such projects. I feel beyond question of doubt that, in the interests of the Department of Administrative Services, of this Parliament and of the people in the broad, we should desist from seeking exemptions from referral to the Public Works Committee for all projects of over $6m and at the same time should be on the alert to ensure that projects are not fragmented or sequenced so that an objective in excess of $6m could be attained over stages. That is something that the Public Works Committee should keep very much in mind, as it has done in respect of lease arrangements by the Commonwealth as distinct from the erection of new structures. In practical terms this achieved the same effect, but in the first instance Public Works Committee scrutiny of the project was sought to be evaded.

As I mentioned when I commenced my remarks, the Administrative Services Department, a familiar and innocent sounding title, contains extraordinary possibilities for neglect-innocent neglect at best-of taxpayers' best interests, but also have incredible scope for mischief to be perpetrated through neglect, indifference or an attitude of a singular nature which arguably is not consistent with the best interests of our country.

I have pointed out that the Public Works Committee has been around for a long time. In recent days it escaped the intention of the Government to restructure some of our committees so that it would cease to be a joint committee. There has been a reversal of opinion, for which I congratulate the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The submarines were trying to torpedo it.
—Perhaps, but I suggest that this debate is far too dry for submarines.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being past 12.45 p.m., in accordance with sessional order 101a, I shall report progress.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Deputy Chairman having reported accordingly-

TALK.START.PARA: —The House may at a later hour this day again resolve itself into a Committee of the Whole.

—I refer the Prime Minister to reports in this morning's Press that the most recent report on Australia by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) has forecast that our net foreign debt will continue to grow to new record levels of between 43 and 45 per cent of gross domestic product by 1992. On the basis of current policy settings and the latest advice from both the Treasury and the Economic Planning Advisory Council, does the Government agree with this forecast, and does it believe that it is a satisfactory path for our debt accumulation? In the event of any adverse external developments during the next five years, such as an international recession or a further decline in our terms of trade, what policy options would the Government consider to prevent our debt position deteriorating any further than envisaged by the IMF?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer and I have said, not only in the Budget but consistently inside and outside this House, that neither the Government nor the people of Australia should be complacent about Australia's external debt position. However, the Government's policies are appropriately aimed at correcting the external imbalance and stabilising the external debt over the medium term. We are doing this through this year's balanced Budget, through the more flexible and appropriate two-tier wages system, and through the fundamental ongoing structural reforms that we are bringing about in the Australian economy. I hope that the Leader of the Opposition will agree that there has been a significant reduction in the current account deficit-from 6 per cent of gross domestic product in 1985-86 to 5 per cent in 1986-87, with a further reduction to 4 per cent in prospect for 1987-88.

ANSWER.PARA: Our export base is diversifying. Again I would ask the Leader of the Opposition to note, and I hope he shares my enthusiasm in the fact, that manufacturing and tourism provided 24 per cent of our exports of goods and services in the last financial year 1986-87. That 24 per cent from such exports was a significant increase on the figure of 20.5 per cent in 1985-86. At the end of June 1987 Australia's net foreign debt, at $83 billion, was actually lower by $1.6 billion than it was at the end of March. This principally reflected a rise in the exchange rate in the quarter. Net foreign debt fell to 31.4 per cent of gross domestic product from 33 per cent at the end of March. I also note, and hope that the Leader of the Opposition has noted, the comments reported in today's Australian by Mr William Chambers, Vice-President, International Finance, of Standard and Poor's Corporation. His comment was that the policy responses of the Australian Government to the terms of trade collapse had been `impressive'. I agree with him.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. What is the Government's reaction to the declaration by Colonel Rabuka that Fiji is now a republic?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade said this morning, we continue to recognise the Governor-General of Fiji as the only source of legitimate constitutional authority in Fiji. We do not recognise the actions of Colonel Rabuka. I can inform the House and the honourable member that this morning I rang the Governor-General of Fiji, Sir Penaia Ganilau, and informed him directly of our support. I found, as I had during a similar call that I made to the Governor-General last Friday, that the Governor-General continues firmly and unequivocally to assert his authority and to reject the pretensions of Colonel Rabuka.

ANSWER.PARA: I repeat that it is not for us to seek to tell the people of Fiji how they should get out of this political crisis, or to lay down any detailed blueprint for a political outcome. It is critical that a solution be found in Fiji which restores the parliamentary system, which protects the basic human rights of all the people of Fiji and which permits a reversal of the economic decline which unquestionably threatens economic tragedy for that country and its people. Today's devaluation underlines the predicament which Colonel Rabuka's actions have created. We sincerely hope, and I am sure that I speak for the whole House, that the Governor-General is able to find such a solution. I have arranged to have a further discussion with the Governor-General before I leave on Friday for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting so that I will be in a position to have at the latest point before my departure the clearest indication I can of the Governor-General's position. I repeat the great admiration that we have for the steadfast, dedicated, committed and courageous way in which the Governor-General of Fiji has discharged his responsibilities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to his answer yesterday regarding exchange rate policy when he used the following words:

QUESTION.PARA: When you float the dollar it bloody floats.

I ask the Prime Minister whether he can reconcile this description of our exchange rate policy with, first, the heavy intervention in foreign exchange markets by the Reserve Bank of Australia, the Bank having bought over $5 billion worth of United States dollars in just the last six months to prevent our exchange rate from appreciating quite significantly, and, secondly, with this statement by the Reserve Bank in its annual report:
. . . its heavy intervention in the foreign exchange markets and its consequent impact on the free operation of those markets was much greater than the Bank would think appropriate.
Did the Prime Minister or his Treasurer, or indeed Senator Button or Senator Walsh, authorise or request that intervention by the Reserve Bank?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not regard those statements as inconsistent with the position I put. It ill behoves the Leader of the Opposition to talk about Australia's exchange rate because one of the fundamental reasons why the Australian economy became such a mess in the period 1975 to 1983 was the consistent refusal of the then conservative Government, with the Leader of the Opposition in the prime position of responsibility as Treasurer, to adopt a responsible attitude towards exchange rate management. He blindly kept the Australian dollar overvalued. That was a significant part of the reason why Australian industry was not able to be as competitive in this world as it should have been. This is not just a judgment made by me having succeeded that Government; it is the universal judgment of all analysts of the Australian economy in that period. The Leader of the Opposition simply did not have the courage or the wit to conduct a sensible exchange rate policy.

ANSWER.PARA: As for the latter part of the honourable member's question, I would point out that the Treasurer has the prime responsibility for the conduct of Government economic affairs in regard to monetary policy and exchange rate policy. Obviously he has frequent discussions with the Governor of the Reserve Bank. I am not privy and do not seek to be privy to the details of those conversations, although the Treasurer keeps in broad contact with me. Senator Walsh and Senator Button have had no part, obviously, in any directions to the Reserve Bank.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Community Services and Health. Given recent criticisms of the Government's allocation of $25m to assist with public hospital waiting lists, will the Minister advise the House of progress in the implementation of this program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course there have been the usual exaggerated claims about the nature of waiting lists in the public hospital system. I notice that the honourable member for O'Connor has got to 150,000, which is just as much an exaggeration as his previous 100,000. I am very glad about the way in which the States have responded to the offer by the Commonwealth of matching $25m for a waiting list program. Indeed, the States themselves have made it quite clear that Medicare is not the problem with or cause of the hospital waiting lists. They have identified the specific reasons in the work that they have done. For instance, the States have identified nursing shortages, an undersupply of some specialities, particularly orthopaedic and ophthalmic surgery. It has also been noted that advances in technology have made a whole range of operations possible now which can be much more routinely performed than they were 10 years ago. Of course there is also a growing awareness of these changes and therefore a greater demand.

ANSWER.PARA: Many of the States had already targeted these problems with programs of their own. While the Commonwealth does not wish to interfere with those targeted programs by the States, we wish to back them up and give them support. That was the reason for the $25m announcement during the course of the election campaign. That money has now been distributed on the following basis: New South Wales, $9.6m; Victoria, $7.4m; Queensland, $2.8m; Western Australia, $1.1m; South Australia, $2.3m; and Tasmania, $350,000. The Northern Territory has indicated that it will not have a program this year but may well develop one next year.

It may be of interest for honourable members to know the kinds of specific targeted programs that are receiving this money. In Victoria there is a five-part program which covers specially dedicated facilities to deal with specific surgery items, overseas nurse recruitment to deal with the shortage of nurses, the use of private hospitals for recovery and rehabilitation, more day surgery provision and a management review of the handling of the waiting list problem. In South Australia the money is being used to open new day surgery facilities, to provide extra theatre sessions for orthopaedics, ear, nose and throat, and urology. In New South Wales there has been an expansion of cardiac and orthopaedic services, improved eye surgery, development of day surgery facilities and paediatric enhancement programs. All of these are targeted programs to deal not with the sort of ideological noise but with specific problems that hospitals have in this area. We are confident that this co-operation between the States and the Commonwealth will mark an important advance in dealing with a difficult problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to reports in the Australian newspaper on Monday that the Treasurer has predicted that investment in plant and equipment might increase between 7 and 10 per cent in 1987-88 compared with the 3 per cent forecast in the Budget. As the estimates released today for private capital expenditure indicate a continued poor outlook for investment, I ask the Prime Minister: What additional information has become available during the three weeks since the Budget which would lead to such a significant revision to the forecasts for investment as indicated by the Treasurer? In addition, what is the likely impact of the upwards revision to the forecast for investment on the demand for imports and hence on the balance of payments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to the first part of the honourable gentleman's question, I have not had any discussion with the Treasurer as to what detailed considerations were in his mind. One of the factors would be the very bullish forecast that was made by the Metal Trades Industry Association, of which I imagine the honourable gentleman is aware. Its most recent survey found that metal and engineering firms are planning to increase investment in plant and equipment by 22.5 per cent in 1987-88. In real terms that is about a 15 per cent real increase. That is the result of the survey by the Metal Trades Industry Association. The honourable gentleman is obviously well aware of that Association and of the dimension of its coverage and the integrity of the organisation. I therefore believe that when the Treasurer was talking about significant increases in investment in plant and equipment that survey by the Metal Trades Industry Association would have played quite a significant part in his assessment.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the second part of the question, we acknowledge of course, to the extent that a large part of that investment in plant and equipment involves the purchase of capital equipment from overseas, that that in an initial sense will have some adverse impact on the external account. Again, I think the honourable gentleman would agree that to the extent that that equipment is being brought in place to make Australian industry more competitive, to enable us to compete better not only externally but also against imports, and if we take the medium to longer term point of view, that is to be regarded as a plus.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories inform the House of progress being made in finding alternative industries to phosphate mining on Christmas Island?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I think most honour- able members would be aware that the economy of Christmas Island is dependent upon the phosphate mine there which has been in decline for a number of years and which is about to be wound down. Obviously, there was a degree of urgency about finding alternative industries and employment for the people who live there. I am pleased to inform the House that at the end of Question Time I will be tabling, for the information of honourable members, the heads of agreement between the Commonwealth and the developer of the Christmas Island resort and casino, which represents a major breakthrough and is the culmination of 12 months negotiation instigated by my predecessor, the honourable member for Corio. I am sure that he will be delighted that at last this has come to fruition.

ANSWER.PARA: The condition of the agreement is that the developer, Mr Frank Woodmore of Perth, will spend $35m on building a 200-room resort hotel with a casino. He will also be establishing his own engineering works and will be paying for the upgrading of the island's airport to the standard required to service this new development. A condition of the development was that a casino operator be found who would be suit- able to the Commonwealth and would pass the most rigorous examination of his credentials by the Australian Federal Police. I am pleased to report that Federal Hotels Ltd, the operator of the very successful Hobart and Launceston casinos for a long time-I notice a smile on the face of the honourable member for Franklin-and highly regarded as the operator of the two casinos in the Northern Territory before the debauchery of the operation by the then Northern Territory Government, has been accepted as the operator of the casino on Christmas Island. The examination by the Australian Federal Police has found Mr Haddad's operation to be one above question and reproach. I can assure the House that this development will go ahead on Christmas Island and will provide alternative employment for those people who are resident there-the Chinese and the Malays. This is a very positive step forward which, as I said, was started by my predecessor and will lead to some sort of prosperity for those people who live on Christmas Island.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Prime Minister. On the premise that reasoned address should result in mutual benefit, I ask the Prime Minister whether he will exercise his influence to bring about an extension of time allowable for presentation of submissions on World Heritage listing of Queensland rainforests.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Wide Bay for his question. I cannot give an undertaking about such an extension of time. I believe that for a very considerable period of time the public must have been aware of the intentions of the Government in this matter. I would remind the honourable member that in the election campaign of June and July not only I but also other spokespersons for the Government made it quite clear that our intention was to seek World Heritage listing. So I find it difficult to believe that people would not have had a very considerable period of time in which, firstly, to be aware of the Government's intentions and, secondly, following from that, to prepare their submissions if they so wished.

ANSWER.PARA: I have confidence in the capacity of the Minister for the Environment and the Arts, Senator Richardson, to handle this matter. I must say that I believe that the whole handling of this issue would have been a much more sensible, rational and sane business within the Australian community if that fast-disappearing figure on the Australian political scene, the Premier of Queensland, had not sought deliberately to provoke public passion and indeed, I would say, physical activity on this matter. That did nothing to assist the proper consideration of this matter. Fortunately one of the benefits that will occur in the Australian community from what appears to be his imminent disappearance from the Australian political scene is that we will be able to have a much more sensible debate on this issue. I do want to be positive in regard to my friend the honourable member for Wide Bay. I do encourage people to prepare their submissions. As I say, I would hope that they have had time to do it, but they should do it as quickly as possible because we want everyone who has an interest in this matter to have their interests represented.

I repeat to the honourable member that we as a government have made it clear that it is our belief that the tourist potential in the area is such that there is no reason to believe that, taking the medium to longer term point of view, there should not be a net addition to employment opportunities in the region. This is a belief which is shared by some members of the National Party of Australia who identified with our judgment in that area when I visited the Daintree during the election campaign. Finally, I say to the honourable member that we have indicated that we are prepared to look sympathetically at the cases of those for whom some compensation would be appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Employment, Education and Training aware of widespread concern in the private sector, which views the shortage of skilled labour as the main problem facing Australian manufacturing today? What is the Government's response?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Obviously it is true that one of the problems confronting particularly the newer and expanding industries in Australia is the lack of sufficient skilled people to be employed within those industries. I might say that one of the important reasons for this is the deliberately induced recession of 1982-83 brought about by our opponents when they quite deliberately decided to overvalue the currency. Of course, that led to a massive downturn in manufacturing. It led to an historically low level of intakes of apprentices, the harvest of which we are now beginning to reap in that we now see a smaller number of apprentices coming out of their training than is necessary to satisfy the demand.

ANSWER.PARA: Happily, we have seen since that time a 50 per cent increase in the number of people taking apprenticeships, and therefore the future for skilled people joining the work force now and in the future is much brighter. As well as that, there has been a 17 per cent increase between 1982 and 1986 in the enrolments of students in engineering and science courses, which again is a very important requirement if we are to find the kinds of people necessary to fill the jobs which are opening up now and which will open up in the future in this economy. I make the point that in the Budget context the Government tabled a very important policy statement which brought together our various approaches to skills training, whether it be in the programs administered by my Department or in relation to our funding arrangements for technical and further education. All of those measures are designed to achieve a greater enrolment of young people, particularly in skilled training, and also to encourage a greater commitment on the part of industry-that is, private employers-to investing in skills.

It is true that in this country there has been a very shallow commitment on the part of industry generally to investment in skills training. We hope that through our programs we will see some turnaround as far as industry is concerned. In order to assist that, a new program which was first announced by my predecessor, the Minister for Industrial Relations, is now being brought into effect. This new skills training program will provide some $22.6m. It is designed to provide funding, along with industry funding, to encourage new and innovative training schemes in order to encourage a greater number of skilled tradespeople in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to the demands for 40 per cent of Australia's land mass, 7 per cent of our gross national product and other concessions contained in the draft Aboriginal treaty as reported in Tuesday's Australian. Does the Prime Minister concede that he has fuelled such impractical demands and unrealistic expectations in sections of the Aboriginal community by his reckless, off the cuff floating of a proposal for a compact with the Aborigines? What concessions does the Prime Minister consider such a compact should contain?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Briefly, the answer to the first part of the honourable gentleman's question is no. I am disappointed that he should approach this matter in this way. The observation contained in the honourable gentleman's question that I made an off the cuff comment is, of course, totally fallacious. I had had discussions about this matter with a number of people, including the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, and I thought it appropriate on my visit to the Northern Territory at the first opportunity to make such a statement. So I can assure the honourable gentleman that if I were to be looking for an excuse-which I am not-I would not be pleading that it was an off the cuff comment; it was a considered statement. It is a tragedy that this pathetic Opposition should seek--
—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. I ask the Prime Minister to withdraw. There is no evidence of that. We have been doing him like a dinner this time back.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—That this pathetic Opposition should--
—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—Is it the same point of order?
—Madam Speaker, the point of order is directed to you. I do not believe that that is parliamentary language and I ask you to have it withdrawn.
—The honourable member for O'Connor will be aware that there is a certain give and take within this House on political matters. I call the Prime Minister.

—The issues involved in the honourable gentleman's question are of fundamental importance, and I believe they should be considered in a much more constructive way than that embodied in his question. I think it is important. I would have hoped that the overwhelming majority of the members of this Parliament would share my view that it is a matter of overwhelming importance that, as we approach our 200 years of European settlement in this country, we do so in the recognition that that 200 years comes after 40,000 years of a proud tradition and culture of the Aboriginal people, and that we will not as a nation properly celebrate the 200 years of European settlement if we do not have that fact in our minds.

ANSWER.PARA: As Prime Minister of this country, I am concerned to try to stimulate, if I can, a consideration by the Aboriginal people and the non-Aboriginal people in this country of what the nature of that relationship between the 200 years of European settlement and 40,000 years of Aboriginal culture and tradition should be. It is obvious, I suggest, that in such a consideration the representatives of the Aboriginal people themselves will make demands and suggestions that to us may seem outrageous. We should not be surprised by that fact, but what we should do, if we have a proper sense of responsibility to the people of Australia today and in the future, is to encourage discussions between representatives of the Aborigines and the Government and other organisations so that, if it is possible, we can go into 1988 with a sense of shared commitment on the part of the non-Aboriginal people and a recognition that in those 200 years many injustices have been done to the Aboriginal people.

That is not something which is the monopoly of one side of politics. It has been a guilt-if you like, a responsibility-shared by all of us in politics and by all generations in those 200 years. We do ourselves little justice and have little cause for pride if we try to sweep those facts under the carpet. We will be a prouder nation in 1988 if we can recognise those facts. If in the process, as I say, some demands or claims are made which appear somewhat outrageous, so be it. I hope that under the strong leadership of my Minister for Aboriginal Affairs there will be serious discussions. I am encouraged by the indications that have already been forthcoming from sections of the Aboriginal people that they do want to engage in such discussions. I am also encouraged by a public opinion survey reported in the Sydney Morning Herald yesterday which showed that 58 per cent of those surveyed supported the compact proposal in principle. That is not something which should be subject to this cheap gibberish and interjections from the other side.

If Opposition members are really serious about their responsibilities as representatives of the Australian people in this Parliament, they should understand the nature of the problem, the depth of feeling of the Aboriginal people and their sense of accumulated injustice.
