We will be the better people and the stronger nation in 1988 if we accept and recognise those facts and constructively together try to get a sense of mutual understanding and obligation between the Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Consumer Affairs. In view of the rash of product recalls last week which affected all Australian car manufacturers, a major food manufacturer and a home goods manufacturer just outside my electorate, will the Minister advise the House on the success or otherwise of these recalls and the implications for Australian consumers and manufacturers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was a rash of recalls last week in certain areas of manufacture. At this stage I am able to advise honourable members that the recalls are progressing quite satisfactorily. The voluntary recalls provision was brought into effect in July 1986 under the Trade Practices Act and the system is working quite well. The Government, nonetheless, appreciates that recalls are quite costly and do upset production schedules, just as industry and manufacturing recognise that it is important to protect their reputations and responsibility to consumers in this way. I take this opportunity to congratulate industry and manufacturing in Australia on their compliance with the voluntary recall provision and point out that consumer affairs is more than simply consumer protection.

ANSWER.PARA: As Minister for Consumer Affairs I will certainly take every opportunity to support and encourage industry where actions benefit the consumer, industry and the economy. The whole question of recalls points out again the issue of quality in Australian manufacturing. There is a need for greater efforts in inbuilt quality in Australian manufacturing, particularly in the areas of design, materials, the process and, indeed, workers' skills. Such efforts to improve quality will improve the reputation of Australian manufacturing for quality, productivity and competitiveness and will bring a mutual advantage, I believe, to business, to the consumer, to government expenditure and, indeed, to the economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs to the now abolished community employment program and remind him that when it was announced on 13 May that CEP was to be abolished the then Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations extolled the virtues of CEP for assisting people to return to the general labour market and claimed specifically that 130,000 long term unemployed and disadvantaged job seekers had been assisted. Is the Minister aware that the since tabled Auditor-General's efficiency audit report on the CEP states, among other trenchant criticisms of the program, that professional advice indicated that the net effect of the program was to gain employment for a mere 9 per cent of the former CEP participants? I ask the Minister whether or not the Government was aware of the Auditor-General's audit findings before the program was axed. If so, why did the Government mislead the nation on the scheme's success?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The decision to abolish CEP was taken after many of the objectives in respect to CEP had in fact been achieved.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I can appreciate the fact that had some of the honourable gentlemen opposite been applicants for CEP they would not have been admitted. Nevertheless, I remind the House that, despite the sort of carping criticism that has come from honourable gentlemen opposite, many of whom were responsible for creating the highest level of unemployment in recent years in Australia, they are not prepared to face the fact that this Government has not merely turned around that situation but is now embarking upon new programs which are designed to train many of our unemployed young people and mature aged unemployed for real jobs and to provide real training to equip them for permanent employment. I should have thought that that was an emphasis in government policy which would be supported by members of the Opposition. It is certainly a general proposition which, by and large, has been accepted throughout the community. It is a proposition which is enjoying the support of business enterprises within the community and in levels of the trade union movement.

ANSWER.PARA: At the time the decision was made, as far as I am aware, no regard was paid to the recommendation contained in the Auditor-General's report. The decision was taken on the basis of the decision of the Government to realign its total strategy and to meet the objective of training unemployed young people in our community for real jobs. I suggest that if honourable members look at the detail of what was achieved by many CEP programs they will see that many of those programs received strong support. Indeed, the change in government emphasis in going to a broader strategy of employment training created some criticism among local councils and other organisations which had benefited from the results of CEP.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order-
—Order! There is no need for the honourable member to bang the desk. I can see you and hear you.
—I didn't touch it.
—Do you have a point of order?
—Yes. I refer to the Auditor-General's report, which states that 13 May, the day after--
—Order! The honourable member does not have a point of order. Please resume your seat.
—It is a good point of order because it shows that the Minister is not telling the truth.
—Would you please resume your seat. I warn you that, if you do not sit down, I will take action.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PALAU: COMPACT OF ASSOCIATION WITH UNITED STATES OF AMERICA

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade inform the House of the Government's attitude towards the Compact of Free Association between the governments of Palau and the United States of America? Is the Minister aware of criticisms which have been made of the compact on the grounds that it allegedly deviates from the nuclear free provisions of the Palau constitution? Is he aware of recent violence in Palau apparently associated with the compact? Can the Minister comment on those matters?
—You cannot ask the Minister to comment, but the first part of the question is in order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —A referendum was held in Palau on 4 August this year. That referendum provided that the constitution could be amended by a simple majority, if that was the wish of a simple majority of the people of Palau, to provide for a compact of self-governing free association with the United States on the part of Palau and additionally that the United States would attend to defence and security matters. I should stress that that referendum was conducted strictly in conformity with the provisions of the constitution of Palau.

ANSWER.PARA: On 21 August a further referendum was conducted in relation to the proposal for a compact of free association with the United States. It was carried by 73 per cent of the voters, that is, nearly three out of four and a clear majority, which is a bit better than what happens in my home State of Queensland, where one in three voters is able to impose his will on the majority of the people. That referendum was conducted under the supervision of a visiting United Nations observer team. The provisions in respect of nuclear matters are now what they were before either of those referendums; there has been no change. I have absolutely no evidence to link the matters of violence with the issues that the honourable member has raised.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories: Is there any truth in the assertion that boundaries drawn for World Heritage listing of Queensland rainforests specifically exclude numerous properties owned by radical conservationists and Government supporters? Will the Minister investigate these assertions and advise the House who was responsible for drawing the boundaries and what the processes of consultation and professional input were?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Provisional boundaries have been drawn that are now the subject of discussion and consultation and, as the Prime Minister alluded to in his answer to the honourable member for Wide Bay, there have been submissions from people who have an interest in the area. I can assure the honourable member for Mallee that I will come back to him with a response that is as responsible as that question was irresponsible.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I can assure him and all members of the Opposition, cynical as they might be, that of course there has been no attempt to provide a set of circumstances that are in line with the question asked.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: WOMEN: DISCRIMINATION IN THE WORK FORCE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Will the Minister advise the House what progress has been achieved in removing discrimination against women in the work force since the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Act was passed by the Parliament last year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the honourable member for Brand, I can say that the Act to which she refers came into effect on 1 October last year. I am pleased to say that there have been encouraging developments in the 12 months since. As the House would be aware, that Act involves a graduated approach, with higher education institutions and companies with more than 1,000 employees being covered in the first instance and with subsequent extension to companies with 500 or more employees by February next year and to companies with 100 or more employees by February 1989. The companies and institutions covered by the Act are required to develop affirmative action programs, that is, to develop a profile of where women are placed in their company structure, and to develop their own objectives and forward estimates on how they might change that profile. They are also required to report annually to the Affirmative Action Agency on the plans that they have developed and what they have done to implement them.

ANSWER.PARA: The first year of operation has understandably involved the Agency in extensive educational activities; that is, advising companies of what their obligations are under the Act, of what benefit it can be to them and what affirmative action entails. I am pleased to say that the attitude of companies in general has been quite co-operative. A significant number of companies had already adopted affirmative action plans prior to the legislation and indeed had co-operated with the Government in a pilot program prior to the legislation being brought in. In the first 12 months of the operation of the Act over 300 companies have contacted the Agency to obtain information and assistance to develop their plans.

It is also true that some companies have been less than enthusiastic about this Act and their obligations under it. This stems in large part from a misconception of what is involved. They need to understand and indeed the wider community needs to understand fully that we are not seeking by this Act to give priority to women. We are seeking to give women equality of treatment with men. Experience has already shown that when companies look more closely at their practices and eliminate discrimination against women they achieve a much more efficient use of their work force; so there are real benefits to them from this process. As companies understand that more, I am sure that there will be more enthusiasm than there has been in some companies which have had to face up to this legislation.

This legislation, along with the equal employment opportunity legislation in the public sector and other actions by the Government to encourage women to enter male dominated occupations, will certainly ensure that in the next few years we will take very substantial steps towards achieving equality of treatment of the sexes in the work force. The result of that will be that we will see a much more even spread of women across industries, a much more even spread of women across occupations, a much higher proportion of women in management and executive positions, where they are abysmally represented, than we presently have and, as a consequence of those changes, a much higher level of female earnings relative to male earnings than currently applies. The action of the Government in this area has been extensive. It is very effective and it will make a great difference to the women in the work force in future years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.
—Yesterday in the Senate my newly acquired relative, Senator Walsh, made the following remarks when answering a question on tax file numbers. In part, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, it would appear that Mr Tuckey seems to think that it is all right for an employer to supply a false name to the Taxation Office, but he is not so keen on an employer supplying a correct name.
A little further on he continued:

. . . but it seems to me that what Mr Tuckey is objecting to is any onus being imposed on employers to notify the Taxation Office of the tax file number of the employee to whom payments are made and on whose behalf an employer is required, under long-standing law, to deduct PAYE tax instalments.

That statement is totally untrue and could not be substantiated on even the broadest interpretation of the remarks I made on the Morning Show. I have expressed concern for the rights of millions of honest taxpayers in Australia as to the confidentiality of their tax file numbers and possible illegal activity by someone who can obtain another person's tax file number, such as the redirection of tax refund cheques.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will not go on to debate the issue. He has made his point.
— I have another point, Madam Speaker, relating to the same matter. Senator Walsh, in concluding his remarks, also said:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Tuckey has a record already of abusing public office for personal gain, and I warn it that it would be most unwise to follow him very far down that road.
Senator Puplick then rose on a point of order and Senator Walsh concluded:
Very well, I will withdraw it and think about tabling the file on the Carnarvon Shire Council.

Not only is the first part of this remark untrue, but also it recycles previous unsubstantiated assertions by other members of the Australian Labor Party. In particular I refer to the implication of Senator Walsh's final remarks which could give credibility to his withdrawn allegation. I now demand that Senator Walsh keep his threat to table his Carnarvon Shire Council file, of which he apparently claims ownership, so that it can be exposed to proper parliamentary scrutiny and compared for accuracy with his other tabling of photocopied cheques which proved to be a fabrication and for which he was censured in the Senate. Upon tabling it I will comment further but Senator Walsh should be aware of the level of scrutiny by others of those allegations.
Finally, Madam Speaker, you would be pleased to know that, considering my new-found family responsibilities, it is my intention also to have a talk to Peter about his affairs with his secretaries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will withdraw that comment.
—I withdraw, but it is a message for Senator Walsh--
—Order! The honourable member will not add to it.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOWARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, Madam Speaker.
—Before the honourable member proceeds, I ask for some courtesy so that he may be heard. He may proceed.
—Here is your lap-dog, Tuckey.
—I do not want any interruption from that area, either.

—During Question Time the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) specifically referred to my conduct of exchange rate policy as Treasurer in the Fraser Government. He made the oft-repeated claim of the Government, particularly of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and other senior Ministers of the Government, that I, as Treasurer in the Fraser Government, had followed a policy of deliberately overvaluing the exchange rate and that the exchange rate had been liberated from that overvaluation when the Hawke Government floated the dollar in 1983. That claim is totally incorrect. My statement that it is totally incorrect is evidenced by the fact that when the Australian dollar was floated in December 1983 the trade weighted index of the dollar stood at 84. Twelve months later-that is, 12 months after the float, which I supported at the time and continue to support, as it is one of the few sensible decisions of the Government-the trade weighted index of the Australian dollar still stood at 84. One would have assumed that if my policies of a managed float had deliberately suppressed the value of the Australian dollar it would have fallen immediately after the float. The reality is that it did not. The claim the Prime Minister made, which repeats one of the canards of the Treasurer over the last 4 1/2 years, is completely discredited.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, Madam Speaker.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—In response to a question I asked of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) today, the Minister accused me of irresponsibility. Could I table in the House a map of the Mossman-Daintree region, which clearly indicates properties under challenge, so that the Minister--
—The honourable member may seek leave to table the document, but this is not strictly a personal explanation. He will need leave to table his document.
—Madam Speaker, I seek leave to table the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the honourable member for Moreton.

—Madam Speaker, I take a point of order. The personal explanation of the honourable member for Mallee was directed to what he believed to be the false assertion of the Minister that his question was irresponsible. He was seeking to put in evidence before the House a map to demonstrate the basis of his claim that the Minister had falsely represented the motive behind his question. I would have thought that the honourable member's request to make a personal explanation was perfectly in order.
—I gave the honourable member the right to make a personal explanation. I understand what the Leader of the Opposition says. However, leave was refused for the tabling of the document.
—I thought you then went on to call somebody else.
—The honourable member wanted to table the document but leave was not given.
—But he had not finished his personal explanation.
—If he has not finished his personal explanation he is perfectly at liberty to continue. He said, `I seek leave to table the document', and that is what I ruled on.

—If I am not able to table the document, Madam Speaker, could I read in my personal explanation the names of the threatened properties so that the Minister can clearly identify the owners of those properties for me?

—Madam Speaker, on a point of order: I submit to you that this is not a personal explanation. In my answer to the honourable member's question I said that I would examine the matter and come back with an answer which would be just as responsible as the question was irresponsible. I stand by that.
—The Minister will come back to the honourable member for Mallee. I presume that they could have a discussion about the matter.
—Madam Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, Madam Speaker.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—During Question Time I tried to raise a point of order, and you may well have properly seated me. I wanted to explain that I had been misrepresented, and that the Auditor-General's report says, `On 13 May--
—Order! The honourable member for Moreton knows that this is not a personal explanation. The honourable member has not been personally misrepresented.
—It is, because my integrity has been put in doubt by the Minis- ter--
—I assure the honourable member for Moreton that he has not been personally misrepresented. The honourable member will resume his seat. Whether the Chair believes him or not is irrelevant.

DEBATE.TITLE: VISIT TO NORTH AND SOUTH AMERICA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUFFY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade Negotiations)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I would like to report to the House on the outcome of my visit to Canada, the United States of America, Brazil, Argentina and Uruguay from 11 to 29 September. From the outset, I would like to report that in the United States and the various Cairns group capitals visited, I received many expressions of appreciation for the positive contribution made by the former Minister for Trade, the present Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), in progressing the movement for world agricultural trade reform and for his most effective leadership as Chairman of the Cairns group. The purpose of my visit to the United States (US) was to register strongly Australia's concerns with several of the proposals contained in two trade Bills currently being considered by the Congress. The two versions of the trade Bill, which were originated in each of the Houses of Congress, are in the process of being negotiated to a single Bill by a joint conference which includes members of both Houses. The Bill agreed to by the conference will then be returned to both Houses for ratification before forwarding to the President for his agreement or veto. Many of the proposals in the present versions of the Bill are protectionist in intent and unfortunately accurately reflect the current mood of many of those in Congress. This is a mood which countries like Australia must fight-the alternative is to allow the undermining of the international trade system to the detriment of all countries.

SPEECH.PARA: While in Washington I met with 10 congressmen-all of whom are participants in a joint conference of the Congress to consider the Bills-and with leading members of the Reagan Administration. I argued strongly for those congressmen to reconsider the most damaging elements of the Bills. I stressed the obvious contradiction between the radical United States proposal for agricultural trade reform which they have tabled in the Uruguay round negotiations in Geneva, and the protectionist tendencies evident in draft US trade legislation. I pointed out that such a contradictory approach to trade policy put at risk the credibility of the United States. I argued that, in the interests of all nations, what the United States should be doing is providing leadership in the process of trade reform, not trade destruction.

Apart from the illogical and unsustainable direction of the draft legislation, I argued that specific measures, which would directly damage Australia, should be reconsidered. I argued most strongly against the provision in the draft legislation which would restrict the entry of Australian lamb into the United States market. I also argued for the removal of a proposal to introduce an effective export subsidy for United States sugar refiners. I repeated the Government's views on the intention to increase the funding for, and duration of, the export enhancement program (EEP). I also expressed concern at other elements of the Bills which would provide increased protections for US industry. I can see no justification for any of these proposals, and I said so. I received a good hearing from all those I met and was able to detail Australia's concern about the Bills and the general direction of US industry policy. I am reasonably optimistic that the final version of the US trade Bill will emerge from the US Congress in an improved form.

I took up these same concerns with the United States Administration. While there was some agreement on the desirable direction of trade policy, I was particularly disappointed with the differences between us on the operation and extension of exports subsidy provisions under the export enhancement program. The Administration's position is that while it opposes export subsidies in principle, the EEP is seen to have value as a retaliatory measure and as a means of putting pressure on the European Community, in particular, to negotiate on agricultural trade reform in the Uruguay round of trade negotiations. I indicated to the Administration that current US policies were placing only marginal pressure on the European Community. I pointed out that, contrary to US claims, their strategy was proving ineffective in adding substantially to the cost of the common agricultural policy, and that rather it had shifted the adjustment burden on to non-subsidising countries like Australia which were being caught in the subsidies cross-fire. I drew out for them the consequences of reduced export income for Australia's purchasing power and what that could mean for future trade between our two countries.

I would like to note that despite the strong protectionist mood which prevails in the Congress, there are some signs of recognition that increased protectionism is not the right path to take. One recent indication of this welcome development has been the failure of the textiles Bill to attract enough support in the United States House of Representatives to avoid a presidential veto. I left the United States encouraged in this view by the efforts of certain congressmen and the Administration to work towards an open and fair trading environment, not only in the United States but also globally. The statement last week in Washington by President Reagan to the International Monetary Fund-World Bank meeting that he would veto any protectionist proposal is also a welcome reaffirmation of the Administration position. I am convinced that the repeated representations by this Government, especially given the reasonableness of our views, is essential if we are to protect both our bilateral trade position in the US as well as our position in international trade. During my discussions in Canada and the US, I indicated clearly my concern that Australia's trading interests should be properly protected in any US-Canada trade agreement. Our officials are closely monitoring more recent negotiations in North America and have again been in contact with Canadian officials this week. It is still too early to judge the final form of the US-Canada agreement. However, the Government will continue to represent strongly our trading interests as the negotiations unfold.

While overseas I held discussions in Canada, Brazil, Argentina and Uruguay, which are members of the Cairns group of fair traders in agriculture. The principal objective of my visit to these countries was to discuss with Ministers our common interests in seeking comprehensive agricultural reform, to gain an appreciation of the priorities of these countries in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade negotiations, and, in particular, the strategy which the Cairns group might follow for the remainder of 1987. Firstly, I would emphasise that it was evident during my visit that the Cairns group has become a recognised and respected voice in the debate on agricultural trade reform. I received strong encouragement, including support from the United States, for the group to continue its efforts in maintaining the momentum for agricultural trade reform in the Uruguay round of trade negotiations.

In all four countries, I was impressed by the strong commitment to the group. I was reassured of the future of the group by the strong expressions of support for the group's objectives and by the assurances I received of active and constructive participation in its future activities. Argentina has offered to host a further meeting of the group at ministerial level in the first quarter of 1988. I welcomed this offer and indicated Australia's participation towards its success. I will be visiting Thailand, Malaysia and Indonesia on my way back from Europe later in the month. These Association of South East Asian Nations countries are also members of the Cairns group. I shall take the opportunity of my visit to obtain their views on the appropriate future strategy of the Cairns group.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The fact that the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy) has returned and reported to the House is to be commended. As I understand, he is leaving for overseas again tomorrow, and it is important that at a time when conflicts between the giants of world commerce are leaving considerable ripples in their wake, there should be an opportunity for some debate and consideration of the implications for Australian export trade. It is particularly important because, as we have been discussing in the House, the real problem in the Budget and in the Australian economy is the continuing chronic balance of payments deficit. The only way that can be overcome is by improving export returns and generating a flow of funds which will enable us to offset, to some degree, the ballooning overseas debt which the economic policies of the Australian Labor Party are unfortunately not only permitting but encouraging.

SPEECH.PARA: Sadly, the Minister is one of the casualties of the Cabinet reshuffle of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). While there were some policy areas in the communications portfolio with which the Opposition was in significant disagreement from time to time, the Minister assiduously performed his duties, but the people of Australia must have a major worry now that the Minister is travelling the world, properly trying to learn his task but learning it at the expense of many Australian exporters whose backs are to the wall, and a country whose economy has its back to the wall. I am concerned that the Department of Trade is to be dismembered into four components. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden), to whom the Minister for Trade Negotiations is junior, has recently been overseas, but has not bothered to involve himself at all in trade negotiations.

It should be understood that there are a number of major implications for Australia in relations with the United States of America, not only in the export enhancement program, to which the Minister has referred, but also in the problems between the United States and Japan, the United States and the European Community, and, as the Minister said, in the flow-on from the signing of the United States-Canada new free trade arrangements. I in no way denigrate the Minister for what he has attempted to do, but it should be understood that, in trying to achieve a recognition of the impact on Australia of the policies being undertaken by other countries, status and stature are important.

My first concern is that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade did not see fit in his new role to make as his first task an attempt to ensure in his overseas visits that trade is given the status and recognition it should enjoy. Mind you, Mr Deputy Speaker, after the failure of the Department of Foreign Affairs in advising the Government on events in Fiji, I am very apprehensive about any role the Department of Foreign Affairs might play in the market-place. The Department of Foreign Affairs was absolutely inept in advising the Prime Minister only a few hours before the whole of the political situation in Fiji changed. The manner in which the Prime Minister made a statement to this place is illustrative of the fact that the Department or the Minister's advisers are totally inadequate. The point I seek to make is that on this side of the House we are particularly concerned about the impact of changing trade conditions. While I commend the Minister for his efforts to learn the job, Australian exporters cannot be the bunnies while he is doing so. Unfortunately, it will be only senior Ministers who will be able to grasp the significance of our concern with administrations abroad.

Within the United States context, for example, one commodity to which the Minister refers is sugar. I am very pessimistic about its present prospect. While I note that the Minister argued for the removal of the proposals to introduce an effective export subsidy, it will require far more than a single Minister's efforts to get that lifted. From what I hear about the substitution of various artificial sweeteners-the way in which corn glucose and other substitutes are taking the place of sugar in various manufacturing processes in the US, for reasons unrelated to trade-there is an enormous problem ahead for Australian sugar exports.

We all know that we have had difficulty with lamb. I am glad that the Minister referred to lamb. While I know that the industry is relatively sanguine about its prospects, I am not. I am concerned that industries such as those should be very high on the agenda in negotiations. As I have said, while I respect the Minister for the role he played on earlier occasions, the fact that he went overseas to learn his job does not really put Australia in a particularly good light. In his opening comments from Canada on a radio program The World Today-and we all recall the remarks of 14 September-he said:

. . . on the question of the joint facilities . . . you cannot assume that because the alliance between the United States and ourselves is as solid as it is, we're going to sit back and allow them to enter into arrangements which are going to be extremely damaging in relation to trade.

It is quite clear from what the Prime Minister said that at some stage those matters could well become an issue. Frankly, I blame the Prime Minister; I do not blame the Minister. The Prime Minister has been shilly-shallying and shuffling around over the whole deal. It took the edi- torials in Australia to bring him back to his senses, editorials such as that in the Melbourne Age of 17 September which quite properly identified the fact that security and trade are separate. Honourable members will recall that in that editorial the remark was made that, `they are quite separate issues, and to mix them in anger could be not only futile but counter-productive'. Being prickly in other aspects of the defence alliance may not prove effective either, as New Zealand's idiosyncratic behaviour has shown.

As a result of those remarks in the media, the Prime Minister suddenly decided that the Minister for Trade Negotiations had made a blue and he had to retreat from it. How ridiculous it is to have a junior Minister overseas at a very critical time for Australia, putting the joint defence facilities on the plate and being in a position where the Prime Minister had to deny the comment only a few hours after he made it. I know that the Minister, in all sincerity, had not met that consequence, but the point is that the Prime Minister permitted it to happen and Australia suffers. As I have said, it is no time to send abroad a Minister learning his job to do a man's job. It is a serious situation. Australia is in a very critical state because of the difficulties between Japan and the United States and between the European Economic Community and the United States. We have to get out there with the most senior Ministers available. We now have four Ministers responsible for trade. It is the most junior of them who has been given this very important job. No doubt, once he knows the job he will be able to undertake these responsibilities. But the point is that the anti-American blunder that he made very early in his visit abroad did no good for Australia. I recommend that the Minister on his next visit, whether it be to Europe or to the South East Asian countries, be careful about what he says and not listen to the Prime Minister before he says it.

The second thing I would say to the Minister is that as he travels he will have a good deal of time. Apart from perhaps trying to read the Melbourne Cup race book there are a few other documents that would be worth considering. He needs to understand that there are very important problems caused by government which are also adversely affecting Australian trade opportunities.

We all know that, with the coal industry facing declining prices abroad, government charges are a major adverse factor for profitability. During the Minister's absence we have had the imminent threat of the closure of all the Hunter Valley coal mines. We know that there is a very serious position right throughout New South Wales with the total failure of the New South Wales Government to realise that its charges on the coal industry are one of the contributors. In addition, of course, there are this Government's charges. I pointed out in a speech here the other day, during the Minister's absence, that Mount Isa Mines Ltd, for example, pays somewhere between $3m and $4m by way of fringe benefits tax. There are all sorts of charges for which governments are responsible. The Minister has not only to talk to other countries but also to try to reduce costs for Australian exporting industries and, significantly, to try to make sure that when he talks to other countries he is not put in a position of their being able to say to him, `Yes, but it is your Government's charges that put you in a disadvantageous situation'.

I am told that the New South Wales Government received $754m in revenue from the State's coal industry. If, for example, there were a reduction in rail freight charges, an improvement in efficiency within general handling and a privatising of coal loading there could be a reduction of about $3 a tonne in costs generally. Therefore, I suggest that next time the Minister might take with him a very excellent book which was published during his absence called The Game Plan: Successful Strategies for Australian Trade.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would you know about this? Tell us about--

—I suggest that the honour- able member keep very quiet in this place in view of the mess he has made of his administration over the last little while. The total failure to examine the normal processes of tendering, his inability to comprehend facts that have been put forward to him and his colleague, the failure to report accurately to this House and the conflict in answers given day by day in this House make him one of those who will be very early casualties of this Hawke Ministry. We look forward to his demise.

SPEECH.PARA: The book Successful Strategies for Australian Trade has been written by Andy Stoekel, formerly the Director of the Centre for International Economics, and Director of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, and Sandy Cuthbertson, formerly a first assistant commissioner with the Industries Assistance Commission. The book points out that one of the problems lies in the extent to which, in policies designed to improve trade, 60 per cent of effort must be aimed at the domestic market. I commend the book to the Minister because there are some very good stratagems in it and many of them go directly to the sort of input that he must address if his voice is going to be effective abroad. There is a real problem, as I see it, in our voice being equal. It is all very well to say that what is happening in America and in the European Economic Community programs, and what is happening in Europe and under the common agricultural policy, are the reasons our trade is in difficulty. The reality is that it is this Government's program in Australia that is causing most of the difficulties.

There is a real problem, as we see it, in world trade. I commend the fact that there is now a Minister who will be spending so much of his time in negotiations abroad, but I say to his colleagues, those other more senior Ministers, that whether it is a valid assessment or not, status in government is critically important in ensuring that our voice is heard, and unless those who have more senior responsibility in trade, and the Prime Minister, are prepared to assert our concerns, Australia's export opportunities will suffer. There is no doubt that we need to have an effective voice abroad. We are concerned on this side of the House about the problems not only in the United States but also in the South East Asian region, in South America, in Europe and in Japan. I believe a great deal more needs to be done.

The way by which the problems of world trade can be solved is by lifting trade barriers, as in the Cairns group concept. It is that idea of removing barriers rather than applying them that we must get through to other countries. I know that that is the objective of the Minister's visit. But I say to him that in his forthcoming visit to South East Asia he should understand that one of the problems during the administration of the present Government has been that too little attention has been given to trade opportunities in our closer markets. Ministers such as the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade have been quite keen to go to New York. Of course, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) loves it in Washington and enjoys going to Europe. He likes to get away from the hurly-burly of the Australian domestic scene. Ordinary Australians are not for him.

TALK.START.PARA: —He likes Paris.

—He likes Paris, of course. But there are enormous opportunities for Australian trade in South East Asia. I am delighted that the Minister is going to Thailand, Malaysia and Indonesia. I am only sorry that his visit to those countries seems to be almost an adjunct to his visit to other parts of the world because South East Asia is far more important to us than almost anywhere else. A lot of countries close to Australia have for far too long been neglected in terms of trade opportunities and, as I said a moment ago, in security matters. Unless we treat our regional responsibilities more responsibly than we are at the moment, I fear that, no matter how effective the Minister may be with his rhetoric in those more glamorous capitals of the world, our trade opportunities will not be as good as they should be.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-1986 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.

Your petitioners therefore request the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate select committee to outlaw destructive experiments of human embryos.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

We, the undersigned, being appalled that the Government has set no penalty for the possession of child pornography, and has set no penalty for importing unclassified child pornography, do ask that Parliament urgently legislate to:
make the importation of child pornography, and the possession of child pornography, and all tapes and goods banned by Customs, to be a Criminal Offence, with Deterrent penalties, and
close the Customs barriers to pornography in the A.C.T., in respect of X rated videos, (and ER) and END the shameful Canberra trade, and the Mafia Connections.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The Commonwealth has reneged on an established commitment as incorporated in Commonwealth legislation and benefit promise pensions are not being paid in full. In particular we resent the long-term effect of the discounting. The pension loss is compounded throughout the life of a pensioner and surviving dependants-into the 21st century for many. We consider this Government-induced penalty to be out of all proportion to the short-term `extraordinary circumstances of the economy' given as the reason for the discounting.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:

1. limit the pension discounting effect of the Superannuation and Other Benefits Legislation Amendment Act 1986 to the period 10 October 1986 to 1 July 1987 so that pensions are restored to the 9 October 1986 level as a base for the 1987 pension adjustment; and
2. consult with organisations representing pensioners before changing the terms and conditions of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Schemes.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows:

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the World in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:
That we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Labor Government's Identity Card.

We consider that this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combating the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security.
We therefore ask the House to take action to prevent the implementation of this legislation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Closure of Macksville Army Reserve
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The decision by the Department of Defence to close down the Macksville Sub-Section of 41 Battalion, Australian Army Reserve, is of grave concern to the unit members and citizens of the surrounding districts. The decision to direct unit members to Coffs Harbour, some 60 km distant, would impose sufficient hardship to prevent many continuing in the reserve and be a major deterrent to potential members.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled urge the Parliament to intervene to stop the proposed closure and sale of land at Wallace Street, Macksville, and initiate action to have a permanent Depot built on the Army's Macksville land.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telephone Service in Harkaway, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia show us that whereas:
The residents of Harkaway request the immediate replacement of the public telephone service removed on the 12th day of May 1987 by Telecom Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the proposed introduction of compulsory identification (ID) cards should be reconsidered and rejected because the system:
(a) is not a cost-effective method of reducing tax evasion and social security fraud and, to the contrary, in the form proposed will facilitate such evasion and fraud;
(b) will constitute an unwarranted infringement of individual privacy by the aggregation of a wide variety of personal information of a private nature;
(c) will cause a further large and costly growth in the bureaucracy and burden on the taxpayer; and
(d) cannot be guaranteed against misuse for purposes other than for which their introduction is stated to be intended and in fact provide the opportunity for blackmail and other forms of misuse.
And your petitioners humbly pray that the problems which identification cards are intended to reduce should be attacked by other, more effective and less obnoxious methods.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Capital Gains Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:

Labor's Capital Gains Tax is standing in the way of economic development on the Far North Coast, a region with great potential for further growth and renowned for the enterprise and initiative of its local community.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to repeal its anti-business anti-farming and anti-individual Capital Gains Tax.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Prescription Drugs for Pensioners
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
1. We the undersigned are totally opposed to the introduction of a $2.00 fee on prescription drugs for pensioners;
2. The impact of such a fee will be particularly felt by the chronically ill elderly who will be faced with a $2.00 burden with the purchase of each Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme drug;

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to ensure that prescription drugs continue to be provided to the pensioner population without the $2.00 fee on each prescription.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Industrial Relations Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government's Industrial Relations Bill will increase industrial disputation, bankrupt companies, and give the union movement total and absolute power over the Australian community.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to reject Labor's Industrial Relations Bill to save Australia from the actions of militant unions and give our economy a chance of recovering.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Murray electorate respectfully showeth that:
The August 1st changes to Medicare Benefit rebates are unfair to patients, such as those with chronic disabilities requiring consultant physician or after hours consultations.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to amend the Health Insurance Act and the National Health Act to restore the original rebates.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Services, Beaudesert District, Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Beaudesert and district respectfully showeth:
That we are strongly opposed to the proposal for metering of local telephone calls by Telecom since-
(i) most phone calls by residents in country towns are already STD and it would be unfair to have to pay further charges for local calls;
(ii) higher phone bills would add more pressure to the family budget, and some would not be able to pay them;
(iii) elderly, sick and lonely people rely on the telephone as their communication with the outside world.
We therefore request the House to give this matter a lot more thought before acting on the proposal.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The necessity for the Government immediately to implement the next stage of deregulation of the Australian airline industry by giving effect to its commitment to privatise Australian Airlines.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Senate today the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Evans, moved a motion to terminate what is known as the two-airline agreement and tabled a document entitled Domestic Aviation: A New Direction for the 1990s. A number of things about the document should be noted. The first is that it seeks to implement parts of the coalition's policy on aviation. The second is the question of the timing of release of the document. The third is that the document is notable not so much for the things it says but for the things it does not say. It is particularly notable for what it does not say about what is clearly now the Government's commitment to privatise Australian Airlines. It is for this reason that we bring before the House and the Australian people this matter of public importance today.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has been pushing for deregulation of the domestic airline industry for some years now and we have done so against Government objections. I will give an example of those objections. This is what the then Minister for Aviation said in 1984--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was this?
—He is now the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). We will come back to him. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . if the Opposition goes the whole way with its enthusiasm . . . deregulation would be thrown in for good measure.
This is what he said:
If the Opposition follows this scenario there is every chance that Australia's aviation system would slide into chaos.

Despite all these objections, in an extraordinary act of hypocrisy the Government has adopted yet another plank from the Opposition's policies. Targeting of restrictive work practices, the reintroduction of negative gearing and tax reductions-all of those are now followed by deregulation of the domestic airline industry.

What remains intriguing about this document is its timing. The first day on which notice could have been given to terminate the two-airline agreement was 26 January 1987. Yet the Government has brought itself to terminate the agreement nine months later-in itself an interesting period, presumably, as the Government has now found itself in a position in which it can bring this baby into the world. If the Government was committed to deregulating the airline industry, why did it not do it nine months ago? It matters a great deal that it did not do it nine months ago. Nine months ago, in addition to Australian Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia, East-West Airlines Ltd operated many services around Australia and gave consumers more choice at lower cost, much as would be the case in a deregulated environment. In that nine-month period, however, East-West has been purchased by Ansett and as a result, by waiting, the Government has created a situation in which there is less competition, not more. By waiting, the Government has created a situation which is quite the opposite of the situation it had hoped to create. By waiting, the Government has made it more difficult for there to be an open, competitive domestic airlines system operating for the benefit of consumers.

We can, however, unlock the secret of why the Government waited until now to release this statement by noting how the Government's views on privatisation have changed over the last few months. Let me give some examples of what Ministers have been saying about privatisation. Listen to what the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said on 23 May 1985:
No matter where one looks whether it be at T.A.A.-
now Australian Airlines-
or the other authorities there is no case for the Opposition's argument in economics except simply to indulge ideologically in a Thatcherite vandalistic splurge to try and destroy these authorities.
This is what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said in the same year:
Privatisation is a one-off fire sale. A sale of the century of your assets-they would transform them into the hands of a privileged few to the cost of every one of us.
This is what the then Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation said on 19 September 1985:
Privatisation is a cop out from proper government responsibility. It is the ultimate con job trying to sell people what they already own.
As recently as 8 March this year in Bathurst the Prime Minister, when asked what he intended to do about Australian Airlines and whether he would sell it, stated:
The Government has no intention in that regard.

What has been happening in recent days is something quite different, for the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have been on the road to Damascus. This is what the Prime Minister said on 26 August 1987:

Freed of these public sector borrowing restraints these public enterprises may become more efficient and more viable-an outcome which could only benefit consumers, taxpayers and the employees of the enterprise itself.
A few days earlier, he stated:
Certain government holdings that could have, and no doubt did, make good sense in earlier times are not necessarily what is appropriate for current circumstances.
On 27 April this year, the Treasurer said:
Some public assets may be used more efficiently outside the public sector.

So there we have it. Need I say that we see yet another example of the Government adopting the coalition's policy? The Prime Minister and the Treasurer have been converted to the privatisation of certain public assets. That explains the delay; that explains why the Government has waited nine months longer than it should have to bring out this document; and that explains why we are still hearing conflicting comments on privatisation from members of the Government.

In a sordid little trick the Government is using this document on domestic aviation to sort out its own internal critics. The Government is using it as a means of resolving yet another faction fight. The Government is toying with public assets in order to have the cash to balance the Budget without adopting the urgently needed policy of curtailing the growth of government expenditure. This sordid little trick, this act of hypocrisy, this cynical exercise in the manipulation of opinion inside the Australian Labor Party is what the delay is all about. To confirm that the Government still has a job ahead of it in persuading its internal critics, let me give just one quote from the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton). This is what he said just six weeks ago:
I am appalled at the proposal to sell off to private interests the public assets of Qantas, Australian Airlines, the Commonwealth Bank and Telecom.

The Government has the job ahead of it, but it is quite clear that it is now committed to privatising Australian Airlines; and in this matter of public importance we are urging the Government to make that commitment openly and honestly and to give effect to it immediately. Under the heading `Role of Australian Airlines' in the document tabled today there is a commitment to `a strong, viable, efficient Australian Airlines' and then it says:
This means that it is essential that the constraints on the airlines management flexibility and effectiveness are minimised and that it has an adequate capital base.

The first thing the Government proposes to do is to incorporate Australian Airlines as a public company to improve its management's flexibility and effectiveness. There is a sense of deja vu about all this. In 1981 the coalition converted Australian Airlines-or TAA, as it was then known-to a public company. The present Government repealed that legislation in 1984. The Minister for Aviation at the time, who is now the Minister for Defence, does not know where he is on privatisation. Just look at the defence home loans scheme: it is on, it is off-and it is on again. This is what the then Minister for Aviation said at that time:
It is the Government's view that there is nothing to be gained in setting up TAA as a public company.
He continued:
It is the stated policy of this Government that TAA will remain wholly owned by the Commonwealth.

He said on 9 May 1984 that there was nothing to be gained in setting up TAA as a public company. Now we have the ultimate act of hypocrisy, the complete somersault by the Government on the establishment of Australian Airlines, or TAA, as it was then known, as a public company.

Another aspect of this shilly-shallying that is going on is how it affects the employees of Australian Airlines and their morale. By failing to clarify what Australian Airlines' future will be, by failing to come clean about what the Government wants to do with the company and whether it intends to privatise it and by failing to make the necessary commitment on funds, the Government has sentenced Australian Airlines to a further period of instability and concern amongst employees as to their future. How can any management operate any company under these circumstances? How can any management placate the justifiable concerns of its employees? How can any management continue to run an undercapitalised business?

Australian Airlines has already had to defer its purchase of nine A320 Airbuses. It has done this in an environment of uncertainty about the future of the company and, in doing so, it will apparently have to pay penalties to the manufacturer. What a shambles! The Government is simply not giving Australian Airlines a chance.

That brings me to the advisory group. We always have an advisory group when anything becomes too hard or requires a sorting out of the factions. Guess what the advisory group will advise the Government about. After all the waffle, we get straight down to it. In the domestic aviation document, the Minister says that the advisory group will advise on:
. . . in particular how it-Australian Airlines-will be able to meet its future capital requirements.

What a gigantic smokescreen all this is. If the Government has no intention of privatising Australian Airlines, I will tell honourable members how it will be able to meet its future capital requirements. Almost anybody with any knowledge of business would be able to tell the Government how a public company could get its future capital requirements. If the Government is not going to privatise Australian Airlines, it just gives it some money. This is how the airline can meet its future capital requirements. We do not need any advisory group for that.

The establishment of the advisory group now makes it clear that the Government has not the slightest intention of giving Australian Airlines any money. It is a smokescreen for privatisation. In six months, which is when the advisory group is required to report back, it will say to the Minister, `You have two choices: give it some money or privatise it'. There are no other financing arrangements that can be reached-either give it some money or privatise it. It will also say to the Minister, `By the way, you did not need us to tell you that the simple way to resolve Australian Airlines' financing difficulties, if it is to remain in public hands, is to give it some money; and since you did not tell us that we suggest you privatise it'. The advisory group will also say, `By the way, we have locked everybody in. We have locked the Australian Council of Trade Unions in, because the ACTU Secretary is on the advisory group, and if you do not lock the ACTU in you cannot do anything; we have locked in the Department, because the Secretary to the Department is on the advisory group, and we have locked in the left wing in Victoria because a former Labor Party president in Victoria is on the group. So, Mr Minister, now that we have locked everybody in, go ahead and privatise it'.

It is abundantly clear that this Government has a commitment to privatise Australian Airlines, to take yet another plank of coalition policy and sell Australian Airlines to the Australian public. We are seeing a game being played by the Government in order to manage its internal factional fight. This game is being played at the expense of the Australian airline industry, at the expense of the future of Australian Airlines, at the expense of the employees of Australian Airlines and at the expense of the Australian travelling public. The Government stands condemned for playing this sordid little game.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUNCAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —What a great example the speech by the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) was of shadow boxing and method acting, if ever I have seen such a thing. It is typical of the misrepresentation by the Opposition of which we have seen so much in the recent past. This morning the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, made a major statement on the new direction for domestic aviation and its future in this nation. Clearly, the Opposition appears unable to read or hear what was so clearly spelt out in Senator Evans's statement. It in no way committed the Government to privatising Australian Airlines, and we have seen the Opposition's old trick of setting up a shadow. The Opposition, in this matter of public importance, talks of giving effect to the Government's commitment to privatise Australian Airlines. The Government has no such commitment at the moment, and no Opposition member pointed to any statement by a responsible member or Minister saying that this Government has a commitment to privatise Australian Airlines. On the very day of the announcement we have seen the Opposition launch this type of humbug and wishful thinking.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Deakin clearly is attempting to distort rational debate in the community about the future of domestic aviation. The Opposition had three decades in which to do something about the future of the Australian airline industry. In 30 years it did nothing to address the question. If there was justification for the two airlines agreement, the so-called duopoly, it ended in the late 1960s when the airline industry became a mature industry. But from that period on those opposite were in government for most of the time and they did nothing to address that issue. From that point of view, the Opposition has had ample opportunity to develop policies which would have provided benefits to the industry and to air travellers. It has a pretty shabby record as a basis for coming to this place today and saying the sorts of things that the shadow Minister had to say. It is typical of the sort of performance we have seen from the Opposition since the Hawke Labor Government came to power.

This Government has taken its time, it has carefully analysed the situation, and as a result Senator Evans went into the Senate today and put a carefully reasoned and well-argued case for deregulation. Apparently the Opposition did not disagree with any of that, because it did not come into this Parliament this afternoon wanting to debate Senator Evans's statement. Opposition members came in here seeking to set up a smokescreen-and that was exactly what the shadow Minister attempted to do. Big talk and no action has been the hallmark of the Opposition. It has a total lack of understanding of the issues and concepts involved in the development of appropriate policies to lead this nation into the next century. The Opposition has no vision. All one ever hears from Opposition members is carp, carp, carp.

There are major differences between deregulation and privatisation which Government members recognise clearly. Obviously the Opposition is attempting to mislead the public debate by confusing these issues through trivialisation of the sort we heard this afternoon. That can be the only reason I can see for the Opposition moving this motion today, especially given the clear statement made this morning by Senator Evans. I want to deal with the differences between deregulation and privatisation. I shall put it as simply as possible so that those opposite can at least attempt to grasp it. Deregulation is the process of removing regulations which unnecessarily restrict the operations of the organisation or the industry. That is very clear. Privatisation is the transfer of public assets to the private sector. One does not preclude the other, but equally does not necessarily include the other.

The Hawke Government has taken appropriate action to develop policies for the future of the Australian economy. This morning's statement by Senator Evans continues that process. It sets the appropriate timeframe for future developments in the domestic airline industry. It sets in place the appropriate structures for a proper examination of the issues that need to be addressed to make sure that the right decisions are made within the right timeframe. We have given the industry three years in which to plan for the future. Three years notice is required by the legislation. The Opposition might criticise us for delay, or whatever, in relation to the timeframe that has been set up, but of course the Opposition when in government set up the three-year period of notice that is required under the legislation.

It is pretty cheeky of Opposition members to get up in the House today and criticise the Government over the timeframe of the actions we are taking when they placed in the agreement the three-year period of notice which is required to be given to Australian Airlines and to Ansett Airlines of Australia before the notice period can run and before the agreement can be set aside. This is in my view an entirely appropriate timeframe for the industry and for the Government to develop effective proposals for the future. I believe that the three-year period is entirely appropriate, and it is ridiculous for the Opposition to seek to criticise the Government about that timeframe. If Opposition members are trying to say otherwise, they cannot be taken seriously in regard to their own previous policies, the legislation or the realities which face the industry.

Senator Evans' statement sets out a comprehensive policy in which the future of Australian Airlines is an essential element. Is the Opposition seriously suggesting that we should make decisions about Australian Airlines in isolation from the industry as a whole? The statement outlines three steps which the Government is already taking to enable Australian Airlines to compete effectively in the post-1990 environment. The first thing we are proposing is to allow Australian Airlines to become incorporated. It will have the same corporate structure that Qantas Airways Ltd has had since the 1940s. As well, the Government's policy will remove day to day controls and restrictions on Australian Airlines in all but exceptionally significant expenditure decisions. It will detail terms and conditions of borrowing and leasing arrangements, investment of surplus money, choice of auditor, dividend recommendations and provision of insurance against risk. In all these matters Australian Airlines will be freed up as a result of today's statement. We will examine the scope for removal of broader controls in line with the Government's proposals for all government business enterprises and statutory authorities involving major borrowings, remuneration of board members and senior executives, industrial relations arrangements and superannuation provisions. When those matters have been addressed it will ensure that Australian Airlines will be lean and in good shape to compete in the post-1990 deregulated environment.

The third step is the establishment of an advisory group to examine those questions which remain about how Australian Airlines can optimise its managerial effectiveness in the post-deregulation environment. The advisory group will consist of Mr Ted Harris, who will soon be the Chairman of Australian Airlines and who is now the Managing Director and Chief Executive Officer of Ampol Ltd; Mr Colin Carter, commissioner of Australian Airlines and a partner with the consulting firm of Pappas, Carter, Evans and Koop Pty Ltd; Mr Bill Kelty, Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and member of the Reserve Bank Board and the Economic Planning Advisory Council; Mr Peter Redlich, senior partner in Holding, Redlich and Company, solicitors--

TALK.START.PARA: —That locks in the left wingers in Victoria.

—The honourable member will be very interested to hear that then. The other member of the group will be Dr Peter Wilenski, Secretary to the Department of Transport and Communications. The terms of reference for the group are as follows: to advise the Government against the possibility of either the removal or retention of the broad ranging controls to which I have already referred on the extent of Australian Airlines' capital requirements and options for meeting these requirements; and the means of enhancing the airline's management, flexibility and effectiveness and the efficiency of its operating structures. The advisory group will generate options and hard data across the range of possibilities for the future of Australian Airlines. This will enable informed debate to take place and decisions to be made, unlike the pathetic attempts by honourable members opposite, who would prefer to treat the Australian public like morons or mushrooms.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has ruled out only one option-that of the amalgamation of Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines, for the reasons that Senator Evans outlined in his statement this morning. The proposals that the Government has announced today do not promote or restrict privatisation as a future option. This matter needs debate within the Australian Labor Party and elsewhere, based on hard data which the advisory group will put together in the future. Labor Party policy is quite clear on this matter and any changes to it require debate within the Party forums. The steps announced today provide the opportunity for Australian Airlines to compete effectively with the private sector and to examine alternative means to increase its capitalisation.

The Government's record on this matter is positive, especially when compared with the shabby behaviour of the Opposition when it was in government, which has continued since it was ejected to the Opposition benches. It is quite easy to see that once again the Opposition is attempting to mislead the public so that its own lack of initiatives is forgotten. The Australian people will not be so easily fooled. This Government has taken the initiatives and the hard decisions. The decisions which were announced today will lead to deregulation of the Australian airline industry. That will lead to significant benefits to the Australian travelling public, benefits which were available for years and years. As I said before, the Liberal and National parties in government for 30 years never did one damned thing to bring on proper deregulation of the airline industry in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the necessity for this matter of public importance debate and just repeat its inexorable logic:

SPEECH.PARA: The necessity for the Government immediately to implement the next stage of deregulation of the Australian airline industry by giving effect to its commitment to privatise Australian Airlines.

A second point of equal logic is that the only way to save Australian Airlines as a proud and competitive major airline is to sell it to the Australian public-that is, to privatise it. That is the point that the left wing has to learn. If it really wants to help Australian Airlines it must agree to the airline's sale, otherwise it has no future because of the lack of capital and the lack of commercial expertise. That is something that will be rolled over Government members by the trojan horse of this statement today and of the advisory committee which will recommend that it be sold.

The Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan) indicated in his speech-I will be pleased if he will acknowledge that this is an accurate assessment of what he said-that Australian Airlines will not be sold. Is that correct, Minister? If it is sold will the Minister resign? Does he favour the sale of Australian Airlines or not?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will not ask rhetorical questions.

—I believe that as the Minister is representing the Government in this regard, he has a responsibility to answer those questions. If he does not answer it can only be on the basis that he is so confused about the Labor Government's policy on domestic aviation, that he really does not know the answer. After listening to him speak about Amann Aviation I think it has to be true that he does not know the answer. At least he has learnt not to open his mouth automatically whenever anyone puts something to him.

SPEECH.PARA: The third point I wish to make after the point that the only way to save Australian Airlines as a major airline is to privatise it, to sell it to the Australian public, is that only by the sale of Australian Airlines will there be a genuinely competitive domestic aviation industry. It has been repeated time and time again by potential competitors in a deregulated environment that there is no way they will put their money into expensive capital equipment if one of the major players remains government owned.
