In other words, they are not facing a fair and competitive commercial situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It belongs to the Australian people.

—That is interesting-it belongs to the Australian people. Has the honourable member read this document? This document allows for far greater foreign ownership of Australian Airlines than does the Opposition policy. The honourable member is supposedly a supporter of Australian Airlines being owned by the Australian public. That is absolutely laughable. He does not even know what the statement says. He is not only left but he has been left by the Left. One of the inevitable consequences of pressures on governments around the Western world today is that they are not able to provide adequate capital for their commercial enterprises. There is no more succinct example of this than what has happened to Australian Airlines by its inability to maintain its order for nine 320B Airbuses. That sort of aircraft is essential if Australian Airlines is to remain a frontline competitor. It has now had to defer these Airbuses from next year until the mid-1990s-the never-never. No modern government will provide the necessary capital. This Government is no different from any other government. Therefore, if it really wants to support Australian Airlines it has only one basis of operation-that is, to sell it to the Australian public and not to foreigners as it will be doing with this policy.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has made comments about the policies of coalition governments of earlier times. He should look at the attitude of the Labor Opposition at the time when those issues were debated. Which was the most regulatory and restrictive party at that time? If the Minister looked at those sorts of things he might shut up a little bit and refrain from such comments in the future. Since the 1981 review with Hunt and later Fife as Ministers, the coalition parties have had a clear policy-a very graduated and sensible policy-in the 1982 legislation to transform Trans Australia Airlines (TAA) into a public company with all of the shares initially owned by the Government. And, wonder of wonders, five years later a major statement is made by the Government that it will do the same thing, it having repealed our legislation after being elected to government. That move has considerably damaged the ability of TAA, now Australian Airlines, to adjust its management to meet a deregulated environment. Honourable members opposite have a lot to answer for in relation to Australian Airlines' ability to meet competition and to give any confidence to its employees that they have any future whatsoever. That uncertainty on the part of Australian Airlines' employees will remain at least until the Australian Labor Party national conference next year.

As honourable members opposite know, today's statement is a setup. It is a setup not only because it gives three years notice of termination but also because it is as inevitable as day follows night that Australian Airlines will have to be sold. That is the only future for Australian Airlines. The Government therefore is establishing a trojan horse advisory committee which will make such a recommendation which the Government will be forced to follow. If you people opposite say, `it will not automatically follow', you will be damned. You will be damned because you prevented Australian Airlines from ever having any real future or any real part to play in domestic aviation in this country. Australian Airlines, having come from a regulated environment in which it was automatically given basically 50 per cent of the passengers on the major trunk routes, will be devastated in a more commercial situation. However, this commercial environment will be to the tremendous advantage of the airline travelling public of this country. You will carry a tremendous cross--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The honourable member should be addressing his remarks through the Chair and not to `you' on this side of the House.
—There is no point of order.

—Further, the policy of the coalition parties-advocated first by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) in 1984 and then by me in July 1986; this logical policy of progressive deregulation which honourable members opposite are now copying-would have given Australian Airlines adequate time to adjust. Honourable members opposite would do a damned sight better if they copied our policy completely rather than just copy it partially as they are. If honourable members opposite really read the Minister's document and see some of the shortcomings in it they will realise they still have a lot to learn. The Government is not abolishing the Independent Air Fares Committee until after the three years notice period-and the Government has already wasted nine months of that time. Certainly the Government is allowing some independent charter services to start domestically, but it should follow the same course of deregulation began under the Carter Administration. Informal deregulation was allowed through discussions among the airlines and the competitive adjustment took place far more easily.
—What a disaster that has been.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Aston.

—Every time we put forward this logical progression, which the Government is now following and is wasting time in doing so, the Government poured scorn on us, impugned us and imputed improper motives to us such as advocating ownership by foreigners. Today that duplicity is continuing. It is inevitable that Australian Airlines will be sold. It must be privatised. If it is not honourable members opposite will carry on their shoulders the even greater cross of what to do with what was once a great Australian airline.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am amazed at the belated concern shown by the National Party of Australia for Australian Airlines. I am amazed that the honourable member--
—Order! The Chair wants to hear the honourable member for--
—We want the honourable member for Calwell.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—I am amazed that the honour- able member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) talked about privatisation in the way he did. The Shepparton News has reported the honourable member for Murray as opposing the sale of Telecom Australia. The Opposition parties have a different policy.
—Are you in favour of selling Telecom?
—If the Leader of the Opposition continues to interject I will warn him.
—The problem with the National Party--
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Shepparton News has never reported me as being opposed to the sale of Australian Airlines, and that is the subject of this discussion.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—It is typical of members of the National Party to say these things in this House. I have a lot of time for them. As I said earlier today, they are bad weather socialists, and I can understand their defending country people. But it is relevant to note that our Party now has a substantial number of members-22 in fact-from country areas. In 1983 the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) described the two-airline agreement as something which was forcing Australian Airlines to fly with one wing tied behind its back. It is interesting that the honourable member for Gwydir has been sitting here throughout this debate. How can the honourable member for Gwydir reconcile that sort of statement with the sort of statement we have heard today, particularly from the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) and the honourable member for Murray? The honourable member for Gwydir, of course, knows that he was the Minister for Transport when that agreement was renegotiated in 1981. But here he is sitting behind people who are preaching new messages to this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, the Opposition parties pursue privatisation with a great religious fervour-the same sort of religious fervour which resulted in the sale of British Telecom for less than its value, to try to avoid concentrated ownership. We now find British Telecom making a subscriber in Scotland pay the equivalent of $10,000 for a new telephone service-and, for remote areas, Scotland has nothing on Australia. The honourable member for Deakin may think that he sees the light; but he forgets about the hill. Good government means responsible government and the religion of privatisation which possesses the Opposition, particularly the honourable member for Deakin, has no official support from members of this Government. Every government regulated industry needs to be looked at constantly by government. Its efficiency, viability and best means of operation all need to be checked. The Opposition's blind support for privatisation-whether it be Australia Post, Telecom, Australian Airlines, the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation or the Snowy Mountains Authority-ignores the need to look at each enterprise separately. In the consideration of the future of such enterprises as these we need to take into account Australia's dependence on the vast areas which provide a large proportion of its exports. The Opposition has taken no account of the needs of people in remote areas-whether they be shopkeepers, school teachers, government or professional providers, farmers or industry owners-to be provided with traversable roads, reasonable communications services and adequate transport by road, sea and air. That is why country people are better off when the government owns enterprises which can cross-subsidise, whether it is Australia Post or Telecom.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is the Government going to sell Australian Airlines, then?
—Order! The honourable member for Murray has contributed to this debate. I ask him to remain silent.

—If lucrative parts of Australia Post and Telecom were to be sold, as the Opposition wants to do, the city parts would be sold and people in country areas would be left to pay, in the case of Telecom, rents perhaps as high as $500 more than they are paying now; they would have to pay higher taxes or their services would be drastically reduced-probably all three. This is the sort of proposition that the Opposition is putting to us.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that we look at the historical basis for the current situation whereby the Government has a significant role in the airlines industry through its ownership of Australian Airlines, most major airports and airline terminals and Qantas Airways Ltd. In the mid-1940s the Chifley Labor Government reflected the Government's concern that if market forces were allowed to operate in a completely unregulated fashion a private airline monopoly in the industry would ultimately result. That is what this Government has to be careful about. It does not want to go along the track of the United States of America, where there was a massive deregulation, a sacrifice in safety and increased concentration of ownership. Subsequently, following the decision of the Chifley Government, the Menzies Government decided to retain Trans Australia Airlines as a public enterprise which would operate under a controlled form of competition with the major private airline under the umbrella of the two-airline policy.

There are strong arguments for the retention of Australian Airlines. First of all, we need to ensure the maintenance of competition in the deregulated airline industry. We need to prevent, for instance, Ansett Airlines of Australia from dominating the market. Ansett is a well-established operator with a solid financial backing, under the ownership of Thomas Nationwide Transport Pty Ltd and News Ltd. It would appear to have benefited substantially from its legacy of 35 years of protection from market forces which the two-airline policy has afforded it. As such, Ansett has a head start on any potential newcomers to the industry, including a privatised Australian Airlines. Australian Airlines has been disadvantaged by its government status in terms of inadequate capitalisation and other restrictions on its commercial freedom-for example, superannuation and Loan Council approval requirements. The Opposition, when in government, encouraged Australian Airlines to decline. It is interesting that the May Independent Review of Economic Regulation of Domestic Aviation observed:

It may . . . be more reasonable to assume that in a completely deregulated environment Ansett Airlines' position would become such that only a government-owned competitor could be assured of survival.

Another argument for retention of Australian Airlines would be that to give the Government an insight into the workings of the industry it is useful for it to retain Australian Airlines. These are matters which need to be debated in the coming year. One of the traditional arguments for government ownership of Australian Airlines has been to give the Government an insight into an industry which has particularly significant public interest dimensions. Also there is a major social role in bringing cohesion to a nation with a relatively small population. With deregulation, the need for the Government to have first-hand insight into the workings of the industry will be enhanced by maintaining Australian Airlines under public ownership as a public company.

It is particularly important to ensure the maintenance of fair competition. We have to remember continually that Australia is a large country with fairly concentrated populations but with a very important need to service remote areas and outlying districts, which often provide our exports. How National Party members can hypocritically say the things they are saying, I do not understand. The government airline could assume a significant social, economic development role in maintaining those services to remote areas and in promoting down-market tourist services, which may otherwise be neglected by private operators. All those things need to be considered as we enter the debate.

We also need to keep options open for a Qantas-Australian Airlines merger. We should not preclude such a merger by privatising Australian Airlines at this stage. The Opposition is not only jumping the gun; it is also ignoring the interests of millions of Australian people. It is particularly important that an international airline industry become increasingly competitive, and the need for Qantas to have direct access to a domestic airline network of its own will become more and more important. So we should not exclude that sort of option. Australian Airlines has operated under some disadvantage. It is expected to comply with various broader government policies in areas such as purchasing, salary structure and a wide range of exclusions--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The debate is concluded.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Young, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr YOUNG
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill contains amendments to the Migration Act 1958 to implement decisions taken in the Budget context to recover some of the costs associated with the provision of various services under my portfolio. The 1987-88 Budget expands the level and quality of services provided to the community and to clients of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. In order to help fund these improved services some existing fees for departmental services are to be increased, and this legislation introduces some new fees. This reflects the Government's concern that some of the costs of services of benefit to clients should be borne by the user, and not the community as a whole. The increased revenue proposed also reflects the demand by clients that the Government provide faster and more efficient services. Such improvements are not always possible without resources being increased-resources which have to be funded.

As announced on Budget night, there will be a fee, which will be set initially at $240, for reconsideration of certain decisions taken under the Migration Act. This is the same amount as the fee for lodgment of appeals with the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. In order to protect public revenue, the clause of the Bill that relates to the scheme-clause 9 (a)-will, on enactment of the Bill, be taken to have come into operation on 16 September 1987. The details of the scheme will be prescribed by regulations, which will specify the types of decisions which will be able to be reconsidered under this procedure; who will have standing to apply for reconsideration; the time limit in which such a request will have to be made; and the limited circumstances in which the fee will be refundable.

The Budget also provides for an augmentation of the resources devoted to reconsideration of decisions under the Act. The membership of the Immigration Review Panel has been increased from 32 to 157 and the panels now meet in all mainland State capitals. Departmental resources allocated to the review task have been more than doubled. These steps have been taken to provide improved service and overcome the present backlog of cases. As honourable members know, the Immigration Review Panel was established in 1982. It is independent of my department and recommends to me whether decisions which have been appealed should be maintained or changed.

The review system is essentially directed to providing an avenue for Australian citizens and permanent residents affected by a refusal decision made overseas in respect of an application by a close relative or a sponsored employee to seek the reconsideration of that decision. In some cases, the actual person who is the subject of the refusal decision-especially where that decision is made in Australia-will have the right to seek a review under these arrangements, provided that he or she was legally in Australia at the time the refused application for further temporary stay, or resident status, was lodged.

Simultaneously with the introduction of the fee, the range of reviewable decisions has been significantly widened. Among the decisions that will be prescribed as reviewable, following a request by an eligible appellant, will be refused migrant entry applications, with the exception of people applying to settle in Australia under the refugee or special humanitarian programs; refused applications for permission to come for a temporary stay in Australia, apart from those in relation to persons coming to study; unsuccessful applications for the grant of resident status; and refused applications for extension of stay by persons in Australia on a temporary basis. Decisions not prescribed will not be reviewable under the legislation, but will be subject to existing arrangements.

The fee that has now been introduced is refundable to appellants where the decision-maker on appeal is of the view that, on the basis of the information available to the earlier decision-maker, a favourable decision should have been made by the earlier decision-maker. To explain these new arrangements, I recently wrote to all members and senators. I note that representations concerning these prescribed migration decisions-if they are to be effective-will need to relate to a formal request for reconsideration. That is, no effective action on a request for reconsideration will be taken unless statutory requirements have been fulfilled, including the payment of the notified fee. Where a valid request for reconsideration has been made, representations from honourable members of parliament will be able to be considered by me and by the Immigration Review Panel.

As I have mentioned, the introduction of the fee is in the context of the new arrangements to provide a much improved and speedier service for reconsideration of decisions. The estimated cost of providing the review mechanism in 1987-88 is $5.9m. The estimated revenue from the fee is $1.44m in 1987-88 and $1.92m in a full year. These changes are not meant to affect the recommendations about the review process made in 1985 by the Administrative Review Council. Those recommendations will be considered afresh following the report of the Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies.

Clause 7 of the Bill establishes the mechanism whereby a new immigration clearance fee for service can be collected and paid to the Commonwealth. At present, the full cost of undertaking immigration clearance services at ports of entry is borne by the Australian taxpayer. These costs are increasing dramatically each year, because the number of persons travelling to Australia is increasing and because of improved clearance services. In order to recoup part of these costs, it was announced in the Budget package that passengers over 12 years of age arriving on international flights and who require immigration clearance on arrival will, from 1 January 1988, be required to pay a $5 immigration clearance fee. The fee is to be collected by international airline operators who bring the passengers to Australia. In turn, the operators will pay the fees collectable by them to the Commonwealth. The amount of the fee payable by airlines will be a debt due to the Commonwealth.

Revenue generated from the fee is estimated to total about $17m in a full year. It will be used to offset the cost of immigration inspection of passengers at airports; the costs relating to passengers who are refused entry; the cost of facilities to detect fraudulent immigration documentation; the cost of issue of visas; the salaries and other costs of airport staff; and general administrative overheads. Consultation with the airline operators is taking place to ensure that the legislation and mechanisms to impose the charge will impose as small an administrative burden as necessary on the airlines.

The Bill also seeks to introduce a system of on the spot penalties for airline and shipping companies bringing foreign nationals to Australia without proper immigration documentation. At present, carrier companies commit an offence under the Act and, if found guilty by the courts, are liable to a maximum penalty of $2,000, for each foreign national they bring into Australia without proper immigration documentation. Clause 6 (b) provides that the maximum penalty will be increased to $3,000. The level of the maximum penalty has stood at $2,000 since the offence provision was established in 1979. Clause 9 (c) of the Bill will provide power to establish a mechanism whereby, as an alternative to proceeding in courts, it will be open to the Department to serve a notice on the carrier stating that it is in breach of the Act and requiring it to pay a prescribed amount as a penalty.

The system, which is to operate from 1 January 1988, will provide that the maximum penalty will not exceed $1,500-which will be half the maximum penalty which can be imposed by the courts. As publicly announced on Budget night, it is intended that initially the penalty will be $1,000. The option will, however, still be open to the Department to institute proceedings before the courts under section 11c of the Act. Clauses 6 and 8 make amendments to section 11c and section 57 to facilitate the production of evidence in court, in the event of prosecution under section 11c. The present system of instituting prosecutions is both time consuming and costly, even though the factual issues are relatively straightforward and simple.

The number of prosecutions able to be initiated by my Department is very small, which is of concern, given that the number of people arriving without documentation is increasing. Overseas experience indicates that a system of on the spot fines acts as a powerful incentive for international carriers to check more adequately their passengers' documentation prior to boarding and helps to reduce the number of inadequately documented passengers arriving at borders. It is not, of course, proposed to impose the penalties where a carrier can show that it had taken all reasonable steps to ensure that passengers had valid documentation when they boarded the aircraft or ship.

A final matter dealt with in the Bill is that amendments are to be made to the provisions in the Act dealing with requests for entry permits and visas. In order for a valid request to be made, it will be necessary for any prescribed fee to be paid, and the request to be made in writing in accordance with the relevant form approved by the Minister. This was also announced on Budget night and will, on enactment of the Bill, be taken to have come into operation from 16 September 1987. The amendments-clauses 3, 4 and 5-will clear up an anomaly identified in a recent court case which cast doubts on the requirement that the prescribed fee actually was payable. The need to lodge applications in accordance with the relevant form will help overcome problems which officers of my Department have experienced in identifying whether in fact a person is making an application.

Of course, in the vast majority of cases, applicants have always paid the relevant fee and lodged their application on an official form. This amendment is merely designed to help underpin that practice. Similar arrangements will be put into place, by way of regulations, in relation to requests for reconsideration of decisions. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. This contains details of the amendments I have outlined. I commend this Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Connolly) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK INDUSTRY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to make a number of amendments to legislation affecting Australia's meat and livestock industry, namely, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act 1977, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation Act 1985, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Policy Council Act 1984, and the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Selection Committee Act 1984. This Bill is associated with the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill 1987 and the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill 1987.

In regard to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act 1977, the Bill formalises the ability of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation to work with the Australian Pork Corporation in the development of marketing schemes for meat and livestock. Provision is made for the Minister to prescribe by regulation individual marketing schemes such as computer aided livestock marketing, known as CALM, and the authority for the uniform specification of meat and livestock known as Ausmeat.

The Bill also provides that the AMLC will be required to consult with the peak industry bodies in the preparation of its five-year corporate plan and its annual operational plan. In addition, the five-year plan is to be a rolling plan; that is, it will need to be updated each year so that it always covers the next five years. A number of specific additions are made to the information to be contained in the AMLC's annual report; these are intended to improve the level of reporting by the Corporation to Parliament on its activities.

The powers of the AMLC to meet the costs and expenses incurred by industry organisations attending consultations with the Corporation are clarified. The AMLC will be able to make payments in addition to travelling expenses, in accordance with guidelines issued by the Minister. These guidelines make it quite clear that only reasonable costs associated with consultations can be met, and it will be up to the AMLC to ensure that activities for which it meets the costs are consistent with its powers and functions. The legislation proposes to limit the making of such payments to the Cattle Council of Australia, the Sheepmeat Council of Australia and the Australian Meat Exporters Federal Council. There is also, however, a provision for other organisations to be added to the list by regulation, should it become apparent that this is appropriate.

Under the current AMLC Act, members are appointed for a fixed three-year term with appointments being staggered so that not all members change at once. It is proposed to make this arrangement more flexible by providing that members may be appointed for periods of up to three years.

A number of changes are intended to streamline the administration and operation of the AMLC's annual general meeting. These include greater flexibility in the timing of annual general meetings, the closing date of voting registers, lodgment of notices of motion and the deadline by which proxies must be lodged. In addition, the provision requiring a vote of 75 per cent of those people on the register to pass a special motion or to overturn a Corporation motion for an increase in the levy is to be changed so that a vote of 75 per cent of those people present, either in person or by proxy, is all that will be required.

In line with the Government's policy on the reform of statutory marketing authorities, the legislation requires the AMLC to adopt an equal employment opportunities program. This program is to be incorporated in the Corporation's corporate plans and a progress report is to be included in the Corporation's annual report to Parliament.

The changes to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation Act 1985 are designed to streamline the administration and operation of the AMLRDC's annual general meeting and mirror the changes being made in this regard to the AMLC Act. The Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Policy Council Act 1984 is to be amended to remove the requirement that the Policy Council hold an industry-wide conference at least every two years to canvass industry views on matters currently affecting the industry. The Policy Council will, however, retain its power to call such conferences whenever it feels they are needed.

This Bill also seeks to amend the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Selection Committee Act 1984. This Act provides for a selection committee to nominate members for appointment to the AMLC and the AMLRDC. The proposed changes are to allow for the appointment of members of the selection committee for periods of up to three years instead of the present fixed three-year term. Also it is proposed to remove the requirement for the selection committee to prepare an annual report to Parliament. The preparation of an annual report is considered unnecessary as the committee has only a single purpose and meets on an ad hoc basis. The amendment will bring the selection committee into line with other statutory marketing authority selection committees. The changes proposed by this Bill will have no impact on Commonwealth income or expenditure. I commend the Bill to honourable members, and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Connolly) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to increase the maximum rates of export charge that may be imposed under the Live-stock Export Charge Act 1964. This Act imposes a charge on the export of cattle, sheep, lambs, buffaloes and goats from Australia. As in the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Act 1964, the charge consists of three components which raise funds to finance the activities of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation (AMLC), the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation (AMLRDC) and, in the case of cattle and buffaloes, bovine disease eradication.

Maximum rates are set in the legislation for the AMLRDC component, the disease eradication component, and the total of the AMLRDC and AMLC components. The maximum available for the AMLC is the difference between the current operative rate for the AMLRDC and the maximum rate prescribed for the total of the AMLRDC and AMLC components. The individual operative rates of charge for each class of livestock are set by regulation. The export charge rates for the AMLC and the AMLRDC are varied only after the Minister has received recommendations from the relevant body; that is, either the AMLC or the AMLRDC. Neither the AMLC nor the AMLRDC is permitted to recommend a change to the operative rates of export charge without having first had a motion endorsing the changes passed at their respective annual general meetings.

The amendments proposed in this Bill will increase the maximum level of the export charge and therefore the AMLC's potential share of the charge, while not increasing the maximum rate prescribed for the AMLRDC or disease eradication. The proposed increases in the maximum charge rates are as follows: cattle, from $6 to $18; sheep, from 60c to $1.50; lambs, from 67c to $1.50; buffalo, from $6 to $18; and goats, from 60c to $1. The considerations behind the substantial increase in maximum charge rates are the same as I outlined in my speech relating to the livestock slaughter levy. The proposed increases will have no effect on the current operative rates of the livestock export charge, nor will they have any direct impact on Commonwealth income or expenditure. I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Connolly) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to increase the maximum rates of levy that may be imposed under the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Act 1964. This Act imposes a levy on the slaughter at an abattoir of cattle, sheep, lambs, buffaloes, goats, calves and bobby calves for human consumption. This Bill is associated with the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill 1987.

The levy consists of three components which raise funds to finance the activities of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation (AMLC), including its promotion functions, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation (AMLRDC) and, in the case of cattle, calves, bobby calves and buffaloes, bovine disease eradication. Maximum rates are set in the legislation for the AMLRDC component, the disease eradication component and the total of the AMLRDC and AMLC components. The maximum available for the AMLC is the difference between the current operative rate for AMLRDC and the maximum rate prescribed for the total of the AMLRDC and AMLC components. The individual operative rates of the levy for each class of livestock are set by regulation. The slaughter levy rates for the AMLC and the AMLRDC are varied only after the Minister has received recommendations from the relevant body; that is either the AMLC or the AMLRDC. Neither the AMLC nor the AMLRDC is permitted to recommend a change to the operative rates of levy without having first had a motion endorsing the changes passed at the respective annual general meetings.

The amendments proposed in the Bill will increase the maximum level of the slaughter levy and therefore the AMLC's potential share of the levy, while not changing the amount set aside for the AMLRDC or disease eradication. The proposed increases in the maximum levy rates are as follows: cattle, from $6 to $18; sheep, from 60c to $1.50; lambs, from 67c to $1.50; buffalo, from $6 to $18; goats, from 60c to $1; calves, from $2.10 to $6.30; bobby calves, from 60c to $1.80.

Substantial increases in the maximum rates prescribed for the livestock slaughter levy have been recommended by the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation, with general support from the major industry organisations. The levels recommended to me allow scope for the AMLC component of the levy to be increased to enable the purchase and disposal of meat with a high risk of containing pesticide residues and to finance anticipated expenditure by the Corporation on programs being initiated to avoid a repetition of the recent chemical residues crisis. They also provide scope for the AMLC to seek additional funding for its promotion activities in Australia and overseas.

On the matter of pesticide residues, I would like to congratulate the industry on its preparedness to tackle the problem. The industry, apparently universally, accepts the need to get its house in order and to take whatever steps are necessary to re-establish its reputation as a supplier of nutritious product to the world's markets. Domestic consumers can be assured that Australian meat remains a healthy and desirable part of a well-balanced diet.

The adequacy of the AMLC's present promotion activities was the subject of lively debate at the last annual general meeting of the AMLC. It was apparent at that meeting that there was general willingness to support significant increases in promotion expenditure if the AMLC thought it would be cost effective.

Passage of this Bill will clear the way for the possible introduction of new operative rates of levy if such are recommended by the forthcoming annual meeting of the AMLC. The proposed increases will have no effect on the current operative rates of livestock slaughter levy, nor will they have any direct impact on Commonwealth income or expenditure. I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Connolly) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGES COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The principal purpose of this Bill is to amend the Export Inspection Charges Collection Act 1985 to complement the amendments to the Export Inspection (Establishment Registration Charge) Act 1985, which are included in the Export Inspection (Establishment Registration Charges) Amendment Bill 1987. The Bill amends the provisions in the Export Inspection Charges Collection Act 1985 which prevent the extension of the `continuous registration' initiative to establishments which are subject to establishment registration charge. An explanation of this initiative is given in the second reading speech on the Export Inspection (Establishment Registration Charges) Amendment Bill 1987. The Bill also makes general consequential drafting changes.

Other effects of the Bill are to replace a provision describing the time within which various charges are to be payable, so as to leave that kind of detail to be specified in regulations, and to remove a provision which will serve no purpose following the entry into force of amendments to the Export Control Act 1982, which are included in the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 1) 1987. The Bill will have no direct financial impact, as the amount of charge collected will not be affected by the amendments. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Connolly) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT INSPECTION (ESTABLISHMENT REGISTRATION CHARGES) AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Export Inspection (Establishment Registration Charge) Act 1985 to remove impediments to the full implementation of an initiative designed to reduce the red tape burden on exporters of foodstuffs. The Export Inspection (Establishment Registration Charge) Act 1985 is one of three Acts-the others being the Export Inspection (Quantity Charge) Act 1985 and the Export Inspection (Service Charge) Act 1985 introduced by this Government to give as much flexibility as possible in determining appropriate export inspection charging systems for different sectors of the food export industry.

At the time the Act was introduced, export establishments were registered on an annual basis subject to renewal, and the establishment registration charge was modelled accordingly, to be a charge on that registration, payable annually. Earlier this year, the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service initiated a system of continuing, or perpetual, registrations, not requiring any renewal. This is attractive as reducing the paper work for the Service and for industry, and reducing administrative costs in the long run. Because of the inflexible nature of the establishment registration charge, establishments subject to that charge have not been able to participate in that system. These are all establishments involved in the preparation of fish and poultry products for export.

The Bill amends provisions in the Export Inspection (Establishment Registration Charge) Act 1985 which prevent the extension of this initiative to establishments which are subject to the establishment registration charge. Under the Bill, the charge may be imposed on a periodic basis and not linked to the commencement or renewal of registration. The Bill also makes several consequential drafting changes. The Bill will have no direct financial impact, as the amounts of charge imposed will not be affected by the amendments. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. I commend the Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Lloyd) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr John Brown, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Sea Installations Bills were passed by the House in the autumn sittings and honourable members will recall that the legislation had the support of all parties in the House. Passage of this legislation is necessary so that a regulatory system is in place in the time for the opening of the floating hotel to be installed at the John Brewer Reef by Barrier Reef Holdings and to consider proposals for other similar ventures. There have been several proposals for establishing off-shore installations on the continental shelf beyond the territorial sea, mostly, to date, in the Great Barrier Reef area. Some of these can be dealt with under existing arrangements involving the Great Barrier Reef Ministerial Council and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, both of which involve continuing Commonwealth and Queensland co-operation on policies and day to day management. However, proposals are now being made which require regulation beyond the scope of those arrangements.

This legislation provides a framework not only to ensure that new developments are technically sound and environmentally acceptable, but also to provide a basis for the application of important Commonwealth laws in an area of Commonwealth responsibility where presently no general body of civil or criminal law applies, and for State or Territory laws to be adopted as Commonwealth laws. These provisions are parallel to those already applying under the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act, which regulates off-shore petroleum and mineral exploration and extraction. That Act and the Bills are based on the belief that the most efficient approach is to adopt State and Territory laws and to develop administrative arrangements involving State and Territory administrations. This approach also takes account of the satisfactory arrangements we have with the Queensland Government for day to day management of Great Barrier Reef Marine Park activities by the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service.

It is important that off-shore installations not be used as a basis for evasion of Australian laws, particularly those regulating customs, migration, taxation and quarantine. The proposed legislation will deal with this by requiring contact with the installations to be from the mainland or an adjacent Territory, and by including provisions to ensure that the laws in question can be efficiently and effectively applied. The Bills do not cover sales tax and income tax, both of which will be the subject of separate legislation in accordance with the announcement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in January this year.

The approach taken in the legislation is to require proponents of off-shore installations to seek permits. They will have to provide information about the purpose of the installation, structural and technical issues, the extent of use and occupation by people, insurance arrangements and so on so that proper standards can be applied, and assessments made of the impact on the environment. Where necessary, the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act will be invoked, as was done in the case of the proposed floating hotel off Townsville and is now being done for a similar proposal for the Fitzroy Reef. Permits will be accompanied by whatever safeguards are necessary to ensure that safety and environment considerations are paramount in day to day operations. Variation, revocation and renewal provisions have been included to provide a means of continuing monitoring and to allow changes to accommodate any new factors which arise.

Thus, concerns relating to the number of permitted sea installations, particularly tourist complexes, which were raised during the second reading debate earlier this year, are groundless. This Government is not about to authorise a chain of floating hotels in the Great Barrier Reef region, which this legislation is designed to protect. The application of State laws and the use of State administrations will be an important part of this monitoring, in areas like health standards and others which will normally apply to similar operations on the mainland. The Sea Installations Bill makes clear that the States will be paid for their participation.

There are several categories of installations which do not require further regulation, such as certain fishing vessels and historic shipwrecks. These are already subject to effective and sufficient regulation. It will also be possible under the regulations to exempt other installations from the new legislation. A provision has been included to allow exemption from particular aspects of the regulatory scheme. This will also ensure that there is no unintended interference with existing regulatory arrangements directed at matters not within the objectives of this Bill. On the other hand, care has been taken in defining sea installations to include non-exempted ships which remain constantly or continuously in the seas in question and thereby provide a basis for evasion of the legislation. These provisions acknowledge our obligations in respect of foreign shipping.

The Bill's delayed passage has given officers of the Government the opportunity to fine tune its provisions. For example, the definition of `sea installation' has been amended to provide for further exemptions from the operation of the legislation, including commercial fishing and pearling vessels, navigational and meteorological aids, commercial cargo carriers, wharves and jetties and historic shipwrecks. These exemptions will ensure further that over-regulation will not occur. The Government has also recognised the desirability of amending the levy arrangement to permit a flexible and simple approach. In some cases, a fixed fee based on revenue or market value may be appropriate, while in others a fee based on the number of visitors may be best. This approach recognises the variety of installations, ranging from fairly simple pontoons to large hotels, which may need to be covered.

The development of off-shore installations is already a fact of life. We are committed to harmonising conservation and sustainable development in the natural environment. This includes the seas. This legislation will be part of the Government's policy of protection, wise use, understanding and enjoyment of the environment. This approach is already being applied by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority to installations subject to its regulations. I commend this Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Connolly) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr John Brown, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is part of a package of Bills to provide for the implementation of the Government's decisions relating to sea installations. The levy Bill provides a framework for imposing taxes and charges on these installations. This will ensure that the administrative costs of the States and Territories are met, and that general revenue can benefit, as it would if similar installations were located on the mainland. The States have quite rightly pointed out that the development of off-shore installations for commercial purposes should not be at the expense of the mainland economy, and should not provide a basis for evasion of State and Territory legislation. The Commonwealth accepts this, and so the intention is that the levy be set with these factors in mind. I recommend this Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr John Brown, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is part of the sea installations package and provides for the extra-territorial application of several Commonwealth Acts to sea installations installed in waters off Australia as a consequence of the proposed introduction of the principal Bill in the package, the Sea Installations Bill 1987. The proposed amendments to the Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act 1901, contained in parts II and IV respectively of the Bill, extend those Acts to sea installations installed in coastal waters of Australia, or areas adjacent thereto, and give to officers administering those respective Acts, customs control powers over such installations and any ships, aircraft, persons or goods arriving with or at the installations or departing overseas from such installations. The extension of customs control to these installations includes the respective customs and excise tariff Acts, so that with regard to sea installations brought to Australia from overseas, for example, import duty will apply under the Customs Tariff Act in the normal way.

The proposed amendments to the Migration Act 1958, contained in part VI of the Bill, essentially identify the point when sea installations and the persons on board such installations enter Australia, and extend the migration control powers of that Act to such installations, once installed. The proposed amendments to the Quarantine Act 1908, contained in part VII of the Bill, apply, similar to the previously mentioned Acts, a wide range of quarantine controls to sea installations which are installed in coastal waters of Australia or areas adjacent thereto. The principal of these is to make newly arrived installations, and persons or goods on such installations, subject to quarantine. The Bill is proposed to commence on the date on which the principal Sea Installations Bill 1987 receives the royal assent, with the exception of the customs and excise related amendments, which will be deemed to have commenced on 15 October 1987, so that the duty provisions of those Acts noted previously can apply as and from that date. A standard penalty transitional provision is provided for those amendments, however, to prevent any penalty or offence provisions under that legislation from applying to acts done, or omitted to be done, prior to the royal assent of this Bill. The proposed amendments in this Bill have no direct financial implications. I commend the Bill to the House, and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Connolly) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Holding, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the imposition from 1 July 1987 of an annual levy on all borrowings, including raisings of money otherwise than by borrowing, by Commonwealth semi-government authorities. The levy is imposed in place of the Commonwealth guarantee charge introduced in 1986-87. The Commonwealth guarantee charge was introduced to take account of the favourable interest rates paid by Commonwealth authorities where their borrowings are explicitly guaranteed by the Commonwealth. The Government's objective in imposing the charge was to ensure that the effective cost of borrowings to authorities was more directly comparable with that faced by private sector borrowers, thus ensuring that authorities take full account of the cost to the community of their investment decisions.

Following a review of the operation of the charge in 1986-87, the Government has decided that the arrangements should be modified in three respects. First, the charge on explicit Commonwealth guarantees should be replaced by a levy on all borrowings by authorities. This is because the authorities' government-owned status confers advantages in financial markets similar to those which arise from an explicit government guarantee. The cost of funds to Commonwealth authorities appears to reflect an expectation by lenders that the Commonwealth will stand behind those authorities whether or not an explicit guarantee has been given. Second, the levy should not apply to Commonwealth-owned financial institutions, such as the Commonwealth banks and the Australian Industry Development Corporation. These institutions gain only little advantage in terms of borrowing costs from Commonwealth ownership beyond that arising from their status as financial institutions. Third, the rate of the levy should be lowered to reflect more closely the benefit that authorities gain from Commonwealth ownership.

These modified arrangements are to apply to borrowings undertaken on or after 1 July 1987. Borrowings undertaken in 1986-87, which were subject to the Commonwealth guarantee charge, will continue to bear that charge until they mature. The Bill provides for the imposition of the levy at a rate not exceeding 1.5 per cent per annum, the rate of the Commonwealth guarantee charge applying in 1986-87. It is intended that, in respect of 1987-88, a levy at the lesser rate of 1.125 per cent per annum will be imposed by regulation. The levy imposed by this Bill is expected to raise revenue of some $1.3m in 1987-88, while ongoing revenue from the Commonwealth guarantee charge is estimated to amount to $7.6m. The impost is now described as a levy because it will apply comprehensively to borrowings and will not be related to the provision of a guarantee, which in most cases could be sought by authorities at their discretion. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Connolly) adjourned.

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the collection of the Commonwealth borrowing levy imposed by the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Bill 1987. The Bill defines the borrowings in respect of which the levy may be payable to include all borrowings and other raisings of money which the Commonwealth authorities subject to the Levy Bill are empowered to undertake, and provides for the making of administrative arrangements to collect the levy.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987, which is now before the House, contains a number of amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1987-the harmonised tariff-which was passed by Parliament in the autumn sittings.

The international convention on which the harmonised tariff is based will come into force on 1 January 1988. It is the Government's intention that the new tariff and the amendments proposed in this Bill will operate from the same date. These amendments, which are explained in detail in the explanatory memorandum presented with the Bill, can be divided into three main categories:

First, those required to implement decisions on industry assistance and trade relations matters taken since the close-off date for the principal legislation. Many reflect changes already implemented in the current tariff;
Second, amendments to correct anomalies created by the translation of current assistance arrangements to the harmonised format; and
Third, editorial amendments to clarify the intention of the convention and to correct errors in the original legislation.

The first group of amendments results from Government decisions on the development of the pharmaceutical products industry and the chemicals and plastics industries, and those taken following receipt of Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) reports on vegetables and vegetable products; luggage, handbags and similar containers; and reconditioned automotive engines. With the exception of pharmaceutical products and reconditioned engines, the amendments implement, in the harmonised tariff, changes which have already been commenced in the current tariff.

Amendments following the Government's consideration of the pharmaceutical products industry and the IAC report on reconditioned automotive engines are consistent with the Government's policy to encourage internationally competitive industries and to reduce reliance on tariff assistance. The amendments reduce the general tariff rate on glycosides from the current 20 per cent to 2 per cent, crepe bandages from 20 per cent to 5 per cent, wadding from 20 per cent to 10 per cent and certain automotive engines from 25 per cent to 15 per cent. Also falling to this category are amendments implementing the Government's continuing sectoral policies in respect of textiles, clothing and footwear and passenger motor vehicles.

The second group consists of amendments to redress assistance anomalies which have become apparent following publication of the harmonised tariff. In its report on tariff harmonisation, the IAC calculated that its recommended option two would have little effect on industry assistance generally. However, it conceded that duty rates for particular goods might vary significantly. Seven anomalies have been brought to notice which would have unacceptable consequences for the industries concerned. These, and the remedial actions proposed, are:
Chain of precious metal: duties are increased from 2 per cent to 25 per cent to maintain the current assistance level.
Solar cells and assembled solar arrays: duties are increased from 2 per cent to 20 per cent to maintain current assistance levels.
Beverages concentrates: duties are decreased from 10 per cent to 5 per cent to maintain the current duty rate.
Wadding of textile materials: duties are decreased from 25 per cent to 2 per cent which is the current rate.

Certain air compressors: these goods are currently under reference to the IAC. Pending the outcome of this review, duties have been increased from 5 per cent to 15 or 25 per cent. The amendment reflects the more detailed structures proposed by the IAC in option one of its recommendations on the harmonised tariff.
Motorcycle exhaust systems: duties are increased from 5 per cent to 20 per cent to maintain current assistance levels.
Certain commercial cooking equipment: duties are decreased from 25 per cent to 15 per cent to maintain the current duty rate.

Finally, the third group of amendments includes minor redrafting and additional notes to some sections and chapters considered necessary to clarify the intent of the convention, to correct errors and to strengthen some provisions in the principal Act. The opportunity has also been taken to remove a redundant item in schedule 4 to the principal Act.
Financial Impact
The decreases in customs duty rates for the pharmaceutical products will result in an estimated decrease in revenue of $568,000 during the financial year 1987-88.

The vegetables and vegetable products industry has undergone considerable rationalisation in recent times, particularly in the processing sector. It is expected that there will be further rationalisation in the tomato growing and processing sector. The rationalisation of the rates of duty is expected to have minimal financial impact.

It is difficult to quantify the financial consequences of the decision on the chemicals and plastics industries. However, it is likely that the removal of the concessional arrangements will provide some increase in duty payments. However, in the context of the Government's overall decision on chemicals and plastics which considerably reduced tariff rates, the net effect of the current changes will be minimal.

The impact of the change to flax yarns is also difficult to isolate from changes associated with a move to a uniform 15 per cent duty rate for yarns and threads not subject to bounty. In the financial year 1987-88 the changes affecting flax yarns are likely to add approximately $200,000 to revenue and $400,000 in a full year. This is based on annual imports in recent years averaging around $8m from those sources affected by the 5 per cent increase in duties. The remainder of the changes to textiles, clothing and footwear are expected to have no financial impact.

The reduction in duty on off-road vehicles from an average rate of 63 per cent to 25 per cent is expected to reduce revenue by up to $400,000 in a full year. This loss to the revenue could be offset by additional customs duty through increased imports as the lower duty rate plus removal of quota restrictions increases demand and available supply. The imposition of a surcharge of 3.9c per litre on aviation gasoline will raise an estimated $3.9m in the financial year 1987-88.

There is expected to be minimal financial impact caused by the other amendments in the Bill. Details of the amendments contained in the Bill have been included in an explanatory memorandum which has been circulated for the information of honourable members and which I now table. I commend the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Connolly) adjourned.
