SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address my brief comments this afternoon to the appropriations for the Australian Electoral Commission. Budget Paper No. 3 provides for an allocation of $73,310,000 to the Australian Electoral Commission in the coming financial year. I am sure that you, Mr Deputy Chairman, will be aware of the great importance to Australia of an independent non-political Australian Electoral Commission. Arising out of the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform in the Thirty-third Parliament, the Parliament passed legislation to dismantle the previous organisation, known as the Australian Electoral Office. The Australian Parliament decided that it was very important that we establish an independent Australian Electoral Commission which would be not separated from ministerial approval but made independent of the party political process. That is something which is quite important to the fair functioning of elections in a democracy.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to address my comments today to an attack by one member of this Parliament on the independence of the Australian Electoral Commission. The fact that that attack was made in the heat of an election campaign does not excuse the fact that a member of this chamber has sought to slur the independent Australian Electoral Commission. During the election period the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) put out a Press release on 2 July 1987. I will read the full text of that release so that I cannot be accused of not providing the full details of it. It is headed `Official Federal Election Guide Misleads Voters'. Above that heading it states:
Julian Beale, M.H.R., Shadow Minister for Communications, Shadow Minister assisting the Shadow Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is the shadow.

—As the honourable member for Macarthur suggests, he is the shadow. I mentioned that he was the shadow Minister assisting the shadow Treasurer because he has made a few arithmetical errors in this Press release. The Press release states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke Government's official Federal Election Guide grossly misleads voters, according to Julian Beale, Federal Member for Deakin and Shadow Minister for Communications.
The Federal Election Guide has been posted to all Australian households.
The instructions for Senate voting in Victoria are incredibly biased towards the A.L.P.
The Ministers responsible for electoral practices must immediately recall all of these bogus guides.
The Senate ballot paper in the guide indicates three ways to vote, described as A, or B, or C.
A happens to be the D.L.P.;
B happens to be the Industrial Labor Party; and
C happens to be the A.L.P. ticket.
No other political party gets a mention at the top of the Senate ballot paper.
The Senate guide is laid out to indicate that these are the only three options.
This is a travesty of the supposed independence expected of official government publications.
I demand that the Prime Minister have letters of clarification immediately sent to all electors.
It appears that the Government's dirty tricks department has excelled itself.
The Guide favours the A.L.P., not only in Victoria, but in almost every other State.

I will go on to explain where the errors are in this Press release. The honourable member for Deakin built up such a head of steam that he issued a second Press release on the following day, 3 July. In that one he again mentions the different parties in Victoria, group A being the Democratic Labor Party, group B being the Industrial Labor Party and group C being the Australian Labor Party. The Press release states:
No other parties or their letters are mentioned in the Guides.

The honourable member for Deakin, through this Press release based on misinformation, has launched an attack on the independence of the Electoral Commission which deserves close examination. I have the advertisement which was placed by the Electoral Commission in newspapers throughout not only the electorate of Deakin and those electorates in the Melbourne metropolitan area but also all the electorates in Australia. In no way could this ballot paper be alleged to be biased towards the Australian Labor Party. The honourable member for Deakin, in his Press release of 2 July, states:
The Senate guide is laid out to indicate that these are the only three options.

By that, he is referring to groups A, B and C. The honourable member for Deakin obviously had failed even to bother to read the text of the advertisement. I will quote the text of the advertisement which gave instructions for voting for the Senate. It states:
The simplest way to vote is to use the top part. Just place the single number 1 in the box of the party or group you prefer.

But if you want to chose your own Senate candidates, you can vote in the bottom part below the black line. To do this, you must put the number 1 in the box of your first choice candidate, then the number 2 in the box beside your second choice, then the number 3 in the box beside your third choice and so on until you have numbered every box in the bottom part of your white ballot paper.
Your ballot paper may have more boxes than this sample.
I emphasise that it states:
Your ballot paper may have more boxes than this sample.

The Australian Electoral Commission simply used this demonstration ballot paper as a standard for all of its advertisements throughout Australia. The allegation by the honourable member for Deakin that this was a bias towards the Australian Labor Party was simply a cheap publicity stunt to try to get a few column inches in the midst of an election campaign. In the last sentence of his Press release of 2 July, the honourable member for Deakin states:
The Guide favours the A.L.P. not only in Victoria, but in almost every other State.

Not only did the honourable member for Deakin seek to cast aspersions on the Electoral Commission, but he failed even to study the draw for positions for the Senate throughout Australia. The honourable member for Deakin alleged that the Australian Labor Party was successful in gaining the A, B or C group in most of the States. I took the trouble to obtain the details and in fact the Labor Party obtained group K in New South Wales, was lucky enough to get group F in Queensland, obtained group G in South Australia and group F in Western Australia, in addition to group C in Tasmania.

So the suggestion of the honourable member for Deakin that the Labor Party gained from these advertisements was simply a fabrication of his own vivid imagination. Yet he went to the trouble of alleging that the Australian Electoral Commission was somehow part of the Government's dirty tricks department. That is a scurrilous attack on independent appointees to the Electoral Commission and he should have had the courage to withdraw and apologise to the Electoral Commission. Instead, he issued a further Press statement on 8 July. He did not have the courage to admit that he was wrong. He went on to state that another set of guides were misleading in that they provided misleading information for the House of Representatives. The simple point I wish to make is that the honourable member for Deakin was unlucky enough to draw the fifth place on the ballot paper in Deakin. As the standard advertisement which the Electoral Commission had run throughout Australia showed only four candidates, the honourable member for Deakin thought this was a conspiracy against him. His Press statement of 8 July states:
Half of the seats for the House of Representatives are being contested by five or more candidates.
The advertisements and the guides discriminate against candidates placed fifth or sixth or lower.

The honourable member's claim that half of the seats for the House of Representatives had five or more candidates was another figment of his imagination. I have gone to the trouble of going through all of the 148 electorates throughout Australia for the House of Representatives. There were only 48 electorates in which there were five or more candidates-not more than 74, as the honourable member for Deakin suggested, but only 48. Having been lucky enough to obtain an engineering degree, I am a bit embarrassed to find out that the honourable member for Deakin, a fellow engineer, has made the basic arithmetic mistake of thinking that 48 is equal to 74.

TALK.START.PARA: —He's a very successful engineer, too.

—I am very grateful to the honourable member for North Sydney for paying me that compliment. The other point I wish to make before I conclude is simply to express my concern about the large increase in the number of section votes in my electorate of Dobell. In the 1984 election, only 67 section votes were cast. In the latest election, 701 section votes were cast. I would like to believe that that is the result of the Electoral Commission staff encouraging citizens to know their rights and to know that they are entitled to a section vote if their name is not on the roll. But what I am concerned about is that I suspect that a very large number of citizens have had their names removed from the electoral roll between the 1984 and 1987 election campaigns. It is my hope that the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters will be able to investigate these and other matters. As the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) is present in this chamber, I am sure that he will ensure that these matters are thoroughly investigated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WEST
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to reply to the speakers who have participated in the debate and to run over quickly some of the key aspects, policies and numbers concerning what is being done in the new Department of Administrative Services. A number of other portfolios and a range of common services were brought together in the new Department. I indicate my wish-and it is the wish of the Government and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-to conduct a pretty fundamental reappraisal of the provision of common services to government agencies by the new Department.

SPEECH.PARA: The three criteria I will be using are, firstly, the extent to which the central provision of services by individual agencies is necessary, as against just the central setting of standards; secondly, the extent to which any service provided by a central public authority should be in competition with the private sector; and, thirdly, the extent and method of application of the user pays principle for partial or full cost recovery or cost recovery on a full profit-making basis.

I will refer in a moment to some sweeping changes that I have already made to the Transport and Storage Division of the Department-it is now called the Transport and Storage Group-which basically means that the division now runs along corporate lines. To an extent it allows partial competition in a wide-ranging number of areas. I will have more to say about that in the Parliament if I get the opportunity over the next few days.

The assessment of the criteria I have just mentioned regarding the future provision of common services will achieve diverse results as we sequentially address the different common services. I have already mentioned transport and storage. For instance, competition will not be allowed in the supply to entitlees of cars with drivers or in the provision to departments of cars without drivers, but it will be allowed in the area of car with driver services for public servants-enabling competition with taxis and hire cars-and in the movement and storage of goods except in high security areas.

We will be removing the average staffing level (ASL) limits of the division and effecting full cost recovery which will now include recouping the cost of capital. We will allow the new Transport and Storage Group to proceed and to be managed along business lines so that it will be able to retain in a trust account the funds that it might generate from the rationalisation of its property holdings, the sale of cars and so on. It will apply charges across the different departments on the basis of full cost recovery which will include a return to government on the cost of capital deployed. Many changes have been made and perhaps I will have the opportunity to explain them in more detail at a later date.

I have mentioned that I have already achieved some of these measures but that does not mean privatisation or a sell-off; it means efficiency and competition. That is the approach I will be adopting. I will be producing for the Government and Cabinet a paper which will outline the principles which we might apply for the provision of common services. We will then proceed, as I have with transport and storage, to address different areas such as design, construction and property management on a case by case basis. We are certainly not proposing full and open competition, the removal of ASLs in all areas and even full cost recovery in all areas. We will look at all of them, as was done with transport and storage, on a case by case basis.

We are now running a very large Department of Administrative Services. It has the construction groups from the old Department of Housing and Construction, all property management-both overseas and domestic-and, as I have mentioned, transport and storage. It also has surveying and mapping, the Australian Protective Service, purchases and sales, the Commonwealth Bureau of Meteorology, the Australian Valuation Office from the Department of the Treasury, Australian Archives, the Parliamentary and Ministerial Staff and Services Division of the old Department of the Special Minister of State, authorities and commissions such as the Australian Electoral Commission and the Parliament House Construction Authority, the Commonwealth Grants Commission and media groups in the National Media Liaison Service. Basically that adds up to a budget which provides for total appropriations of some $2.25 billion to the portfolio, which is an increase of around 25 per cent on the 1986-87 expenditure. As I have just mentioned, the Department covers many areas now amalgamated into one area.

The revenue to be generated in 1987-88 is estimated to be something like $482m, excluding the special assets sales which we hope will realise about $1 billion. Key components of this sales program are the revenue which is expected from the rationalisation of the Tokyo embassy complex and also the sale of the Commonwealth office blocks at Chifley Square in Sydney and in Melbourne. Net Budget outlays take into account the fact that expenditure and income will be approximately $1.758 billion.

I have talked a little about the machinery of government changes, which really involves common services, construction, property and all of the other areas I have mentioned and the way that has affected the Department of Administrative Services. As a result of that reorganisation process, there will be a staff saving over two years of 750 on the ASL, 375 of which will be achieved by the conclusion of 1987-88. In other words, by the end of June 1988, the staff saving will be approximately 750 although the ASL will be down by only 375. The Department will have approximately 750 fewer staff members than when it took on these new divisions. This Department will be meeting the assurances that the Prime Minister gave when he announced the machinery of government changes.

I will quickly mention a few issues and pro- jects in the property development area. In 1987-88 we will be providing $52m for civil land acquisition. A major element of the civil program is an allocation of $15m for the continuing acquisition of properties for the second Sydney Airport site at Badgerys Creek and $1.5m for site acquisition for Commonwealth offices at Logan City, Queensland. I also got Budget approval for the construction of a $143.5m project of 60,000 square metres of planned office accommodation in Melbourne. We are selling the old centre and building a new one. Similarly, in Sydney the 50,000 square metre project at the block bounded by Pitt, Hay, Parker and Barlow Streets in the Haymarket is a $120m Commonwealth development. That will supersede Chifley Square, after it is sold, as the main Commonwealth centre in Sydney.

We will also refurbish the Edmund Barton Offices in Canberra, which will cost $25m. I have Cabinet approval for that project. We will get all of the asbestos out of that building. I think that is a very worthwhile project. Some $15.3m is allocated for new Commonwealth offices at Frankston and Oakleigh. We will be extending existing offices in places such as Ipswich, having allocated $5m for a major extension. Despite the constraints of the public sector borrowing decisions taken by the Government, because of the work that is already in the pipeline, we have an increase of about 19 per cent in the public works program for 1987-88. All up, it will total about $1,385.7m, including the civil works program of $195m and the defence program of $269.7m. So, $1,385m covers all civil works, all defence fitouts, repairs and maintenance in the departments, authorities and Commonwealth instrumentalities.

I have already informed the Parliament that the Bureau of Meteorology has been given an extra $7.5m over several years to upgrade its severe weather warning systems. I have already mentioned transport and storage. The Australian Government Analytical Laboratories will go into its second year of the cost recovery program and revenue will be boosted by around $6.5m. Overall it is a fairly exciting picture in the new Department of Administrative Services.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you mean that?
—A lot is happening. It is starting to do things that involve looking at efficiency, running government businesses like corporations and effecting full cost recovery. These things are on the agenda.
—What's on the privatisation agenda in your Department?

—I am glad the honourable member raised that issue because efficiency and competition do not necessarily mean selling off or privatisation. What I aim to do particularly in the transport and storage areas and in other areas such as I have flagged which will be given attention is to give the private sector plenty of what it has always asked for: competition. I shall prove just how efficient and competitive a division of a federal government department can be. My view is that as I do that we will come out on top of many of the organisations that those opposite applaud in the private sector. We will see just how good the public sector can be.

SPEECH.PARA: Vociferous Opposition members have suddenly found their tongues. Therefore, I draw attention to the fact that Opposition members were so interested in the debates on the estimates of the Department of Administrative Services that they put up only one speaker. I conclude my remarks, having not been given very much to answer in the debate, apart from what was contained in the remarks of the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar), whose points I shall now address. It is a pity that Opposition members who have found their tongues did not rise to their feet during the debate and put forward some of their views. I can only conclude that they are as pathetic in debate in committee as they are at Question Time every day of the week.

The honourable member for Wide Bay, who is one of the best back bench members in the Opposition-he would beat many of the members who are now taking up space on the Opposition front bench-raised the important issue of the Government's attitude to the Public Works Committee. Therefore, in conclusion I shall deal with the only salient point that arose from the Opposition's ranks. He mentioned referrals to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works. I assure the honourable member for Wide Bay and the Committee that I want the client departments to comply with the requirements of the Public Works Committee Act to the maximum extent possible. I personally have great respect for the Committee, as does the honourable member for Wide Bay. As an example of that respect, the Government and I have ensured that the new instalment purchase projects for new office buildings, some of which I referred to earlier, if over $6m will now be referred to the Public Works Committee. I assure the honourable member for Wide Bay that the Government's policy is that projects worth $6m plus, both civil and defence, wherever possible are referred to the Public Works Committee. However, honourable members should understand that under the Act defence equipment purchasing is not necessarily referable to that Committee, nor ought it to be. There will always be the occasional project, particularly defence project, which has Budget funding approval and which can be legitimately exempted, on the grounds of urgency, from referral to the Public Works Committee.

The Department of Administrative Services, while I have ministerial responsibility, will be examining the big issues regarding the provision of common services to government departments. At this point the actions we have taken to weld together a very large number of divisions from six or seven former departments is working very well indeed.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time that is available to me I wish to make some general observations about East-West security relations. The first thing I want to say, which is very obvious, is that security interests are globally interdependent. There is a tendency to focus on negotiations between the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Social Republics and on tensions between the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) and the Warsaw Pact countries. But over the last two decades the centre of gravity of international affairs has moved from the NATO-Warsaw Pact area to the Pacific region. What happens in the Pacific region, for example, in the Philippines, affects security interests in Europe just as what happens in Europe can affect security interests of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point I wish to make is that it is said that we have had a peaceful globe since World War II. We have in the sense that there has been no world war, yet on one estimate the many wars that have been fought since 1945 have accounted for 35 million lives. Almost without exception, these wars have been fought in Third World countries such as Afghanistan and Africa. The irony is that it is likely that future wars which involve the interests of the West, even if the West itself is not directly a participant through Western countries, are likely to be fought in Third World countries where Western military strategic thinking and Western capabilities lie very much on the periphery. We have not focused our attention on what our capabilities and strategic thinking should be with regard to wars, conflicts in Third World countries, and how we may respond, as we may have to.

The third thing that needs to be said is that crucially the security of the West depends on its economic strength and technical innovation. Without the continued growth in Western economies and technologies which underpin our military and defensive capabilities, our security is placed at risk. This is why the current protectionist sentiment in the United States and the Bills presently before the conference between the United States Senate and its House of Representatives are so dangerous. The last thing we need is the erection of trade barriers by the United States as inevitably the economies of other countries will be hurt and the likelihood is that the protectionist sentiment will emerge in other developed economies. The process of international `beggar thy neighbour' through protectionism is a formula for economic stagnation with potentially ruinous consequences for some countries, especially developing countries.

Just as security is globally interdependent, so is the economic strength and hence the security of the West affected by what takes place in developing countries. This is why Third World debt is, and will remain, such an important issue. The burden of debt which has been incurred by countries such as Mexico, which owes $US108 billion, Argentina $50 billion and Brazil $106 billion, together with a number of African countries and others, is such as to present immense problems in debt servicing and even greater problems in repayment of what has been borrowed. It presents to those countries a burden on the growth of their national economies.

One of the major issues which now face the West and developing countries is how to manage the debt problem. It seems inevitable that a greater writing off of debt will have to take place, just as it is inevitable that there will have to be a greater rescheduling of debt and interest repayments. To say this is but a recognition of the economic incapacity of a number of countries to repay the debt they have incurred. The reasons why they are unable to do so and the reasons why the debts were incurred are, to an extent, irrelevant. One has to look at the economic reality. It is in all our interests that the countries which are presently burdened by high levels of debt should become economically viable, since we live in a world whose economies are economically interrelated.

I would like to say something about Mr Gorbachev, the General Secretary to the Communist Party of the Soviet Union. He is the most astute, sophisticated and innovative leader of Russia since Lenin, with a talent for negotiations and skills as a publicist and a propagandist for himself and the Soviet Union of a very high order. It is too early to attempt any final assessment of his likely effects on his own country, on the Communist Party in his own country or on international relations, but some things can be said of him. Plainly, he realises the depth of economic failure and stagnation in the Soviet Union. He realises that the strength and political power of the Soviet Union depend almost exclusively on its military capabilities and that as an economic model or a source of political inspiration it has failed. This means-and he has addressed this issue with great energy-economic reform within the Soviet Union coupled, as we have seen, with some signs of improvement in the Soviet system; for example, the release of some of many, but only some of many, political prisoners. In the Berlin communique which was issued a few days ago at a meeting of the International Democrat Union which I attended this was said of Gorbachev and what might be called the `new Russia':

. . . but until all prisoners of conscience are released, and steps are taken to guarantee that basic human rights are observed within the Soviet Union and especially in Soviet prisons and mental hospitals, the situation will remain unsatisfactory.

I add to those comments the words `deeply unsatisfactory and still deeply wrong'. There is no evidence of any change of commitment to the Soviet system. Some people believe that such a change exists. Plainly, from what Mr Gorbachev has said it does not exist. He is not talking about democratic pluralism; he is talking of reform within a Marxist-Leninist context. We should never forget that. The test of his intentions will lie in his actions and not in his words.

In foreign affairs he is a far more innovative leader and a far more challenging negotiator than any other we have seen. His skills have been shown in the arms negotiations with the United States, both in the meeting with President Reagan and later, and with the conclusion of the intermediate range nuclear forces agreement, which has not been concluded but is likely to be concluded, I believe, before the end of the year, we will be further tested. The resolution and political skills of the West will be further tested in the complex of negotiations in main nuclear weapon systems, chemical weapons and conventional forces.

We must not become mesmerised by nuclear weapons negotiations, because at the same time as those negotiations continue it is crucial that there be negotiations to reduce Soviet superiority in conventional forces. Let me give just one example. In Europe the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation has 17,730 main battle tanks at its disposal. The Warsaw Pact countries have 50,000. Nor should we be beguiled into thinking that disarmament agreements are good in themselves or that disarmament is, in itself, a desirable objective. Everything depends on the terms of the agreement and on the balance of forces achieved. It is in mutually verifiable and balanced reductions in forces that the safe path in negotiation lies. The unsafe path is to seize upon agreements for the sake of having an agreement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my remarks tonight to the issues of trade. For almost three decades since World War II, the Liberal and National parties were in government in this country. While they governed, their policies were responsible for Australia slipping from eighth to twenty-third in world exporting rankings. Australia lost ground in almost every major overseas market, including Japan, the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN) and the Western Pacific. The people of Australia should never forget this and they should never forget that the paralysis of will of the Liberal and National parties and their lack of capacity to develop policies to meet the challenges of international trade are still evident. I do not know what it is that prevents the Opposition from coming to grips with the realities of the challenges that face Australian exporters. It may simply be lack of ability, laziness or lack of leadership. Even so, given the paucity of new ideas and proposals from the Opposition, I do not believe its contribution to this debate will be constructive or helpful to Australia's exporters.

SPEECH.PARA: The top priorities of the Hawke Government have been, firstly, to arrest Australia's slide in trade performance under the previous Liberal-National Government and, secondly, to put in place machinery and policies which will enable a dramatic improvement in Australia's foreign trade performance. The Hawke Government has established the Australian Trade Commission. It has actively sought out the views of industry leaders in agriculture, mining, high technology, manufactures and services. It has aggressively encouraged the development of the Australian Trade Commission to be an organisation of flexibility and independence with the ability to provide early warning of international market trends and to seek out and develop new market opportunities. Above all, the Hawke Government has developed economic policies capable of successfully adjusting to the ever-changing international economic circumstances whilst, at the same time, laying the foundations for structural change within the Australian domestic economy. Indeed, from the time the Hawke Government was first elected it recognised that it was essential to develop integrated industry and economic policies if Australia's future well-being was to be assured.

Earlier today the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy) made a statement to the House on the outcome of his recent visit to the United States of America, Canada, Brazil, Argentina and Uruguay. I will comment on Australia's present trade difficulties with the United States shortly. I now make some observations regarding the challenges and opportunities for trade that Australia faces with the Pacific region. It has often been said that the Asian Pacific region is now the most economically vibrant region in the world. Although the region includes the world's two major economic powers in the United States of America and Japan, it also includes many small island states in the central and South Pacific. As a Pacific region nation, it is essential therefore that Australia continue to focus more and more on our Pacific neighbours. The importance of developing stronger socio-economic ties with the countries of the central and South Pacific cannot be underestimated. One way we can do this is by fostering trade between Australia and these countries. These new opportunities must not be missed.

Australia's trade with Papua New Guinea deserves the close attention of the Federal Government. Last year total two-way trade between Australia and the western Pacific region amounted to more than $32 billion, including nearly $780m with Papua New Guinea. Total two-way trade with countries of the South Pacific Forum amounted to just over $400m. Regional Australia has a vital role to perform in developing an awareness in industry that exports are the arteries of our national economic health.

North Queensland is playing a vital role developing new trade links between Papua New Guinea and Australia. Honourable members will be interested to know that in 1985-86 total exports from north Queensland seaports and airports exceeded $3.4 billion and, given current annual growth rates, will probably exceed $4 billion this year. As an exporting region with a population of almost 500,000 people, north Queensland contributes over 47 per cent of Queensland's total exports, ranking it ahead of South Australia, southern Queensland, central Queensland and Tasmania. Major export items include coal, mineral sands, bauxite, kaolin, gold, marble, sugar, maize, wheat, beef, frozen prawns, fruit and vegetables, tea, dairy products, copper products, nickel briquettes, cement, industrial alcohol, molasses and fabricated steel.

Exports from north Queensland to Papua New Guinea have experienced a marked increase since mid-1986-due almost entirely to barges and small-deck ships operating out of Townsville. These vessels regularly service the Ok Tedi mining project via the Fly River port of Kiunga, Port Moresby and less frequently Lae and other island ports. Since the commencement of the new shipping service by the Townsville company of Curtain Brothers the value of exports into Papua New Guinea from Townsville exceeds $30m.

Dr Doug Hartley of the Townsville office of Austrade-established by the former Minister for Trade, Minister Bowen-has organised a trade mission from Townsville to Papua New Guinea from 12 October to 23 October this year. A 56-page Townsville export directory specifically dealing with Papua New Guinea is being printed this week. The Austrade office in Townsville is also actively promoting two-way trade to open up opportunities for Papua New Guinea industry to sell products to north Queensland. Timber, coffee, seafood and wood products are possible exports from Papua New Guinea to Townsville.

Business in Townsville is enthusiastic to develop trade with Papua New Guinea. Given aggressive and co-ordinated export marketing, annual exports into Papua New Guinea and neighbouring islands from north Queensland could well exceed $100m per annum within four years. Three words sum up the motivation of north Queensland exporters-sell, sell sell. The people of north Queensland ensure that the quality of their product is better than that of anyone else; the next step is to go out and find the markets and sell.

I now turn to Australia's trade relations with the United States of America. Australia and the United States have enjoyed a long and stable trading relationship. For the United States, it has been an extremely beneficial trading relationship. The balance of trade runs two to one in favour of the United States. In 1986 the United States sold goods valued at $US5.6 billion to Australia, and imported from Australia more than $US2.9 billion in goods.

In May this year Guy Barnett of Taft, Stettinius and Hollister, a Washington firm, prepared a paper entitled `Summary of Current issues Impacting on United States/Australia Trade'. He made a number of important and accurate observations. First, he noted that Australia was the ninth ranking-in size-United States export market in 1985. Sales to the United States accounted for 10 per cent of Australia's exports in 1985-86. Major Australian exports include beef, petroleum, sugar, metal ores, wool, fish, uranium, iron and steel, metals and a range of manufactures. Australia supplied less than one per cent of United States imports in 1986. In 1985-86 the United States accounted for 21 per cent of Australia's imports. In 1986, 77 per cent of United States exports to Australia were cleared by Customs at non-protective rates of duty; that is, 5 per cent or less. Over 800 United States companies have established a presence in Australia, with the stock of investment being estimated at $US9 billion.

The United States farm legislation-that is, the Food Security Act of 1985-introduced a new element of subsidised competition on world agricultural markets, and this has caused severe disruption and depressed world market prices, particularly for wheat, cotton, rice and feed grains. The system of `marketing loans' for cotton and rice and the export enhancement program-that is, the subsidisation of exports for wheat-have been particularly detrimental to world prices and to Australia's export earnings. Australia is competing in trade in agriculture with countries that subsidise heavily-for example, those of the European Economic Community, the United States and Japan. The European Economic Community's common agricultural policy has imposed tremendous burdens on the Australian economy. The cost of this policy to Australian rural exports has been estimated at over $1 billion per year.

The two trade Bills presently before Congress are protectionist and if passed and put into effect they would hurt Australia's exports to the United States-particularly sugar, meat and wool. Given the increase in protectionism in the current United States Congress, Australians must be willing to protect their own interests-for no one else will. We have in Washington one of our most competent and experienced diplomats, Mr John McCarthy, who is responsible for promoting the trade interests of Australia with congressmen and senior American trade officials. He is there to ensure there is no misunderstanding on the part of our American friends of the gravity of any move by Congress that would deliberately hurt Australia's export trade with the United States.

The process of reform of the international trade system must be pursued by Australia. We must be creative and tenacious on the question of reform of agricultural domestic trade policies. In this regard the efforts of the former Minister for Trade, Mr Dawkins, deserve the enduring gratitude of every Australian. In August 1986 he brought together 13 countries which shared Australia's interest to establish the so-called Cairns group of fair traders in agriculture. This group, chaired by Australia, has succeeded in ensuring that agricultural issues will never again be side-lined in the process of reforming the world trading system. The group includes Brazil, Argentina, Canada and New Zealand. Four of the six ASEAN countries are members of the Cairns group, and this has helped establish new lines of communication and co-operation with ASEAN. The Cairns group played a decisive role in urging the European Economic Community to move more quickly to unravel its elaborate system of farm subsidies. Japan, too, has been forced to acknowledge that it cannot continue for long with its protective barriers against agricultural imports.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested in the remarks of the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), particularly those in relation to the need to free up trade and on the influence of trade in the well-being of the nations of the South Pacific. I was particularly interested in the part of his speech relating to Papua New Guinea because I wanted to bring to the attention of the Committee this evening some of the developments within our immediate region which are causing me a very great deal of concern and which I suggest should be causing the Government a very great deal of concern. I am particularly sorry to notice that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) is not in the chamber this evening while his estimates are being discussed.

SPEECH.PARA: I start with the issue of Papua New Guinea because, as the honourable member for Herbert has already outlined to the Committee, that country has particular associations with Australia. There are traditional relations going back many years now and we have accepted a particular responsibility over many years in our relations with Papua New Guinea. I received very recently a copy of a newspaper printed in Papua New Guinea which disturbed me greatly. It reinforced reports that have been increasingly evident in our media about the problems that are occurring in that country in relation to the treatment of expatriates and what appears to be a breakdown of law and order.

I do not think it should ever be forgotten that what happens in Papua New Guinea is of extreme importance to this country. I was pleased to see the development of a better relationship between Papua New Guinea and Indonesia because, of course, that has significant political effects in Australia. But I must say that I am becoming increasingly concerned that Australian influence in Papua New Guinea seems to be diminishing. I am also concerned about some other developments in that country, such as, as I said, the treatment of expatriates and that country's looking outward to other sources of supply. These are warning signs of which I suggest the Government should take very close notice, and I have not seen any evidence from this Government so far of its capacity or preparedness to deal with those potential problems, or even its awareness of them.

Looking around the South Pacific generally, it is of concern to me that, whilst this Government is paying lip service to having a strong commitment to the area and whilst there is no doubt that officials from various departments have travelled around the South Pacific, there is also no doubt that at a senior political level it has been almost totally ignored by the present Government. There are developments in the area which must cause concern to all Australians. We all know that Australia is vitally placed, both strategically and economically, to play a very major role. Obviously we do not want to become an overbearing Big Brother. On the other hand, we do not want to be so timid in our relationships with the area that we do not take those positive steps we should as a nation in our situation, which would do something to dampen down some of those strategic wobbles which appear to be growing in the area.

I only have to mention New Caledonia to highlight an area which has the potential for some real problems, both to its immediate neighbours and, of course, to Australia. The problems in New Caledonia have already had their flow-on effects in our relations with France, and obviously we have been taking a very consistent attitude towards France's continued testing in the South Pacific. But we should not allow that to stand totally in the way of effective liaison with France in dealing with the problems of emergent countries such as the, in my view, quite legitimate wishes of many of the people of New Caledonia.

Vanuatu is another area that has the potential to cause Australia some problems. We now know that Father Lini's unfortunate sickness earlier this year has led to his decision not to continue, as I understand it, in the long term in a political sense in Vanuatu, but there are also developments there which have caused some concern. Particularly we remember the midnight flight to New Zealand of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) when the question of Libyan involvement was raised, and the problems that that overly dramatic gesture raised in our relations with Vanuatu. That is an example of an overreaction by the Minister to a situation which needed some calm political thought rather than a media publicity gesture-which really appeared to be the sole reason at least that one heard about in relation to that particular matter.

We all know that the problems of Fiji are very much with us at present. I believe that the Government has not been well advised in relation to the developments within Fiji. People holidaying in the Fijian islands who returned to Australia some time before the first coup took place spoke quite openly about the potential for a coup such as occurred with Colonel Rabuka. We all know the unhappy sequel to that event. At this stage, of course, the situation in Fiji is extremely fluid. I hope that the reporting that the Government is getting at this stage places it in a better position than obviously it was at the start of the events.

I should like to mention also, in relation to the particular area in which we live, the effect of New Zealand's foreign policy and its capacity to add to what I regard as the strategic decline in the South Pacific area generally. There is no doubt that the effective New Zealand break with ANZUS has added yet another factor to those elements which are combining to influence actions in the South Pacific. Add to those the increased interest of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics in the area and the reports of Libyan involvement and the situation is markedly different from anything which has confronted this country since the Second World War. It is not good enough for the Government to pay simple lip service to its responsibilities in this area.

As I mentioned at the time it was proposed, I believe that the Government's pursuit of the nuclear free zone proposal has in fact added another factor to the instability of the region, because it has not solved the problems; it has not stopped France from continuing to test. It certainly has, as I said, added yet another factor to these changes within the region which may well have very significant effects on Australia's secure environment. I should like to see more than just the officials of the various ministries concerned being fully involved in the region. I believe they are; I believe a lot of departmental officers are doing very good jobs in the various states of the South Pacific. I do not think enough senior political attention has been paid by this Government to our responsibilities as a nation towards this area of the world.

It is not good enough for the Prime Minister to appear at a Pacific Forum meeting or for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to have one trip around the place in four years of government. We need to have a succession of Ministers going into the area on a continuing basis to prove to those microstates, and the larger ones, that we are genuine in our concern for their well-being, that we are genuine in our efforts to develop their economies and that we are genuine in our commitment to producing a stable and secure region, not only for them but for us. Unfortunately, there has not been any indication of that senior political will within the Government, and I believe it is a very great mark against the performance of the present Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade that he has allowed that situation to occur.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the time allocated to me to discuss the proposed expenditure under the portfolio of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, I shall of necessity concentrate on only a few issues. In the Budget Papers under discussion, Australia's contributions to international organisations are listed. It is becoming increasingly fashionable in certain quarters in Australia and overseas to criticise international organisations, especially United Nations bodies such as the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO). I have no doubt that many will argue for a downgrading of our role in UNESCO. Some might even suggest that we withdraw altogether from that body.

SPEECH.PARA: Although understanding the reasons, I was disappointed that our ambassador to UNESCO was recently withdrawn. One of UNESCO's major achievements has been the establishment of a world forum for the discussion of global problems, particularly in the fields of education, science and culture. Australia has profited from UNESCO by contributing to solutions to a wide range of problems of interest to Australian departments, professional bodies and non-government organisations. In particular, Australia has benefited by building bridges within the Asian-Pacific region, which has helped to overcome our geographic isolation and generally furthered our foreign policy interests.

UNESCO has 157 member states in its network of activities radiating from the Paris headquarters and, from UNESCO regional offices in places such as Bangkok, Jakarta and Apia in Western Samoa in the agency's Asian-Pacific region, helps improve the lives of people at all levels. UNESCO is the only international agency capable of providing the mechanism for such a wide variety of practical programs which promote peace, security and collaboration among nations in the fields of education, science, culture and communications and social sciences.

Each year Australia's contribution is 1.64 per cent of the total UNESCO budget. In 1987 this represents $4.3m. The operating budget of the Australian National Commission for UNESCO-its guiding body-is about $160,000 annually. I might say that I am a member of that Commission. The return to Australia can be measured both directly and indirectly by our participation in UNESCO-sponsored seminars, training workshops and consultancies. Just recently there has been the opportunity for Australian consultants in electronics and robotics to work for UNESCO in their specialised fields in Singapore and Thailand.

Around 250 Australian academics and industry people are paid for by UNESCO, Paris, each year to contribute to meetings, to exchange state-of-the-art technical information and to do research and consultancy work world-wide, and particularly in the Asia-Pacific area. The gains are obvious in terms of acquired expertise which later results in benefits to Australian education and industry and, indeed, frequently opens markets for Australian products. Australia also benefits as a signatory to UNESCO conventions such as the World Heritage Convention and UNESCO's international network of biosphere reserves. Such well-founded projects protect natural and cultural sites and unique animals and plants in Australia and around the world, for the benefit of future generations of humanity. The Australian section of UNESCO's APPEAL program-the Asia-Pacific program of education for all-which is to be launched in Canberra on 20 November, aims to improve vastly literacy throughout our area. Overall, the APPEAL program seeks to achieve complete world literacy by the year 2000.

Australia was one of the original signatories at the formation of UNESCO in 1946. Its National Commission was founded in 1947 by a decision of Federal Cabinet. Today the 16-member Commission, appointed in an honorary capacity for a three-year term, has, among its various duties, the duty to advise the Government on the effectiveness of Australia's participation in UNESCO programs and to suggest ways to overcome any deficiencies or shortfalls. The National Commission has two regular publications-a newsletter and a quarterly review-which detail UNESCO activities in Australia and the Asia-Pacific region and provide a forum for discussion about UNESCO and its work.

The Australian secretariat for UNESCO is based in Canberra and is provided by the Department of Employment, Education and Training. The specialist officers of the secretariat provide a working link between the UNESCO National Commission, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Australian permanent delegation to UNESCO in Paris and UNESCO headquarters in Paris. The secretariat is responsible for circulating reports, publications and technical material produced by UNESCO for assisting Australians contributing to the work of UNESCO and for assisting with the organisation of UNESCO activities, particularly the increasing number of projects directed to the Asia-Pacific part of the world. The Hon. E. G. Whitlam represents Australia on UNESCO's executive board, which is currently conducting its 127th session in Paris. Plans for UNESCO's major activities for the next two years will be formulated at the Paris general conference. Australia should continue its contribution to the work of this international agency while also striving to improve further and streamline the overall UNESCO operation.

With the expansion of the former Department of Foreign Affairs to cover trade, I hope that more attention will be given to our relationship with India. I listened with interest to what other speakers in this debate had to say about our relationships with various countries. Having visited India several times in recent years, I must say that our diplomatic and trade staff in the New Delhi and Bombay posts are the most dedicated that I have seen anywhere. There have been some recent rumours that the Consulate-General in Bombay may close. I personally believe that this would be a great tragedy.

India is a great untapped market for Australia. It amazes me that Australian business people fly over and view India from thousands of feet on their way to and from a market in Europe that is, to all intents and purposes, closed to us. I know that this is a time of economic restraint, but we should consider spending more money on our posts in India. We should have more people involved in trade there. India is a huge potential market for Australia. Not only is there a huge domestic market there, but also there is great potential for export to the rest of Asia and Africa. I do not think India would be a market for our manufactured goods, but we should be looking at joint ventures. If we had, say, a component of only 10 per cent of a finished product on the Indian market, this would be better than perhaps 100 per cent of the finished product on, say, the Malaysian market.

There are many advantages in trading with India, not the least being that both countries are English-speaking. The business community in Australia is often very critical of the Government, but I think the business community has a lot to answer for in that it is not developing trading contacts with India. Japan, Canada and even Denmark are leaving us far behind in this respect. Recently when I was in India I met a representative of a company from Denmark who was selling windmills to India. When I questioned him, he said, `Do you have any idea of how many windmills there are in India?'. We would have a huge market if we manufactured only one component of each windmill sold in India. There is also great potential to develop scientific and technological links between the two countries. Naturally, I would also like to see more cultural links with India. The relationship between India and Australia is good but it could, with an effort, be even better, to the mutual benefit of both countries.

In the minute or so that I have left, I would like to mention briefly our new embassy building in Beijing. Last week I had the privilege to be in Beijing and, because of my role on the Standing Committee on Public Works, I took the opportunity to inspect progress on the work of the new embassy building. This work was approved in September 1984 after being referred to the Public Works Committee in April of that year. The cost at that time was estimated at $33.8m. Work is only now commencing and the cost, for various reasons, has risen to over $60m. The Australian Embassy in Beijing performs a broad range of functions under conditions which, it could be argued, are among the most difficult of any of our diplomatic missions and which are undoubtedly more difficult than those at any post of comparable importance in policy terms. The building which is under construction is architecturally very pleasing. But, more important, it will give to the staff representing Australia in the People's Republic of China acceptable working and living conditions. I hope that the work on this important building progresses speedily.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few minutes available to me I want to say a few things about the estimates of the Department of Foreign Afairs and Trade. I find it rather appalling that the Government treats this place with such contempt. I have long been concerned about the way in which these Estimates debates are conducted. It is quite apparent from the fact that a very junior Minister is at the table that there is no proper consideration of Estimates in the House of Representatives. We all know that the Australian Labor Party, through its Constitutional Commission, wants to destroy the effective power of the Senate. It is doing that because it is only in the Senate at the moment that there is any effective scrutiny of the expenditure of individual departments. While I commend the public servants who sit in this place and no doubt take some note of the particular matters that are canvassed, it is the responsibility of Ministers to appear in the House of Representatives and to consider and debate those comments that are canvassed with respect to their individual departments.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that the Government does not favour the idea of having Estimates committees. There is good reason for individual expenditure items to be examined far more closely than the debate at this Committee stage now allows. I am concerned that so many significant errors have been made in a whole range of areas. I do not believe that a proper opportunity has been given to us in this debate to pursue matters in a way which I believe is desirable and necessary.

The first thing I would say about the estimates before us is that I am concerned about the effect on the integrated staff of the former Department of Trade as a result of that Department having been split into four parts. Even Gaul was originally divided into only three parts; yet, the Trade Department has been divided into four separate sections. It is in part the responsibility of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade; in part the responsibility of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce; in part the responsibility of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy; and in part the responsibility of the Minister for Trade Negotiations.

Earlier today I made a few remarks in response to a statement made by the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy). I identified the concern of this side of the Parliament about the general trade war being undertaken between the United States of America and Europe and between the United States and Japan, and the repercussions for Australia. I also made the point that part of my worry is that not enough is being done within Australia, and much of the effort that used to be undertaken by an effective Department of Trade is now being totally negated by the split in the Department, and the fact is that the morale of so many members of that Department is certainly at a low ebb. I am concerned that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) is far more inclined to be engaged in the capital cities of Europe and the United States than he is in the markets and in the market-place, which is where, if he is to be Minister for Trade, his prime responsibility should be.

I repeat my concern that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, as far as I am aware in the time that he has been overseas since his appointment, has not expressed much concern in what are the fundamental matters affecting every Australian, at a time when we have this chronic balance of payments difficulty, when our overseas debt is ballooning and when we must expand our exports and our overseas revenue in order to survive.

I do not accept that the present restructuring of the Department is efficient, and I am particularly concerned that its fragmentation will weaken Australia's export and trading efforts at a time when I believe maximum effort must be given to exports, and not just to manufactured exports, for while we support them we believe our traditional exports still have a major role to play. Those honourable members who read the article by Ross Gittins this morning will know that there has been this year quite a significant increase in the returns from our wool exports. We know of the problems with our mineral and coal exports, and the Government is doing nothing. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) obviously knows very little about those problems. He gave me an answer in the House the other day and said that the problem in the shortfall of oil revenue, as a result of the rundown of the Bass Strait reserves, is going to be countered totally by the increase in the North West Shelf production. He does not comprehend that even if there is an ability to produce that much oil from the North West Shelf-which I doubt-the time factor will not meet the rundown and there will be about a $3 billion shortfall in Commonwealth revenue. That is an illustration of how the split in the Department of Trade is leading Ministers to make major errors in areas which affect Australia's profitability and which will certainly affect our future ability to fund the growth and development of this country.

I do not believe that the general operation of the Department of Foreign Affairs lends itself towards the market-place. I have always believed that individual high commissioners and ambassadors should have prime responsibility in their particular posts, but if the Department of Foreign Affairs is going to assume policy responsibility for overseas trade negotiations, and, through the Minister for Trade Negotiations, undertake that responsibility with only a little back up from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, once again it must understand that the status of Australian Ministers abroad is critical. For example, in Japan a junior Minister has no opportunity to get through to the Minister who will be able to influence the Ministry of International Trade and Industry or the overall policies of the Japanese Government. It is of no use the Government pretending that because it has somebody there, he will get access. He will not get access in the United States or in Europe and certainly not in Japan. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and the departmental officers have to comprehend that the role the traditional trade commissioners played, particularly the senior trade commissioners, was critical not only in the development of Australia's very considerable status as a major trading nation, but also to our reputation in policy formulation. In that respect I believe the Cairns initiative was well worth while, but I am apprehensive that it will not be able to be maintained by a government that has been decimated.

I am very concerned at the way in which this Government is going in the defence area. There were a few brave statements by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) about what we would be able to do in Fiji. But we no longer have an ability to land troops in Fiji if we need to. It was absolute nonsense for there to be some illusion that Australia would be able to send a defence force to Fiji to help Australian tourists if we needed to. The landing ships heavies have largely been put in mothballs in Cairns, and those that are not in mothballs are carrying out surveying operations in conjunction with HMAS Cook. It is not possible for the Australian Services, with the rundown in manpower and the change in the structure of the Defence Force, to undertake their responsibilities in this part of the world.

I have said on other occasions that I am concerned that the Government began with a report which, through Mr Dibb, was hailed as being the solution to all of Australia's defence problems. Progressively through the Dibb report on the Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities, and in the White Paper, there was an expectation that we would have a better defence capacity. That is not so, and today we have in particular a major rundown in defence personnel. None of that has come out in these papers because the Government is refusing to release half the statistics on the people available within our defence forces.

I am told that within the first six months of this year 4,770 service personnel left the Australian Defence Force. In a paper prepared by the Assistant Chief of Defence Force Staff and given to the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) in January of this year, by the Chief of Defence Force Staff, alarming wastage trends were highlighted. Statistics for the first quarter for 1987-88 show actual wastage of 128 against 98 for 1985-86. Among other things, the paper said:
The increased wastage rates are impacting adversely on the Services as increasing resources are diverted into recruiting and training functions to allow increased training rates.
Administrative and other costs are also increasing and experience levels are being diluted.

The Army officer separation rates are of major concern and, particularly so, because of the increasing tend for MAJ/CAP and LT/2LT ranks to separate from the Service. The Army male officer wastage rate for financial year 1985-86 was 9.7% compared with five and 10 year rates of 6.9% and 6.4% respectively.
The high rates experienced by Army in 1985-86 show little sign of abating.

The Royal Australian Navy and the Royal Australian Air Force are experiencing exactly the same problems. The point is that this Government is not doing anything to overcome the wastage rates, because it has not undertaken the necessary measures to reduce the run-off in personnel. Unless there is an urgent inquiry undertaken by the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal into comparable terms and conditions in the bureaucracy and in the private sector, we are not going to be able to offset the problems in personnel. The Government must understand that we, on this side of the House, do not accept that our Defence Force today is in a proper state, simply because the Government has been walking away from its proper responsibility to those members of the armed forces who wear the Queen's uniform in Her Majesty's Australian colours. I think it is critical that in any analysis of these estimates we understand that in defence in particular this Government has failed miserably in its responsibilities to the Australian community.
Sitting suspended from 6.27 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to discuss the estimates of expenditure for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. In that context I want to address myself primarily to the elements of the budget for the Department which deal with Australia's overseas aid program and, in particular, to the statement circulated by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) as Budget Related Paper No. 4.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr McLeay, it may surprise you that some years ago I undertook the preparation of a paper on human rights. I have been a long-standing member of the parliamentary group of Amnesty International. As such, I am very much aware of the emphasis many of us place on what we regard as the fundamental human right of personal freedom. I have worked strongly for prisoners of conscience, those who have been tortured or lost their lives because of their political views.

While preparing my paper on human rights I came across a speech given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade-a very eloquent speech which went into some detail about human rights in the terms in which I understand them. It also posed the question as to what we, as Australians concerned about personal freedoms, were doing about the other aspects of human rights: the right to eat, the right to live and to bring up one's family with dignity; in other words, the right to enjoy a reasonable standard of living and to live in a country where one is able to achieve development and where resources will be available to ensure that the freedoms we regard as fundamental can be enjoyed. In other words, one cannot talk about freedom of the individual unless one is prepared to give people food to put into their stomachs.

That argument put by the Minister was very reasonable and very strong. Yet now, under a Labor Government, we have had one of the most remarkable turnarounds in Australia's history. For the first time the countries which have problems in feeding people, the countries to which all the points the Minister was making so eloquently and so strongly can be applied, are now very poorly supported by Australia. For the first time we have slipped below the international average for aid donor countries. The level of aid this year is expected to drop to 0.36 per cent of gross national product, compared with the forecast international average of 3.8 per cent. That is the information given to us by the Australian Council for Overseas Aid. The foreword to the statement circulated by the Minister is the most remarkable foreword I have ever read. He had this to say about our miserable performance:

Because the growth rate of the Australian economy is expected to be somewhat faster than the increase in aid, as a share of GNP aid is expected to be lower than in 1986-87-0.36% compared to 0.38% last year.

What a remarkable piece of convoluted logic to describe the enormous reduction in real terms in Australia's overseas aid budget. In real terms there has been a 3.4 per cent cut in aid in this year's Budget. Aid is at its lowest level for more than a quarter of a century. All of this has happened under a Labor Government. Recently I heard a statement about our present relationships with countries overseas. The view was put that in the context of Australia's economic difficulties charity ought to begin at home. But somebody put to me more recently a more accurate statement of that euphemism which is often used as a basis for reducing overseas aid. It was this: charity may begin at home but it should not end there.

Recognising that we have problems in Australia and that we need to take a critical look at our own levels of expenditure, we still have to have priorities. In the region in which we live as a nation-the Pacific, South East Asia-we have a special responsibility. I draw the attention of honourable members to the speech made earlier by the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), who spoke about possible future problems in our region vis-a-vis Papua New Guinea. Whilst Papua New Guinea will remain the largest recipient of Australia's overseas aid, nevertheless overall aid to that country will continue to contract. The Minister's statement made the following point:
The level of Australian aid to Papua New Guinea, which has been steadily declining for some time, is expected to continue to fall in 1987-88.

Assistance to the rest of the South Pacific region will also fall slightly in 1987-88, reflecting the fact that expenditure in 1986-87 was inflated by the provision of a once only payment . . . for the Tuvalu trust fund.

There are significant problems in the way Australia is perceived by nations in the South Pacific; yet Australia's relationships will be jeopardised by the continuing contraction of its overseas aid in the region in which we live.

In the time left to me I would like to make briefly some other points in relation to the aid program generally. I am disappointed that Australia continues to give such a poor performance in support for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. I am very conscious of the programs he supports in our region, which are important in providing a resolution in part to the problems occasioned by people being dispossessed of their homelands, as we have seen in Kampuchea, Vietnam and the like.

I would like from the Minister some clarification of questions I have posed previously about the International Fund for Agricultural Development. The Minister would no doubt be aware of the important role played by this fund for the rural poor. He would also be aware of my continuing concern that Australia ought to make known its contribution to the second replenishment that that organisation has requested and its contribution to the sub-Saharan Africa pledge, which Australia has been requested to assist.

In the context of this debate I would also like to seek from the Minister information on the situation involving Kampuchea. I note that there were some weeks ago news reports that the Kampuchean Prime Minister, Hun Sen, had said that he was willing to deal directly with the Khmer Rouge leader, Khieu Samphan. I would like the Minister to clarify for the Parliament the developments occuring in relation to Kampuchea in particular and whether he sees this new approach of the Kampuchean Prime Minister and Foreign Affairs Minister as a realistic move on their part, one from which we might see some new developments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, last year when I spoke in this very same debate-I recall it was on 16 October-I expressed my concern about the South Pacific region. At the end of my speech I called on the Government to make a substantial statement on what it proposed to do in the region-a coherent statement indicating the direction and the substance of Government policy in that part of the world so vital to our future. What disturbs me is that, over the past 12 months since I made that speech, the Government has done absolutely nothing to co-ordinate and make coherent its policies in our region. That is, I think, a very serious matter; and that has been shown up so clearly in our responses to the two coups that have taken place recently in Fiji.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the past 4 1/2 years the Opposition has repeatedly commented that the Australian Government has given too low a priority to the South Pacific. If it is not too cheap a political point to make, there is no doubt that the fact that the Minister has made the one, albeit extensive, sweep through the South Pacific-and I point out that he has made one visit also to Central America in the same period-is a matter of concern. I think the Minister should spend more time in the South Pacific, more time talking with the leaders and the governments of those nations. I have said before that I am concerned that the Government abandoned the Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meetings. I think the Minister would now concede that, in retrospect and in all honesty, that was a pity, because that organisation would have been extremely helpful in the sort of crisis we are now faced with in Fiji.

The Opposition had some very real reservations about the one initiative that this Government has pursued in the South Pacific-the establishment of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. That has, of course, come at a time of real concern about the stability and the security of the region, at a time of real concern with the collapse of the ANZUS alliance and the withdrawal of New Zealand into a Finland- isation policy. The Government's only initiative has been to pursue the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty, something that weakens the role of the United States of America and the Western alliance in our region.

I take up the very important point made by the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock). Year after year the Government has reduced our aid as a proportion of gross domestic product (GDP), and I assume that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) has simply been rolled on this matter time and again in Cabinet by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). But when one looks at the figures for aid to the South Pacific, excluding Papua New Guinea, it is a matter of real concern to me that the Government has once more given our region such a low priority. The total figures are not too bad. There is a decline, but it is a decline of $1m in the estimated aid to the South Pacific from $69.7m to $68.2m. Taking into account that it was proposed to increase aid to Fiji from more than $12m to $20m, as a result of the Government's response to the second coup in Fiji we can assume that that $20m will not be spent.

There has been a reduction in real terms in aid to countries like the Solomon Islands, Vanuatu, Tonga, Western Samoa, Kiribati, the Cook Islands, and so on. It seems to me that, at a time of regional instability and regional concern, the Government should be moving in the opposite direction. It would be good foreign policy to be moving in the opposite direction and, as the honourable member for Dundas pointed out several times, it is good humanitarian policy to ensure that the level of aid as a proportion of GDP aims towards the United Nations target of 0.7 per cent. But we are moving in the wrong direction.

These are practical issues of Australia's relationship with the South Pacific. I sincerely believe that, in confronting that complicated and ever-changing relationship, the Government, to use a word, has been negligent. We are never told by the Government or by the Minister specifically what the objectives are in our region and what the principles are by which the Government will abide in pursuing its regional diplomacy. We should have elucidated by the Minister very clear and very simple objectives. After all, putting it simply, we as Australians want stability and prosperity in our region. That is why a coherent foreign policy and a generous aid policy are important in the pursuit of those objectives.

Australia is a force in this region and we should not be ashamed of that. We should not be walking away from that; we should not be wringing our hands and putting our heads down and saying that we should not be a force in the region. We should believe that we, as Australians, are a force for good-not nasty, overbearing imperialists but a country with very strong philosophical values which are humanitarian and caring about individuals and a country also with considerable regional economic strength which can be used not to oppress people but to the benefit and the enrichment of the region.

The Government, in my view, has been embarrassed to play a role-I suspect for philosophical reasons-and it has therefore tended to ignore the region as though it were nothing to do with Australia, as though it would be wrong to use our influence for good in the region. I think that is very regrettable. That shows the Government's lack of response to our regional objectives. But what of the Government's principles in relation to the region? I imagine that, as an Australian government, it would believe in the values of self-determination for all the peoples of our region and in the pursuit of a pluralist democracy. Certainly the Opposition believes that, if individuals are free to determine their own futures, that is the sure path to domestic stability in any country.

As far as those principles are concerned, there is some confusion in relation to the Government's policy. The Government does not pursue the principles of self-determination and pluralistic democracy in the case of New Caledonia. A referendum was organised-I think on 13 September-by the French Government in New Caledonia. The Hawke Government did not allege that the referendum was in some way stacked or illegal, or was in some other way illegitimate, but accepted that it was legitimate.
