We all know the result of that referendum: in a genuine act of self-determination, whether we like it or not-and I know the Government does not like it-the people of New Caledonia expressed a majority view that they wanted to remain part of France and not become an entirely independent country.

I believe there has been no Press statement from the Minister on this issue, but in subsequent briefings the Government has said it did not really like the result of the referendum and that the French Government had given the people of New Caledonia the wrong choices. So the Hawke Government decided that the referendum did not count. In a briefing note which has kindly been provided to me by the Minister's office the Government said that its objectives in New Caledonia were an orderly transition to multiracial independence which recognised the rights of indigenous people and so on. It is fair enough to recognise the rights of indigenous people, but what is this about having a policy which pursues multiracial independence when we are supposed to be a country which believes in self-determination?

There is an issue of the rights of indigenous people. We do not know how the Government addresses that issue. We do not know what its policy and its philosophy towards the rights of indigenous people are. We assume that the Government supports the principle of self-determination; but at the same time the Government is arguing for decolonisation in New Caledonia and is apparently putting the rights of indigenous people, as the Government sees it, above the right to self-determination.

I would like that matter clarified, particularly as the Government's policy on New Caledonia-without having time to explain it-contradicts its policy on Fiji. I am not criticising the Government's policy in general on Fiji, but I want the Government to make a clear statement about our relationship with the South Pacific, about the values and the guiding principles of that relationship, and about the economic objectives that we as a nation can pursue to enhance the living standards of ordinary people throughout our region. Do not let us be ashamed as Australians of the important role we can play in the Pacific. We should be a force for good; we should be proud that we are a force for good; and we should pursue the objectives we believe in in our region.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment on this year's overseas aid allocation. This year's overseas aid allocation was cut by 3.4 per cent in real terms. Our aid allocation will drop as a percentage of gross national product and drop below the international average for aid donor countries. As a result of inflation, our aid allocation is 16 per cent lower than it was two years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to put these statistics in context. Each week across the globe 280,000 children die in what the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) has described as the `silent emergency' of frequent infection and widespread malnutrition. In developing countries the number of child deaths under five years of age each year is almost equal to that of the population of Australia-over 14 million.

It is not hard to understand such statistics of death when one realises, for example, that in our Asian backyard only 31 per cent of the 160 million children in rural areas have adequate water resources and only 12 per cent of those children have adequate sanitation in their communities.

We all know the reason Australia gives for its declining commitment to overseas aid. It is what is known internationally as `adjustment policies' developed in response to international economic pressures and past domestic policy negligence. As UNICEF points out in its latest report on the state of the world's children, as is always the case it is the poor, women and children who are suffering from the international phenomena of recession and adjustment. Adjustment policies in both developed and developing countries are producing deteriorating health and nutrition for millions of poor families in developing countries. So in Australia today, adjustment means deferred tax cuts and fewer luxury items. In developing countries it means death from malnutrition and disease. That is the undeniable truth that these real cuts to overseas aid ignores.

Let me bring home the significance of this policy question by quoting briefly from the UNICEF report to which I have already referred. I ask honourable members and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) to listen not just in mind but also in heart. The report states:

At the moment, it is still accepted as normal for more than 14 million of the world's youngest children to die every year and for millions more to live on in malnutrition and ill-health-despite the fact that recent technical and social advances have rendered hollow the inevitability on which that acceptance is based.

It is now time for morality to catch up with capacity, for a sea-change in public and political perception, a change to redraw the line of what is acceptable in our times . . . a change which will make it unconscionable not to do what can now be done.
The report concludes:
Surely the time has come to say that it is obscene to let this continue day after day, year after year, as our civilisation moves into the twenty-first century.

Surely the time has come to put the mass deaths of children alongside slavery, racism, and apartheid on the shelf reserved for those things which are simply no longer acceptable to mankind. Surely the time has come to mobilise national and international capacity to put known low-cost measures into effect on the necessary scale, to exert the moral muscle to transform what can be done into what will now be done.

It is interesting to juxtapose this quote and the statistics discussed thus far with Senator Walsh's observation that it is time to `challenge most of the absurd notions that the majority of Australian's have, about what they are entitled to and what is essential to them and what isn't'. This Budget allocation should be about the priority of basic human needs over secondary needs or wants. The cuts to overseas aid reflect the triumph of domestic political demands in that consideration.

The majority of honourable members in this place are sworn in with a Bible in their hand. Each day we commence our deliberations with a prayer asking Almighty God to prosper our deliberations to the advancement of his glory, and the true welfare of the people of Australia. I assume, therefore, that honourable members will not consider it inappropriate if I suggest that we take note of the biblical warning in Proverbs:
He who closes his ear to the cry of the poor will himself cry out and not be heard.

Our unwillingness to maintain our aid commitment in real terms and as a proportion of our national wealth, even as our economy expands and the recession grinds the poor further into despair and death, is in reality a closing of our ears to the cry of the poor. Perhaps we should consider, therefore, how the Almighty will consider our cry to prosper our deliberations for the welfare of the relatively wealthy people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HAYDEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of views have been put forward in the course of the debate, in particular by my good friend the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) who leaves me with a vast sense of deficiency. But for all that I will forbear and not only respond to the key points that have been made but also hang on to the job a bit longer. I think that perhaps some of the points which have been made have been a little overstressed, presumably even a little distorted. The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), if I can distil what he had to say to two key areas, discussed glasnost and his reservations about the genuineness of the Soviets in respect of that declared objective.

SPEECH.PARA: His other point concerned arms control and his worries-worries which I share to some important extent-that perhaps people are expecting too much in presuming that as progress has been made on the intermediate nuclear force arrangements, which we perceive should lead to an agreement soon, it will be a simple matter to roll on to strategic arms control and conventional arms control. I share his concern to the extent that this will be a very difficult task. I should say first that, in respect of glasnost, the openings that are taking place in the Soviet Union, it is desirable to suspend judgment; it is far better to make judgment on performance or, as we see things unfolding, on the developments which are taking place with their clear implications. If those things are positive, both for the relationship between East and West and in improving circumstances in the Soviet Union, it is a highly desirable enterprise.

If we should find on the other hand that glasnost turns out to be a castle of cards with no substance to it, that is the appropriate time to express our criticism; not too late of course, but the judgment can be made at a suitably early point and adjustments made. It is my very strong view that glasnost is important to the Soviet Union and that the dominant view will be to try to make it succeed; it is in its interest. But it is also in the interests of the West that it succeed. Firstly, it will mean a healthier dialogue and a healthier commercial and political involvement with the rest of the world. That is positive and that ought to be encouraged. Secondly, it should also be recognised that while on the one hand the enormous cost burden of maintaining the military machine in the Soviet Union is one which cannot be borne interminably into the future, at the same time the cost burden of the military machine in the West, most particularly for the United States of America, represents a vast obligation that cannot be borne uncritically into the future either.

Some of the economic problems in the United States at the moment-I mention parenthetically here that those problems are reflected in deficits on both the external account and the domestic account, the latter feeding into the former-have been generated by the enormous defence programs that the United States has undertaken. That is not a criticism of the United States; the United States has been extraordinarily generous in the way in which in the post-war period it has taken on such a huge burden of supporting the defence structure which has attended to Western interests. It seems to me that that role is increasingly difficult for the United States to maintain. Simple comparisons bear that out. The European Community has a somewhat larger population than the United States and its per capita income is only marginally less than that of the United States, yet the United States has been taking upon its shoulders the burden of protecting Western global interests. That has meant a much greater outlay of expenditure on defence than the rest of the West has borne. That cannot go on ad infinitum; there has to be a limit. More particularly, other countries in the West, recovering from the devastation of the post-war period, now have very strong advanced industrialised economies. It is in the interests of both the West and the East that glasnost succeed.

On the issue of nuclear arms control and conventional arms control, I want to say, first, that it is evident that there is to be a major breakthrough in achieving an agreement which will lead to the elimination of intermediate range nuclear forces. This will be the first occasion ever in the nuclear age that there will be a comprehensive elimination of a whole range of weapons representing an important part of the arsenal of nuclear capability of both East and West. We have had the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks, SALT I and SALT II. They set limits, but limits which were higher, generally, than the stockpiles of weapons that the East and the West had. So, they were limits which either side could climb up to, and they were limits which created contention because it was alleged that they gave advantage to one side as against the other. Thereafter, there was conflict and dispute and there was lack of credibility in important sections of communities about those agreements. The agreements on the intermediate range forces will be unambiguous, as I said, at the moment anyway. They will lead to the elimination of all of those intermediate range forces.

The next, bigger and much more difficult step will be to get rid of strategic nuclear arms. As the honourable member for North Sydney rightly observed, these are inextricably linked to conventional capabilities, in particular in Europe. Whether there is in the asymmetrical relationship between East and West nevertheless a counter-balancing effect-for instance, whether or not the excess of tanks or the superiority of tank capability in the East is matched by a superiority of anti-tank capability in the West-is immaterial to the issue. The issue is simply that the way people make decisions will be affected by the way they see things. In the East and the West there are beliefs that there are imbalances in conventional arms. It is believed very much on the part of the West in Europe that the strategic nuclear arms capability of the West, dominantly that of the United States, is therefore essential to counterbalance the superiority that it believes it sees on the part of the East. Although I see asymmetry between East and West on particular capabilities, on counter- capabilities I tend to see a symmetrical outcome overall. But that is a debatable point. Europe sees it otherwise. If there is to be progress on strategic nuclear arms, there will also have to be concomitantly progress on conventional arms.

I move on, although not without observing that the points made by the honourable member for North Sydney were quite substantial and important ones, to the views expressed by the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar). The honourable member for Warringah referred to a breakdown more generally in the social and political system in Papua New Guinea. I trust I do him no misrepresentation. There are difficulties in Papua New Guinea not the least of which are matters related to law and order. These in turn relate to the movement of people away from traditional village life into urban areas, attracted by the prospect of a new, better and more exciting way of living. There is nothing novel about that. That has happened in just about every developed country. It has particularly happened in the developing countries of black Africa. But when these people congregate in the outer areas of these main urban centres, unemployed, with time on their hands, resentful and having no support, inevitably there is a resort to criminal activity. This is not exculpation of what has taken place; it is merely a statement of fact about what has occurred. Papua New Guinea has experienced this problem.

But what has also to be borne in mind is that Papua New Guinea is one of the few democracies in the world; there are not many of them. It perseveres with democracy after more than a decade of independence. That is remarkable. If we look at the history of Papua New Guinea, we did not first of all give it much opportunity to develop a fountain of experienced people to run private and public sector administration, and, secondly, we did not therefore give it the additional opportunity to experiment, to graft on to what it had learned from us, from what we had taught it, its own cultural values and cultural interpretation of ways in which things should be done. For instance, our legal system is totally alien to the people of Papua New Guinea. Towards the end of the period, when we were the colonising administrators of the country, we started to realise that. Peter Hastings, a well known journalist who has specialised in this area of our region, was one of the seminal thinkers and writers concerning how this cultural grafting had to take place. The court systems, the legal systems, had to reflect the more traditional values of the people in the community.

Similarly, the parliamentary system with which Papua New Guinea perseveres even after all these years is something totally alien to the culture of the people of Papua New Guinea. It is no easy matter for them to make that work, but they persevere with it. The complexity of public sector administration was a huge and daunting novelty suddenly cast on to their shoulders. But they work with it. There are strains and there are problems. But Papua New Guinea is still a fledgling country and it is working hard at trying to make things succeed. It has had lots of problems and it will have more. On the other hand, it has had many successes and we ought to commend and applaud those. We ought to seek to get a balanced account of what is taking place there and be fair to the people, not put them down. Reinforcing their confidence is important, without being patronising.

Of course, as the honourable member for Warringah observed, we have substantial interests in Papua New Guinea. I have to say that, while Papua New Guinea's interests have broadened in the region and are now starting to broaden beyond that, that does not necessarily imply a decline in interest in Papua New Guinea in Australia. I believe it to be indisputable that interest in Papua New Guinea in Australia is strong, healthy and robust. It is something that will endure. However, at the same time as Papua New Guinea matures as a nation it will want to do many more things its own way-differently from the way in which we do things in Australia, for instance. It has a different culture and different values. It is struggling in a different milieu from this developed and well-off country. If it decides to go into the non-aligned movement, so what? There are many countries in the non-aligned movement representing a great variety of views. After all, if a representative of Cuba can become the chairman of the non-aligned movement, which happened a couple of years ago, it is a very interesting non-aligned movement. A great range of countries are members of the non-aligned movement many of which have a deep commitment to the West.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that in our interest, though?

—I do not see any problem at all. It is Papua New Guinea maturing in its policy decisions, in the way in which it sees its role in the world and in taking an independent position. Singapore is a member of the non-aligned movement and so is Indonesia. Many of the closest friends we have in this region are members of the non-aligned movement. This country is an observer. Dare I say it, in case someone thinks I am a fellow traveller, that I raised this matter at non-aligned movement meetings and I think that is very important. We have sent a number of distinguished representatives from this Parliament to these meetings. The honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney) has been there on three occasions. Was it three or one?
—One.

—I am sorry, I cannot count. I should have joined the National Party instead of the Australian Labor Party. The right honour- able member for New England (Mr Sinclair) made some criticisms of the rearrangements of departments insofar as they affect the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. All I have to say is this: He may be correct. There may be insurmountable problems because of the amalgamation of the two departments in which case I, in particular, have a problem, apart from the Government having its problems. I have to say on my experience so far that I see no evidence that problems will occur. All of the evidence I see reveals that this is a natural amalgamation between two departments. More than that, I believe that it will give a sharper cutting edge to the role of foreign affairs and looking after the interests of this country externally.

SPEECH.PARA: We are most fortunate in this country in the quality of the officers who are serving us in the Department of Foreign Affairs. They are recruited into the Department having a very high level of performance. Some of them are misguided enough to be sitting on the other side of the Parliament but, fortunately, the honourable member for Kingston more than balances that. We are also fortunate now to have recruited to our ranks the very fine quality officers of the Public Service who have worked for the Department of Trade. The symbiotic relationship to me is very clear and productive already. I think this amalgamation will prove to be one of the more outstanding successes of the rearrangements which have taken place.

I now mention the comments of the honour- able member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock). He addressed his remarks particularly to cuts in aid. He and I have shared a very long time in this Parliament and there is no disputing the genuine and long-standing concern he has about this area. I, too, share his worry about the cuts in aid, as I mentioned earlier. These decisions are not easily arrived at. Both sides of the Parliament agree that there is a need to restrain government spending. If one is to take that seriously as an injunction, where the aggregates about which we are talking are quite large, there is little opportunity for immunity for any particular section of government spending. There have been substantial cuts in aid.

I was not, as I think the honourable member for Mayo said rather vulgarly, rolled by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Rather, I freely co-operated in the cuts which took place but not without, of course, expressing reservations about the effect of such a measure. In particular I expressed reservations about the discomfort I felt personally as a democratic socialist-one of a dying race, a little like the dodo in some ways-presiding over this matter. It was an inevitable result of the things the Government had to do. If it is successful-I believe that it is-in getting the economy back on to an even keel, in restructuring industry, getting more substantial growth and moving into new areas, we will be in a better position later on to support more extensive and expansive aid programs.

The honourable member for Dundas referred to Kampuchea. I envy him. A few years ago he had the opportunity of being there and of observing the situation first hand. I am not sure what will happen in respect of Kampuchea. I had rather hoped that the initiatives of Dr Mochtar, the cocktail party and the efforts to bring people together might have been successful. At this point I think I should say that things seem to be somewhat in abeyance. There are talks and attempts at contacts between various groups in the hope that something might be produced that will help to bring about a political settlement of Kampuchea. The sine qua non in the settlement of Kampuchea is a withdrawal of Vietnamese troops.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think the Vietnamese have any intention of getting out of Kampuchea?

—I trust so. They have said it to me often enough and they have said it to others often enough. They have to perform. They say that by 1990 they will have arrangements in place to have withdrawn all of their troops. I sincerely trust that that can be achieved and it would be even better if it could be achieved earlier than 1990. All I can say is that I am not in charge of Vietnamese foreign policy. I urge the Vietnamese to fulfil that commitment. I state for the record that Dr Mochtar, the distinguished Foreign Minister of Indonesia, has worked untiringly to try to bring about a set of circumstances which would lead to contact, to dialogue and, in turn, hopefully, result in a formula which would allow the withdrawal to take place and for Kampuchea to become self-governing. There is some faltering in that process at the moment and I hope it can be recovered.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Mayo said that I had made only one visit to the South Pacific, that I had neglected it; that I had abandoned Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meetings (CHOGRM); that I had introduced a fraudulent South Pacific nuclear free zone; that I had not caned New Zealand for its misbehaviour; and that I had cut aid to the South Pacific. The only thing he did not ask me to do was to resign. In spite of that savage indictment he presented against me, there are some errors of fact that are quite explicitly involved.

I have made more than one visit to the South Pacific and I have visited more countries in the South Pacific than has any Foreign Minister. I do not want to labour the point, but it would be desirable if we all eased back a little. I do not expect honourable members to stop scoring points in this place. After all, I spent many years doing it when I was on the other side of the House before I came to this side of the House. Before I go too far with mea culpa and enrage honourable members opposite, let me say this: all of us should spend more time in the South Pacific area and in our regional area. Too many honourable members are using their travel allocation to go to certainly very interesting places and places important politically which are well removed from our immediate region. But our immediate region is where the action which takes place will most likely have the most profound effect on this country.

I am not the only Minister in this Government to have visited the South Pacific. A large number of Ministers have visited there and they continue to do so. I have not abandoned CHOGRM meetings. It may interest the honourable member for Mayo to know that I do not get to CHOGRM or Commonwealth Heads of Government Meetings and neither did my predecessors except on very rare occasions. CHOGRM has not been abandoned. At the last meeting at Port Moresby it was agreed that CHOGRM should meet as the need arises and that in turn is determined by the members of the CHOGRM association, not by Australia. There will be a meeting when it is decided there should be one. We will not impose one on it.

The honourable member for Mayo was disparaging about the nuclear free South Pacific zone. Let me say this to the honourable member: if he disparages it, he does no good for our standing in the region because the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty reflects a deeply felt article of faith on the part of the countries of the South Pacific region. Those countries which have not signed the Treaty, such as Vanuatu, have not signed it because they do not like it for the reasons which the honourable member outlined-that is, that they see it as some impediment to Western interests. Rather, they see it as wanting. They would prefer it to be much tougher in its prohibitive qualities. It is an effective treaty and it reflects an interest commonly shared in this region. In turn, its introduction has improved greatly Australia's presence and influence in the region.

Aid in the South Pacific, the honourable member for Mayo egregiously claimed, had been cut by $1m or $2m compared with last year. The honourable member has impaled himself in his own self-set bear trap because last year we made a special one-off allocation of $8m to the Tuvalu Trust Fund. With the United Kingdom and New Zealand, we provided money from the surplus funds from the wound-up, defunct British Phosphate Commission. The aim is that from income generated from the trust fund the Budget of Tuvalu, a country of between 7,000 and 8,000 people with a very limited resource base, will be supplemented to give the Tuvalu people more independence and more determination over their own economic future. If we take out that $8m, we are down only $1m and are ahead at least $7m. I hope that I do not confuse the honourable member with simple arithmetic.

The honourable member asked me for a statement of objectives and principles in the region. These come off the top of the head. The things that we are interested in are topics such as the right to self-determination of the countries in the region, a preference for democracy but recognising that there are countries in the region for which democratic values are quite alien. Malay-type countries, for instance, find democratic values quite alien to their traditional cultural ways of decision-making. We want to see economic and commercial success. In fact, the Cairns group reflects this concern not only for our own interests but also for those of developing countries, particularly those in our region. We want to see political stability both domestically and regionally. We want to see an avoidance of conflict and a diminution of tension, should there be a tendency for it to arise. We want to see the minimisation of super-power competition in the region, and we want to see shared interests that apply here as well as in the Western association of nations upheld. Australia is the largest and most developed country in the immediate South Pacific region playing a role of assistance, support and encouragement without being intrusive, overbearing or interfering.

In the case of New Caledonia, our policy is not in conflict with our attitude on Fiji. New Caledonia is a region which is before the Committee of Twenty-four in the United Nations, the Decolonisation Committee. It is an issue of decolonisation and what will be the appropriate outcome. In the case of Fiji, it is an issue of an independent country being subverted by a military coup. We have not at any stage supported the arguments of the Melanesians in New Caledonia that they, and they alone, should be allowed to vote to determine the future of New Caledonia, nor do we support the views of the Melanesian-Polynesian population in Fiji that they should be able to dominate that society on some sort of structured communal basis. We should bear in mind, however, that there is a vast difference between South Africa and apartheid, on the one hand, and communalisation that is institutionalised, on the other hand. No one will suggest that Malaysia, which has institutionalised communalisation or communalism, reflects the values of apartheid. No one sensibly would say that. I could not imagine anything more inappropriate or more offensive, but I ask honourable members to bear that in mind.

The honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) made a powerful and heartfelt statement about the aid cut. His views have a profound impact on me and I share them deeply. On the other hand, I have had certain responsibilities as a Minister over a succession of years of tough budgetary decision-making, and I cannot shirk my responsibility to carry some of that sacrifice, if that is the decision of the Government-a decision which I fully endorsed. I have sought to pull my weight. If we are successful in our economic management, as we are being, later on we will be better off and better fitted to do more and be more generous. But if we do not apply the disciplines now, we will not help anyone much, not even ourselves.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Department of Employment, Education and Training
Proposed expenditure, $1,825,267,000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have only 10 minutes to deal with the estimates for the Department of Employment, Education and Training. Although my colleague the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) will be concentrating on the employment and training aspects of the Department, I wish to divide the 10 minutes that are at my disposal into five minutes for primary and secondary education and another five minutes for tertiary education. It is a great pity that my remarks have to be concentrated into that short period of time because the subject is of immense importance to every Australian family, but so be it.

SPEECH.PARA: To deal first with primary and secondary education: it is quite clear that the new Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) intends to make changes in the Commonwealth structure in this area. But the basic problems we face in primary and secondary education are problems of how one empowers the consumer of education services against the excessive power of the centralised bureaucracies which run the educational systems and the excessive power of the teaching unions, which are more part of the industrial structure than they are of the professional structure. Fundamentally, that is the problem we face.

I am told that the New South Wales Department of Education is the most centralised and the largest single educational unit running an education system in the world outside the Soviet Union. Most education systems, certainly in the democracies, are much more decentralised to local government or regional units, whereas the New South Wales Department is a highly centralised, highly controlled system in which the demands of the consumer are very far down the scale of priorities. It is not possible, for example, within the New South Wales system, or indeed within the Victorian system, for parents to choose even between one school and another within a particular region. There is a zoning system and they have no choice. If there happens to be a bad principal or a school that is badly run, as inevitably in a centralised bureaucracy there will be, there is no capacity for parents to vote with their feet, unless they incur the additional cost of moving to a non-government school, which they may, for religious or other reasons, not wish to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that is true in Victoria.
—Is the Minister saying that it is not true in Victoria?
—I think it is much more flexible.

—Slightly more flexible. I think in South Australia it is quite flexible, but I think in Victoria there is a great deal of rigidity. Certainly in New South Wales one cannot do that. That surely is one of the first requirements that we should have in the system-that within the government system there should be a chance for parents to choose between one school and another within that system. That would be supremely inconvenient for the centralised bureaucracies that run those systems, but it would be a necessary tonic. There is no better discipline than losing customers for people to make sure that they change the system, change the principal, change the teachers and change the teaching systems so that they maintain students at that school.
—It would slow the drift to non-government schools.

—As my colleague the honourable member for Tangney says, if that happened it would probably slow the drift to the non-government schools. I have been in situations as a parent with children in government schools in two cases where the principal became quite unacceptable to the body of parents and it was not possible to remedy that situation for a long time. It was only when the children had subsequently moved on to a different school, a high school, that one was able to have any redress. The Commonwealth has, since the advent of the Whitlam Government, tried to overcome the deficiencies in the State systems by superimposing the Commonwealth Schools Commission, a new bureaucracy, on top of the State bureaucracies. That is an attempt to overcome the distortions and difficulties of these overcentralised systems by superimposing another bureaucracy on top of them. While that system has had some impact and there have been some beneficial outcomes of the work of the Schools Commission, essentially it has been a very inefficient and costly process because the State systems simply failed to face up to their basic responsibilities if they believed that someone else would come in and solve the problem for them.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently I had occasion to talk to some people who had organised an education centre in a remote area of Australia and I asked those people who were running the centre precisely what functions they were carrying out with the assistance of Commonwealth funding. It became clear that what those people were doing in a remote area of Queensland was an essential ingredient of any basic rural education system. The Commonwealth was saying that it intended to reduce its funds and that what these people were doing would not be done any more. It is a disgrace that the State system concerned has not taken the responsibility for those quite basic functions. I do not think it will actually do so whilst the Commonwealth pretends that it will continue in some way with that sort of support.

Therefore, if we look back over the years since 1974 or so when the Schools Commission was set up and Commonwealth intervention in its present form was established, we see that the overall effect of that, whilst beneficial in a number of ways, has resulted in State systems failing to be sufficiently innovative or sufficiently concerned about the fundamental requirements of their consumers. Therefore, I think that some fundamental change is required. I would hope that whatever changes the Minister makes will result not merely in replacing the Schools Commission with a centralised bureaucracy of the Federal Department but in taking steps that will generally empower consumers in the schools themselves to dictate a great deal more of the direction of education.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you any suggestions?

—Well, I have many which I would detail if I had more time, but I have gone well over time on the Schools Commission. Let me turn to tertiary education. The Minister has announced a wide-ranging inquiry into tertiary education. I mentioned two components of that which will be important in relation to whether the results of that inquiry will be beneficial. The first is again this question of centralisation. Will the thrust of the inquiry and its recommendations merely have the effect of transferring what is an overcentralised bureaucratic system through the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission into a new centralised bureaucracy in the Department, or will they empower the institutions to be more responsive to consumers at the grass roots level with a genuine alteration to the power structures of tertiary education? That will be the first important issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The second important issue is the source of funds and the total volume of funds for tertiary education. It is generally agreed that the resources going into tertiary education are inadequate by international standards. It is quite clear that the taxpayer has not sufficient funds to meet that requirement. Therefore, there will be a need to generate additional sources of funds from the private sector and from individuals. Therefore, the question is how one can best organise this new input of funds to expand the capacity of the tertiary education sector.

There are problems within the internal structure of the Australian Labor Party on the question of fees. The present Minister is grappling with this issue; obviously he is not in agreement with the present Labor Party platform on this matter, any more than Senator Walsh is. A lot will hinge on the Minister's ability over the next couple of years to alter the party platform on that, but it is obviously necessary to arrange for additional sources of funds for tertiary education which are not wholly dependent on the taxpayer. Those two elements will be critical.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the Opposition's position on fees?
—Our position on fees is well known. We published it before the last election and the Minister would be familiar with it. The two elements of additional funds--
-Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of the Government's Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88 and, in doing so, address myself to the employment, education and training expenditure outlined in the Bill. In doing that, I would like to emphasise my wholehearted support for public education in Australia. This Government has total commitment to employment, education and training, which is reflected in the Budget, but I will confine myself to expenditure related to particular areas in the Northern Territory. In his media release on the night of the Budget, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) said that the most successful economies have given high priority to education and skills development, and that Australia must now adopt a similar strategy. I agree wholeheartedly.

SPEECH.PARA: My electorate is in desperate need of this sort of commitment. On the latest figures available to me, retention rates of school students in my electorate are more than 16 per cent below the national average. This particularly affects isolated children, especially Aboriginal children, who do not enjoy the advantages of their fellow students in major cities. In fact, the retention rates for Aboriginal and Islander students in the Northern Territory is only one third of the retention rate for the Northern Territory as a whole. The Government has committed $28.5m in 1987-88 to the assistance for isolated children scheme, which provides assistance for the parents of children who, because of geographic isolation or a disability, must live away from home to attend school, study by correspondence or live in a second family home which provides daily access to schooling. In 1988, isolated children living at home and undertaking secondary schooling by correspondence will be paid a flat rate of $10 per week. The number of children who are expected to qualify for benefits in this way nationally in 1988 is expected to be about 19,000 and a significant number of these will reside in my electorate.

Continuing on the commitment of the Federal Government's support for Aboriginal education, the remote area program for Aborigines (RAPA) is designed to provide students of post-primary age in remote communities with an extended and improving range of course options. I add that it is important that these options are provided because, from my experience as a teacher in the Northern Territory and having been employed on a special project to analyse the impact of education and government services on Aboriginal children and families, I am aware that there is no greater need for these services than in remote areas of the Territory.

The Northern Territory Government participated in the pilot RAPA program in 1985-86 and funds were provided for the setting up and operation of a manual arts learning unit, which is a mobile instruction unit offering vocational instruction to a number of communities in central and northern Australia. Under the Aboriginal employment development program, RAPA has been established as an ongoing program which will benefit isolated communities and help them to have access to training they may otherwise not get.

There is a widespread concern that the educational achievements of Aboriginal children are lagging noticeably behind those of other Australians. There is a growing appreciation that educational provisions for Aboriginal children have not adequately considered their cultural outlook or aspirations. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander pedagogy project is researching successful programs that improve the learning outcomes of these children and is funded by this Budget. As a result of the project, it is expected that significant changes in learning and teaching styles will result. The total budget for this project for 1987-88, its second year of operation, will be $255,000 nationally. A significant element of the project will be directed to the Northern Territory.

With the approach of the Bicentenary, the Northern Territory faces the intolerable fact that although Aboriginal people make up 33 per cent of the 17- to 64-year-old age group in the Northern Territory, they comprise only 7 per cent of the student population in that age group. In the last Budget, the Government increased the amount to be spent on Aboriginal student assistance nationally by more than $7.8m. Consequently, the number of students assisted nationally has increased from 30,000 in 1982 to 46,000 last year. Again, a significant proportion of these were in my electorate.

To make it clear, it needs to be stressed that applicants for allowances under the Aboriginal secondary grants schemes (Abseg) and the Aboriginal study assistance scheme (Abstudy) will continue to be exempt from the income test applied to recipients of other forms of student assistance. Students of over 16 years of age receiving Absec and those over 21 years of age on Abstudy will receive higher rates of allowances if they are enrolled in employment-oriented courses. This Government's major concern is to involve more Aboriginal students in forms of education or training which are likely to facilitate increased employment, at the same time ensuring that any such programs are in accord with the needs and aspirations of Aboriginal people, as perceived by them.

I might point out that under Abstudy and Abseg programs the Commonwealth funds a number of special courses in the Northern Territory-some at Batchelor College, some at the Darwin Institute of Technology and some at the Institute of Aboriginal Development at Alice Springs. Two of the courses at Batchelor College are centred on Aboriginal teacher education training. One is the D-Bate program and the other is the homeland centres remote area teacher education program. The D-Bate program is run by Deakin University and is funded by the Government. Last year it saw its first graduates. Bakamanu Yunupingu, Norma Joshua and Robyn Ramsay were the first Aboriginal Northern Territorians to graduate with Bachelor of Education degrees from Deakin University. In addition, very important courses are being run at the Darwin Institute of Technology by the Aboriginal task force unit. The courses are for the community work certificate, the certificate in general and technical studies for Aborigines and a preliminary course.

Aboriginal employment rates are half the national average. Indeed, in my electorate there are some communities which have a far higher unemployment rate, with some having a rate in excess of 60 or 70 per cent. The people in these communities are desperate for work. They do not want to be forced to receive social security benefits forever. This Government is committed to providing the funds that are needed to conduct relevant training and education programs. It is worth pointing out at this point that Aboriginal people in these communities are the only people in Australia who volunteer to work for the dole, or an equivalent of the dole. These people, under the community development employment program, agreed to pool their unemployment benefits and, with the addition of an administrative component of 20 per cent as a top-up for resources, materials and administrative expenses, they run their own employment projects. They do this on the basis that they are paid for part time work at award rates.

This Government's concern is to promote Aboriginal control over their own affairs, and this has led to a stated commitment that Aboriginal people must participate in the design and implementation of education and training programs that are both economically and socially relevant. For too long schemes have been imposed from above on Aboriginal people and their communities. This is seeking to make schemes more flexible and more relevant as part of its long term commitment to Aboriginal people's self management.

In order that appropriately qualified teachers are placed in Aboriginal schools, induction and in-service courses and professional development programs are funded by Federal Government education and training programs. To date, over 60 teachers and 18 teacher trainees in the Northern Territory have benefited from this program. This level of Federal Government involvement will continue in the Territory. In 1987 the Federal Government provided for 101 extra places for Aboriginal students at Batchelor College and the Darwin Institute of Technology at a cost of nearly half a million dollars. The Government will maintain its commitment to these sorts of programs which have provided teachers who are far more responsive to community needs and who have a long term responsibility to the community. I might add that the commitment and dedication of the teachers who work in these remote communities is something to be seen and it should be applauded.

I think it has been recognised by this Government, through the amount it is prepared to spend on education, employment and training, that Australia's economic potential has been held back by an inadequate commitment to skills training and education. If people are starting from a position of disadvantage, as many people in my electorate are, the need for this sort of government initiative is doubly important. The Government has pledged continued support for community based program assistance, over time, and the Minister has indicated that a single community program aimed at maximising training and employment for the most disadvantaged of the unemployed will eventuate. On that matter I might point out that the Federal Government in another area of my electorate, Christmas Island, has underscored its commitment to retraining and employment assistance. The Government's legislation demonstrates its view that the people of Christmas Island are fully entitled to responsible and socially relevant government. With this in mind, $1.5m has been allocated for retraining and employment assistance on Christmas Island.

I know many people in my electorate who receive the unemployment benefit who would give almost anything for a job. As I indicated previously, Aboriginal people, who are vilified by many members of the community-most notably those who belong to the Opposition parties in this chamber and elsewhere in Australia-for being recipients of the unemployment benefit and other social welfare payments, are the only people in this country who have sought assistance from the Government to run projects and employment schemes that effectively involve working for the dole.

TALK.START.PARA: —Started by the Fraser Government.

—That is to its credit, and to the credit of Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, who was the Minister at the time. I hope that Opposition members will support, and continue to support, that move. The Government deserves praise for recognising, because previous conservative governments have not, the importance of training to the national economy. I believe it is vital to our continued prosperity. At the same time it is imperative that we do not throw out the baby with the bath water. Education for education's sake is as important now as it has ever been.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The feature that stands out in this Budget and, indeed, in the consideration of the appropriations for the Department of Employment, Education and Training, is the fact that this Government is making no real attempt to reduce the unemployment rate below 8 per cent. Six hundred and thirty thousand Australians are unemployed, and this figure does not include the substantial pool of discouraged job seekers-the so-called hidden unemployed. Of that figure, 120,000 teenagers cannot find work. The unemployment rate among 15- to 19-year-olds looking for their first job stands at a dismal 22.7 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Budget Statement No. 2 states that the average unemployment rate in the next year will be 8.3 per cent. By June 1988, in our bicentennial year, there will be 10,000 to 15,000 additional jobless Australians. We must face the fact that the actual result may be worse than what is forecast in the Budget Papers. It is not impossible that at this time next year we will be looking at an unemployment rate which is closer to 9 per cent.

Employment growth is vaguely forecast to slow further in 1987-88. The employment outlook of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), which the Government has admitted is only marginally different from its own expectations, predicts that employment growth will slow to 1 1/4 per cent next year. The OECD expects our unemployment rate to rise from the present 8.1 per cent to 8.5 per cent, which is, of course, fully consistent with the 8.3 per cent average rate of unemployment that the Government expects in 1987-88. The sad fact is that we are continuing directly to undermine our own competitiveness with wage and price increases which are still miles ahead of those of our trading partners. Productivity, according to the Confederation of Australian Industry, has actually fallen by 4 1/2 per cent in the last two years.

With an unemployment rate of 8 per cent and a foreign debt of over $100 billion, it is criminal for the Government continually to condone wage increases which undermine our international competitiveness. It is inhuman to waste the talents and energies of 630,000 fellow Australians by accepting 8 per cent unemployment as the trade-off for peace with the Australian Council of Trade Unions. There are now two Australians between which there is a growing gulf of hostility and alienation. There is the Australia of the employed and the Australia of the jobless. The average duration of unemployment has reached historically high levels under this Government. Mr Deputy Chairman, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table setting out this information by age and gender.
