TALK.START.PARA: —As this table shows, almost half of our unemployed-almost 300,000 people-have been out of work for six months or longer. Sixteen per cent of the unemployed, about 100,000 people, have not worked at all in the last two years. This brings me logically to the so-called `new directions' component of this portfolio: the long-overdue shift away from job creation schemes towards active labour market strategies. The skills in Australia strategy is a weak apology for the Government's mistakes over the last four years, for its misplaced emphasis on artificial and cosmetic job creation schemes. We praise the Government for admitting that its approach has been wrong. Only 15 months ago the now Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) said that the community employment program was money well spent and that it demonstrated the Government's `concern for the long term unemployed'. To suggest otherwise, according to the Minister, was `living in a fantasyland of ideology'. Well, that Minister can join his counterpart in the Senate, Senator Ryan, in the Priority One rogues gallery because their philosophic approach was stuck in the 1970s. The new directions announced by the current Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) are a slap in the face for them both.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government is stepping cautiously in the right direction by focusing on the skills side of the labour market, and about time too. But the measures so far announced, in the Skills Formation in Australia Budget Related Paper, are inadequate and concentrate on narrow and shallow skills. To a degree, the overhaul of training schemes is a reflection of Sir Humphrey's timeless motto: `When all else fails-reorganise'.

There are glaring deficiencies in the Government's strategy for skills formation. Firstly, it does not matter how many people we train each year, or what degree of resources we devote to skills formation, if all we end up with is a more intelligent and more talented pool of people without jobs. The Government still refuses to permit greater flexibility in wages and conditions in order to boost employment demand and to increase training intakes. But through wage subsidy schemes-and this is the perversity of it all-the Government implicitly recognises the truth of wage relativities. What is Jobstart, which pays employers up to $180 a week to take on long term unemployed people, if it is not a recognition of the link between wages and employment?

Secondly, the traineeships scheme will continue to fail until the Government bites the bullet on trainee wages. Every target for traineeships has been missed, because union rejection of an appropriate training wage has simply deterred employer participation. As Mr Kelty said, the Australian Council of Trade Unions will not accept a training wage, in his words, `simply to give employers a financial incentive to employ young people'. The Government still has not met the June 1986 target, and has no hope of hitting the 75,000 the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promised by the end of next year. On the Government's own figures, there will be only 13,000 traineeships operating by June 1988.

Thirdly, some of the new programs seem to amount to little more than remedial education, providing basic skills which should have been gained in secondary schooling. The job clubs, which will teach the unemployed how to read job advertisements and write an application after 6 months on the dole, are a prime example of this.

Fourthly, the so-called initiatives in the Skills Formation in Australia document are little more than a collection of quick-fix schemes aimed at the longer term unemployed and those otherwise disadvantaged in the work force. Mostly they are old schemes with a new name. An emphasis on short term vocational courses designed to meet local skills shortages is not sufficient to fulfil our needs for skill enhancement.

To put it simply, let us not be deluded by the Government's rhetoric. Training schemes will not by themselves solve the problem of unemployment. Wage flexibility needs to be addressed urgently to restore opportunity for all Australians who want work. Until we face up to wage flexibility, a fact which the Government, in its own heart, knows to be the reality of the unemployment problem, we are kidding ourselves and tinkering at the edges.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address some of the training programs which are set out in the estimates of the employment, education and training portfolio. It is a very wide-ranging portfolio. So many changes, initiatives and some winding-down of programs have been undertaken within this portfolio that time will not permit me to look at the entire spectrum. However, I agree with the concern expressed by the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack), who has just resumed his seat, regarding the division in our community between those with jobs and those without jobs. It is very important that different sectors of society, such as employer and employee and people of different political parties, pull together in this respect. As has been delineated, people without jobs have been searching around and have been more or less left on the outskirts of development while we go through the different measures, trying to seek a resolution to the problem. This has gone on for many years, but I can remember that between 1980 and 1983, under the previous Government, there were wage subsidy schemes. A lot of the things that are now being attacked were right up front of policy at that stage.

SPEECH.PARA: I disagree with speakers opposite who have attacked job creation schemes, such as the community employment program, as being shallow and of no use. When we introduced the community employment program in 1983, we ended a situation where unemployed people had not gained the recognition that they needed specific programs. In fact, they were termed `dole bludgers' at that stage. They were told to scrub up and front up for a job and they would surely get one. The previous Government did absolutely nothing to alleviate the situation. While we most certainly needed to look at the longer term plans, which is what we are doing in this Budget, we also needed to ensure that people on the unemployment benefit who were given no hope-they were hanging around at home, turning up for jobs and never returning home successfully; some turned to drugs and to drink-were given something a little better than that.

The community employment program has been a fine alternative use of taxpayer's money to the empty payment of the unemployment benefit. It has provided community facilities in many areas. Also, it has taken those who were chronically unemployed out of the hopelessness of hanging around at home and has put them into a job situation. Granted, people were in a job for only three to 12 months, but the program gave them some confidence. It gave people who had never been in a job before a taste of the discipline of work. Anyone who has had young people close to him in the hopelessness of the unemployment cycle would agree with the benefits which obtain to the community employment program.

Another aspect which the program addressed was that of 17-, 18- and 19-year-olds looking for a job who, when they turned up before an employer, were told that at their age job experience was required. It was a hopeless situation in that young people of 20 had never been given an opportunity to gain experience. At least the community employment program got many people into full time work and gave them a curriculum vitae. It gave them some experience, something to present to a potential employer. For that reason I have felt very warmly about that job creation program, the community employment program. I have noted that honourable members on both sides of this House have taken advantage of the program and used it extensively within their electorates.

I turn to some of the problems that we are trying to address within this portfolio. Despite the recent rapid increase in secondary education retention rates from 36.3 per cent in 1982 to 48.7 per cent in 1986, school level retention in Australia remains low by comparison with countries such as Japan and United States of America. The Commonwealth has set a goal of a 65 per cent retention rate to year 12 by the early 1990s. We need to get people into higher education and to see that the education they receive is appropriate and fits them with skills needed in the market-place. Of course, at the other end of the spectrum, we must look at what is happening in the market-place.

Increases in tertiary participation will also take top priority. If we are to meet the challenge of providing job opportunities for those who wish to have them, we must increase the overall level of participation in education and training, and we must expand our national training capacity. The most successful economies internationally give high priority to education and work skills, and it stands to reason that we must do the same. We must take new paths to broaden our education and training system and we must look at achieving a better balance in our national education and training effort to meet the long term economic and manpower needs of Australia. We have to raise the level of private sector investment in giving young Australians appropriate training and skills. That is one of the things that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) is looking at within the context of this Budget.
I turn now to the extra funding for training programs. Budget Paper No. 3 states that the objective in training is:

To promote increased and better opportunities for job seekers who are long-term unemployed or otherwise disadvantaged in the labour market to obtain and upgrade skills relevant to the current and future labour market requirements.

I am very pleased to see an increase to $30.8m for the adult training program. Funding for the youth training program, which is very important, is $31m. Funding for the trade training program, at $131.1m, is important because apprenticeship programs will assist an estimated 92,000, 15- to 19-year-olds in 1987-88. These are a number of different sectors which we are trying to pull together to fill a need. But we need a supplement to that apprenticeship system, and I hope that the private sector will even more strongly put its weight behind the traineeship system.

The traineeship system complements apprenticeships as a major entry point into the labour force, particularly for those in the 16- to 18-year-old group who have not completed their year 12 education or its equivalent. Like an apprenticeship, a traineeship involves a combination of structured on and off the job training and contracts between employers and trainees. I am pleased to see that, while progress has been slower than we originally envisaged, substantial advances have been made. I commend those sections of the private sector which have taken up the challenge of the youth traineeship program. However, I am disappointed that some key employers and unions are still resisting the introduction of the traineeships. However, those traineeships have filled a great need within our society. Traineeships are available in both public and private sectors, in occupations and industries such as office and clerical work, furniture removals, the textile, clothing and footwear industry, the building and construction industry, banking, and the rural and hospitality industries. Nearly three-quarters of the trainees to date have been 16- to 18-year-olds without year 12 qualifications. Some 1,250 trainees have already completed their training. The vast majority have found subsequent employment and have gone on to further education or training, a most important aspect of this program in breaking the cycle of unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —All going well, on Friday night I will be attending the graduation of the nurses from Broken Hill Base Hospital. It will be an historical and sad occasion because on that evening the last three-year trained nurses will be graduating from the hospital. If the present system that has recently been implemented continues there will be no more three-year nurses graduating from the Broken Hill Base Hospital. This is a result, of course, of the new training methods whereby nurses have to be trained at colleges of advanced education. I am one who has been opposed to that. The other night I was in an argument with a male matron in the west of New South Wales who was all for the training of nurses in colleges of advanced education. I have had to rethink exactly where I stand on the matter. Perhaps what is required is a compromise whereby the nurses, whether they are male or female, can train in the hospitals for one or two years and undertake post-graduate course. Perhaps even better, we could use the old university building as the college of advanced education for the training of nurses in Broken Hill. I am keen to keep the training in the hospitals. In Broken Hill, to use that as an example, in any year in the past we would have 30 young people being trained in the hospital as nurses. If one takes away the humanitarian aspect of being a nurse, the fact that training has supplied 30 jobs a year in a rural area is very important to that area. Now those 30 people will have to pay to be educated in colleges of advanced education. They will have to leave Broken Hill. The youngsters from many of the poorer families would make incredible nurses. A lot of gold medals have been issued from the Broken Hill Base Hospital. Those people will have to have their training in colleges, and they just cannot afford to go there. Therefore, firstly, they will lose a career and, secondly, we in Broken Hill will lose those very vital jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the State and Federal governments to look at that matter to see whether they can come up with a compromise for hospitals in bush areas, because once young people leave those areas we find it very difficult to get them back again. I doubt that there is any hospital in western New South Wales which does not have a shortage of trained nurses and which could not find employment for those nurses.

I am very concerned about this matter. Enrolled nurses even now have to travel to Dubbo to be trained on block release for a number of weeks at a time. They do their nursing in Broken Hill and have to travel to Dubbo. Perhaps we can look at an extension of the Mitchell College of Advanced Education in Broken Hill and allowing those nurses to train there. I know it is a difficult subject because the nurses certainly want to upgrade their status in the community. I believe that, with modern technology, they have to be better trained and better equipped. However, I believe that a nurse is a nurse and that the basic training can be gained only in a hospital. Some nurses who go to a college find after 12 months, or whatever the initial period is, that when they go into a hospital environment they are not suited to that career. This is something that we have to look at. I once held very strongly the view that nurses should be trained in the hospitals. I now think a compromise can be obtained whereby they can be trained both in a hospital and in a college. But, for heaven's sake, we have to look after our bush hospitals because we have enough problems as it is trying to obtain nurses for those areas.

I would like now to turn to Leeton in my electorate. Recently the St Francis de la Salle College has had boarding facilities built especially for 26 female students. I take this opportunity to congratulate the Government on providing that money. It has seen a need there. There is a need particularly for boarding school facilities. People in rural areas, particularly the more isolated areas, are finding it ever more difficult to send their children to school. Many people say that sending children to boarding school is elitism and that children should go to colleges, particularly in capital city areas. But the fact is that if they do not go to a boarding college they do not get an education. It is time for a reversal of the Government's thinking about boarding colleges. The Government should be providing more funds for these colleges. It is interesting to note that the college in Leeton has had boarding facilities established for young ladies, an area of real need. Once again, I congratulate the Government for providing this facility. I also congratulate the college and in particular Sister Jean, the Principal, for the tremendous work they have done in organising the plans and getting the facility built.

As well as boarding colleges, there are the hostels in bush areas such as Cobar, Broken Hill and Tibooburra in western New South Wales. These hostels are finding it very difficult to meet their financial problems. This is another area the Government has to look into. We can go back to the nurses again. If one lives in a capital city as a young student one can live at home, go off to college and return home at night. It is all so simple compared to what one has to do if one lives in the bush. It is the same with students who may come down from north of the Queensland border to go to Cobar or to Broken Hill. It is very difficult for them. We must have hostel facilities for these people.

Another aspect I would like to speak about-I suppose it is more relevant in capital cities but it is also affecting us in the west-is the problem of family breakdown. I believe that, because of laws that have been passed and laws that have not been passed by State and Federal governments, the family unit as we know it, understand it and would like to believe it exists is breaking down. This is putting tremendous pressures on school teachers throughout Australia. We are imposing on school teachers problems which are not theirs to handle. They have not been trained to handle them. We are making them the victims of the social problems we face in our schools and in society.

We have a problem in Broken Hill because the State education department is not providing enough school counsellors. It is a pity that we need school counsellors but, with the problems we have, we need them. There is a shortage of school counsellors in Broken Hill. If there is a shortage in Broken Hill, there must be a shortage in other areas of New South Wales. Some of the problems school children face are caused by the more liberal ideas-some people would call them liberal; I think they are crazy-such as the idea that one cannot reprimand students or have any real control over them. Students are allowed to do almost what they like without any retribution. School counsellors are called in to handle the problem. If the schools do not have these school counsellors, I feel sorry for the students and the parents, and particularly for the teachers who have to handle the situation.

I would now like to touch on the problems we have in Griffith and other areas in regard to the integration of physically handicapped children into the major school system. I have been to a number of schools in my electorate and it is wonderful to see physically handicapped children attending schools in both the State and private school system and being treated as equals. At a school one day I saw a young child who could not walk picked up by a couple of young primary school children, one on each arm, and dragged along, laughing and joking. He was one of the class. When I was a young student young disabled people did not have the opportunity to go into the major school system. The only problem with this integration is that, if physically handicapped children are in the school system, ramps, special toilet facilities and, most of all, teachers' aides have to be provided to look after them.

The New South Wales Government put out a statement called `Principles and Objectives in Relation to Services and Programmes for People with Disabilities and Families containing a member who is Disabled in New South Wales'. The report said that the Government upheld the principles of:
(a) individual freedom of choice
(b) conditions of every day life being the same for the disabled as those provided for, and enjoyed by, the majority of non-disabled people, and
(c) where special services and support are essential, they will be provided as part of the local service system.

I know that in my electorate $1,000 per child per annum is provided in those areas in schools. That is totally inadequate. If the Government really wants to implement that scheme-I believe it is a worthwhile scheme because these young people have a lot to contribute to our society; they are part of our society-the Government has to do something about funding those young people and those schools. I have in mind in particular the Griffith Catholic High School, Wade Agricultural High School and Griffith High School. All those schools really need more finance and more facilities to provide for those wonderful young people with physical handicaps who are trying to make their way in the school system. Of course, while they are doing that they are educating the other children in the school system to be tolerant and teaching them what the meaning of life is all about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Appropriation Bill (No. 1) because in my view it represents one of the most significant opportunities for government in Australia, and those on the other side of the House, to co-operate in a restructuring of employment, training and education. I was a little disappointed that during Question Time today the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron), in a fairly cheap point scoring exercise, decided to ask a question that in his view poured the can on the community employment program (CEP). As my colleague the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling), who spoke a little while ago in this debate, said, the community employment program that was instituted by this Government has played a very major role in helping many Australians to get a foothold back into the work force.

SPEECH.PARA: If one went to the Parliamentary Library to research a few of the local newspapers one might find that many members on the other side of the chamber who for political reasons like to bucket this program have been right up front in putting out Press releases in their local newspapers claiming credit for programs that have created jobs and worthwhile community projects in their electorate. They do not hesitate to claim the credit for our programs when there is an electoral benefit for them. All I am saying is that they ought to be a little honest about it in this chamber.

In my electorate alone over 1,000 jobs were created in three years under the community employment program. For the record, the success rate of the projects was over 70 per cent. By that I mean that 12 months down the track 70 per cent of the people involved were in full time employment after leaving the CEP project. That was a very meaningful and successful program. It leads me on to say that providing it is done well, providing we can put together packages that incorporate work experience with a worthwhile task that is seen and valued by people around the local area and a worthwhile training scheme, we have every chance of making these sorts of projects work.
I want to pick up some of the comments made by my colleague the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) in his contribution when he--

TALK.START.PARA: —It was excellent.

—As my colleague said, it was excellent. The honourable member for the Northern Territory referred to the role of teachers and the role of education. They are often criticised, especially by those on the other side, and not well understood. In the teaching service in Australia are thousands of highly qualified and trained teachers. They are able to communicate and they are able to pass on skills. In my view the lack that there is, if there is one, is in the linking of education to industry and commerce in a way that shows what those teachers and their skills can contribute. So one of the things that I think we ought to be picking up on in these new programs is an expansion of work experience.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to see the normal school experience expanded to 13 years so that students in their last three years of secondary education, at whatever institution, in the 15, 16 and 17 years age group have 40 weeks of work experience built into their education program. I would like to see much of our teaching done in real work situations. I would like to see our teachers in offices, in plants, in places where new technology is operating. They should be able to take their students to have some on the job experience, co-operating with industry. I know that many decision makers in industry are themselves desperately looking around at the moment for people to train and educate within their own work force. They are starting to see that some of these skills are very real and are quite adaptable to what we might call a real work situation.

Another opportunity that I think lies before the Government at the moment under this new program is for the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) to play a much greater role in the training and preparation of job applicants. For whatever reason-and I guess it is simply the sheer volume of unemployed people inherited from the previous Government-the CES has, to a large extent, found itself shuffling job vacancy cards hoping that job applicants will find themselves a position from the board. Whilst that is successful in the turnover of new job entrants-the profile of the labour market at the moment shows that many new entrants to the work force are finding jobs-it is the longer term unemployed who need more time spent with them.

Last week I spent some time in a meeting with a number of my local CES regional managers discussing ways that the CES, at the ground level, could play a greater role. To a person, they felt that what they need to do is to spend more time with people who are unemployed and to spend more time with the decision makers-the personnel officers, the people in the industry and in the work force who are looking for job applicants-in order to do more in the role of matching faces with places, as I describe it. I want to see during the next three years a much greater participation from employers in job placement programs.

We have reached the situation where those in management have to take a very solid look at themselves. They can no longer point the finger at the trade unions and say that they are the problem, because in the last four to five years under the accord, Australia's trade union movement has shown a remarkable degree of both flexibility--

TALK.START.PARA: —And responsibility.

—As my colleague says, the trade union movement has also shown responsibility in addressing these issues. They can no longer blame unions. They cannot keep pointing the finger at schools and saying that they are the fault, that they are the problem. They cannot keep waving the finger at parents saying that they are the problem. I am saying to employers and those in this field that it is time they had a damn good look at themselves. It is time they had a good look at the training programs they have in their own operations. It is time they had a good look at the way they can relate to CES more positively.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing I found in talking to CES managers was that they too were able to build up a profile of poor employers. They find that there are very specific reasons for a high labour turnover in a number of places. Some of the reasons are that employers treat their employees poorly; they mislead their employees in job expectations; they say to them, `Take up this position and you will be trained and given careful attention. You will be helped, phased in'. Employees are given about a three-hour crash course on how to turn the machine on and are then left to their own resources. Employers wonder why they become dissatisfied and move on.

The whole concept of employment, education and training is an across the board responsibility. There is a role for everyone; there is a role for the educators; there is a role for government through the CES and other training institutions; there is a role for the trade unions; and, most importantly, there is a role for employers and people in a position to take new job entrants, ease them in, train them and turn them into worthwhile, dedicated employees. I think everyone understands that good staff are the answer for high quality productivity and turnout.

I simply say that this Bill and the changes that are incorporated under the new structure represent the first real opportunity in nearly two decades for Australia to approach constructively the question of education, employment and training cohesively. I very happily support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The knowledge that the current Commonwealth funding period ends next year and that the Department of Education is about to deliberate on schools funding categorisation prior to the ensuing funding period makes it timely to discuss possible changes. Integral to the several issues of immediate concern are the components of the education resource index (ERI). I understand that the Department has the ERI under examination right now. The community standard element is pertinent because of its effect on the ERI. The community standard reflects the costs of government schools, with effects for funding targeted at non-government schools. Costs incurred by non- government schools and not in community standard figuring include: superannuation, long service leave provisions, depreciation allowances, workers compensation insurance, professional liability insurance and various other administrative expenses.

SPEECH.PARA: Because such costs do not find a way into the figuring of the community standard they consequently do not form part of the denominator, which is the education resource index. It is a distorting omission. The community standard should take account of the income non- government schools have to allocate to such essential expenditures. Alternatively, these outlays could be excluded from the ERI numerator with the same effect. Considerable and rapidly escalating fees charged to parents of students in government schools are similarly missing from this equation. This is despite an inclusion of charges for similar purposes in the fee structures of non-government schools. An outstanding example of the widening gap between the costs in government and non-government schools is workers compensation insurance, where costs to non-government schools are becoming almost incomparably greater. There should be provision in the community standard to reflect changes in relativities.

Since the community standard came into being in 1983-84 significant compulsory changes have been imposed on government and non- government schools alike. Changes in curricula, particularly in my State of Western Australia, are a case in point. Considerable additional expenditure by schools has inevitably ensued. In complying with this Government's priorities, costs and fees where appropriate, are increasing as an inevitable consequence of lifting the retention rate in senior secondary years. Lifting retention rates requires increased costs, both of a one-off nature and in recurrent expenditure. Increases imposed include the costs of extra staff, more equipment and buildings and a whole range of alternative curricula needs. With the review of the community standards seemingly under way I suggest that it is an appropriate time to urge that the Government amend it to reflect the changing and higher level of resources required for all schools.

Speaking in the time available in this debate allows only a brief reference to the very important matter of schools with special needs. It seems that the education resource index fails properly to take account of expenditure incurred by some non-government schools in providing for students with special needs. Tonight I am content to canvass a proposal by the Association of Independent Schools of Western Australia, without dwelling on the very good supporting argument. Briefly, it is that additional per student costs in meeting the special needs of students should be recognised by an appropriate increase in the ERI denominator, that is, by an augmented community standard.

The boarding school allowance component of the ERI based categorisation is also in need of adjustment. It is very doubtful that the setting of a single allowance to apply throughout the nation is in any way appropriate, leaving aside for the time being the arbitrary $3,000, at 1983 prices, operating allowance per boarder now in place. Of course, the adequacy of that operating allowance is arguable because of the way it was first struck; but is even more debatable, given the later effects of the fringe benefits tax and the national superannuation imposts which are telling burdens on boarding schools.

Serious criticism of the capital allowance also seems justifiable. It has always been open to grave doubt. While it is a doubtful measure of the so-called average capital needs for schools, the allowance is unacceptably inflexible as a key element of the ERI. The range and pattern of capital expenditure by non-government schools is simply not catered for at present. The factors not accommodated include widely differing curricula, varying client groups and widely differing local and historic circumstances. It should also be self-evident that establishing schools have vastly different needs and priorities from those schools which are established and concentrating on broadening services.

Assuming, as the Government does, that the capital needs of schools vary with fee levels has no logical basis. An outcome of tying the capital allowance to a percentage of private income unreasonably restricts schools with the will and the capacity to maintain private effort from allocating more than 7.5 per cent of private income to capital expenditure. Also, it is a matter of record that for many schools the capital allowance as it stands is simply inadequate; it is not large enough to cater for the essential capital expenditure in too many cases. Furthermore, the disallowance of interest costs on long term loans taken out for capital expenditure purposes is difficult to support.

Although the ERI, by the application of the numerator, adjusts some element of debt servicing, it does not adjust total debt servicing comprised of principal and interest. Again, problems with the capital allowance are exacerbated by the demands mentioned earlier involving curricular changes and retention rates. In fact, it is less than equitable that schools funding be penalised as a result of decisions by State or Commonwealth governments-it being therefore beyond the capacity of the schools to influence and control subsequent and flowing development.

Earlier I listed categories of unavoidable running costs which have escalated and warrant an enlightened reappraisal of the community standard and the ERI. That aside, the imposts of the Commonwealth sponsored 3 per cent superannuation scheme, and the fringe benefits tax with its accompanying burdensome administrative costs, merit special accommodation and understanding by the Department and by the Government.

Given general acceptance of this Government's approach-I acknowledge that there seems to be general acceptance of its approach to school funding with strings attached-refinement and major adjustments are needed for the next funding period which starts in the not too distant future. I urge the Government to pay attention-maybe it already is-to the concerns of the non-government schools and to give very serious consideration to the weaknesses that are already apparent in the system as it now stands. Certainly I would urge the Minister at the table, the Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs (Mr Holding), to convey to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) my concerns along with the hope that the Government may, in the coming funding period, address the matters I raise and those very real concerns that I am sure have been expressed to it by representatives of the non-government schools.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At a time of economic restraint the Hawke Government has increased general recurrent grants to all Australian schools by almost $60m, a real increase of 4.8 per cent over 1986-87. This increase is designed to meet the Hawke Government's objective that by 1992 two-thirds of Australia's school students will be completing their secondary schooling by year 12. While this initiative is to be applauded, an action deserving of even more applause is the decision by the Hawke Government to provide $38.4m to fund an extra 3,500 to 4,000 intakes for young school leavers wanting to attend universities or colleges of advanced education in 1988. The additional funds also allow for the construction of new facilities and new equipment to meet the expanded number of places.

SPEECH.PARA: It is generally acknowledged in the Australian community that no Federal Government since World War II has committed more resources to tertiary education in Australia than the Hawke Government. The creation of more than 43,000 new places at tertiary institutions throughout Australia in less than five years is evidence of a determined commitment by this Government to provide an opportunity for higher education for all Australians. Nevertheless, there is still much to do if Australia is to establish a well-educated, highly skilled population.

I note that in Queensland less than 55 per cent of students who complete grade 12 proceed to tertiary education. I take the opportunity this evening of recording the gratitude of all Australians for the effort by the previous Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, in ensuring that Federal Government funding for education increased in real terms during her tenure as Minister, despite the economic difficulties the nation has faced over the last three years.

Whilst the Federal Government is to be congratulated on its outstanding record of increasing the opportunities for all Australians to participate in tertiary education, I wish to bring to the notice of honourable members a number of matters concerning the inequality of funding for tertiary studies in northern Australia when compared with funding for tertiary students in southern Australia. Honourable members will be aware that there are three tertiary institutions located in northern Australia. I refer to the James Cook University of North Queensland, the Darwin Institute of Technology and the Capricornia Institute of Advanced Education. Each of these institutions is funded by the Federal Government through the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission. Approximately one million Australians reside north of the twenty-sixth parallel.

In 1986 Federal Government recurrent funding for tertiary studies in Australia amounted to $2,444m, or about $153 for every Australian. However, for the three tertiary institutions in northern Australia Federal Government recurrent funding totalled $54m or about $53 for every northern Australian. It is astonishing that such inequality of Federal Government recurrent funding for tertiary studies should be allowed. It is an inequality that calls for immediate rectification. Pleas to the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission for fairer allocation of funding for tertiary studies in northern Australia have not been successful. The case for increased funding for tertiary studies in northern Australia has been proved over and over again. The James Cook University of North Queensland, with its main campus in Townsville, has already achieved an international reputation for excellence. Its Vice-Chancellor, Professor Raymond Golding, and Assistant Vice-Chancellor, Professor Edward Scott, are in the Speaker's gallery this evening. Its graduate school of tropical veterinary science is among the best in the world. It plays a major role in the provision of teaching and research assistance, not only within northern Australia but also within Indonesia. It is a university of which Australia can be proud.

Australia's only university in the tropics-the James Cook University of North Queensland-is constantly seeking Commonwealth funding to meet its desperate needs for additional student residential accommodation. Special pressures are associated with the growth of James Cook University, whose students come from such a large area of Australia. Student enrolment targets have been exceeded in the last two years by more than 20 per cent. Total internal enrolments are projected to reach 5,000 by 1990. About half of the internal students are in off-campus accommodation. The housing problem for internal students is desperate.

James Cook University will fail to meet genuine student needs if more housing cannot be provided. Two residential halls-University Hall and John Flynn College-have indicated strong interest in the provision of more places in independent self-catering units. At least 100 places are required to make a significant impact on the shortage of accommodation. I ask the Federal Government for urgent financial help to accommodate tertiary students in north Queensland.

There is one further priority and that is the need for an extension to the university library building. The main library building was completed in 1974 and was designed to accommodate 150,000 volumes, 400 reader places and supporting staff. At December 1986 it held 329,453 volumes and 336 reader places. A second building, a branch library, was acquired in 1982. It was formerly the Library Resources Centre of the Townsville College of Advanced Education and was designed for 60,000 volumes and 200 reader places. As at December 1986 it held nearly 97,000 volumes and 103 reader places. Both library buildings are full.

The library needs 143 square metres of additional book storage space alone per year just to maintain the present inadequate status quo. This space is not available either within the building or in independent bulk stores. Even if the latter were available, within five years almost one quarter of the library's complete book stock would be in store. Within 10 years almost 40 per cent would be in store. No academic library in Australia operates on such a basis. Lacking any other alternative, as book stock grows seating space for readers decreases. The library system has lost 161 readers places in the last 10 years and this is at an Australian university in 1987.

In 1986, at the time of the submission to the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission for the 1988-90 triennium, the library system had one seating place for each 6.75 effective full time study units. Anything above one in five can be considered a serious problem. In 1987 student numbers increased by 11 per cent, reducing the seating ratio to one seating place for each 7.5 effective full time study units. It has now become a routine situation for there to be no free study places in the library. If the university's student enrolment projections for the future are achieved-they almost certainly will be-this overall ratio will fall to one seat per 10.9 effective full time study units, or one seat per 13 students, by 1990, that is before the beginning of the next triennium. This assumes that reader spaces will not be resumed for book storage space. If there is no extra space, all reader places will have disappeared within 10 years.

For 1985 to 1987, James Cook University has requested an extension of 4,600 square metres gross to the main library building in its submission to the university council. This request was supported by the university council but funding was not approved by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission. The library extension is now the University's top capital works priority and the growth and academic life of the James Cook University will be in jeopardy without it. I again appeal for immediate funding from the Federal Government for this urgent project.

Early this year James Cook University established the Anton Breinl Centre for Tropical Health and Medicine. With the aid of a Federal Government grant of $2.7m, this new facility will deal with the epidemiology of infectious diseases, Aboriginal and Islander health and nutrition, and specialised research into such matters as skin cancer, marine medicine and community health in the tropics. The establishment of this research centre at James Cook University was a recognition by the Federal Government that of all the developed countries, Australia alone has the capacity to establish facilities for tropical medicine in the tropics. With the appointment of a distinguished scientist to the first chair of tropical health and medicine at an Australian university, I am certain that this new centre for tropical health and medicine will quickly earn for itself international renown for technical excellence.
