SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is all too easy for politicians and other commentators to slip into the habit of talking about Australia's unemployment in convenient, statistical terms and in so doing to ignore the real issue; that is, not that 8.3 per cent of the work force is unemployed but that 600,000 Australian people are out of a job. Those Australians are men, women, adults and juniors and for many of them their inability to obtain or difficulty in obtaining suitable employment will cause personal suffering and hardship which will stay with them throughout their lifetime.

SPEECH.PARA: We have all heard, at various times, the Government and others talk about people as being Australia's greatest resource. Yet I see little in the Hawke Government's recent Budget which acknowledged that behind all that talk of foreign debt, the balance of payments difficulties and many other economic statistics, the real concern of government is not those economic indicators but their impact on the well-being of people-you and me, our relatives, children, friends and next door neighbours. There is a section of the Budget Speech under the heading `Employment, Education and Training', but honourable members will look long and unsuccessfully for any acknowledgment that the Hawke Government's policies have failed to have any impact on reducing the unemployment rate below 8 per cent or that an unemployment rate at that level really means that over 600,000 people in this country are facing the uncertainty of seeking and obtaining another job. We are not talking about statistics; we are talking about real people.

Elsewhere in the Budget documents is an admission that 1987-88 will probably see some slowing of employment growth with little change expected in the 1986-87 unemployment rate of 8.3 per cent. Again, if we convert those statistics into human facts, the Budget-and that is what we are talking about tonight-is really saying that there is little hope over the coming year and not much to look forward to for about 630,000 unemployed Australians. I would like to bring that fact to the attention of this Parliament-there are 630,000 unemployed Australians. I believe that this Government must rightly be condemned not only for its failure over its four years in office to reduce unemployment but also because it is seen increasingly to regard that level of unemployment as natural and something that has to be accepted as a permanent feature of the economy. I, for one, do not accept that figure as being a natural feature of our employment situation.

Does the Hawke Government really expect people to accept an unemployment level which means that 22 per cent of Australia's youth are unemployed and that the average duration of unemployment has increased steadily from 32.9 weeks in 1982-83 to 47.1 weeks in 1986-87? I would like to hear some interjections from the Government side about the increase in the level and duration of unemployment for Australia's people. Here we have a government-and a party-which says that it has real concern for Australia's youth and Australia's unemployed. But look at the figures! How can honourable members opposite justify these simple straightforward facts-47.1 weeks in 1986-87?

Again, I wish to convert those statistical terms into human factors by saying that unemployed Australians will take an average of almost one year to find another job and that about one in every four young Australians will be without a job. How about those people on the Left of the Australian Labor Party who sit opposite? How do they feel about the fact that under their Government about one in four young Australians will be without a job in the coming year? They accept it. I see them sitting over there. How will they react to that fact-that about one in four young Australians will be without a job and without the prospect of a job under their Government? They should be-and I believe that within themselves they are-ashamed of the fact that their Government, after four years in office, has been unable to grapple with this factual situation. It is a disgrace and they know it. I believe that within themselves they are deeply ashamed of those statistics.

There has to be something seriously wrong with the very structure of our economy to have these entrenched employment features. Of course there is something wrong. It is the misplaced economic policies of the Labor Government which has poured millions of dollars into vote catching but extremely trivial expenditure programs, while largely ignoring the urgent need for those structural changes which will create jobs and skills both to reduce our unemployment and to improve our economic health.

What do we hear from the Government about those sorts of situations? Not one single word. I was brought up in this country in the belief that the Labor Party was concerned with those people within the community who were less advantaged. But what do I hear from the Government? What do I hear from the Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs (Mr Holding), who is at the table, about those 600,000 plus young Australians who are without a job? What do I hear about those people? Not one single word.

One of the areas of structural change of the utmost importance to the future of this country is the need for business investment in enterprises with improved trading opportunities. Of course that really means manufacturing industry. Manufacturing employment in Australia has been static for almost five years and it is no coincidence that this is precisely the same period in which our unemployment has become entrenched at seriously high and totally unacceptable levels. It is not too much to say that the Hawke Government has a totally unimpressive record in its economic management for the long term rehabilitation of Australian export manufactures. This Government does not seem to understand what is really needed. Up to now its attitude has all too often been a simplistic chastising of Australian businessmen for their investment timidity and lack of real entrepreneurship. Has this Government given any thought as to why there has been frantic entrepreneurship in corporate takeovers, the foreign exchange and stock markets and other financially oriented activities, yet no such interest in manufacturing activities? The simple explanation is that the Hawke Government has failed to create the overall climate conducive to that form of investment.

Certainly there have been some positives, such as improved competitiveness resulting from devaluation, reduced industrial disputation and moderation in wage growth, but the Labor Government must accept that this has not been sufficient and there is now an urgent need for policies which will redress the many other factors which are essential prerequisites to get business investment moving and, more to the point, moving in the direction which will help to ensure our future living standards.

The single most important factor to be realised is the need for a return to historically high levels of profitability and in practical terms this means a rate of return on investment of between 20 and 25 per cent, depending on the particular industry and the corporation. I point out that that rate is presently 17 to 18 per cent.

Despite the four years of economic growth, it must be acknowledged that businessmen have a number of sound reasons for feeling uncertain about the Australian investment climate. Our interest rates are high by international standards. Labour productivity and industrial relations are improving, but much remains to be achieved compared with our trading partners. While wage restraint is evident, there are continuing uncertainties about the full impact of the second tier wage formulation and the trade union controlled industry superannuation scheme. While the Treasurer (Mr Keating) talks about an economic revival, the fact remains that a significant number of Australians simply have no prospect at this stage of getting a job. Of course, that is a very debilitating concept for these people to realise. For a Labor Government to accept these situations, as it appears to be doing, is a tremendous acknowledgment of failure. If we cannot get jobs for our people and if families cannot look forward, at the end of university, technical school or other training, to their children having the opportunity to have worthwhile employment, there is no solution to the real and serious problem which faces the country.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In talking about the appropriations for the Department of Employment, Education and Training, I wish to comment on the Government's announcement in the Budget that it intends to integrate three community employment and training programs into a single program. These three programs are: the community youth support scheme (CYSS), the community training program (CTP) and the community volunteer program (CVP). Expenditure on these community programs has increased sharply over recent years. In 1982-83, expenditure was in the vicinity of $21m. In 1986-87, the estimated expenditure on these programs was $59.6m.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I want to speak in particular about the CYSS program. During the leadup to the Budget, there was much speculation as to the future of CYSS. During this period, I indicated my strong support for the continuance of CYSS as a community-based program with a labour market focus. I have had extensive contact with the three CYSS groups servicing my electorate. They are the Glenroy CYSS, the Broadmeadows unemployment project and the Lalor-Epping-Thomastown unemployment support group. Each of these groups makes a positive contribution to assisting young people in transition. Each has developed effective labour market programs.

I can illustrate their work by outlining the programs provided at the Broadmeadows CYSS, but I should indicate that similar programs are provided at the other two CYSS centres. In the job skills area there is a range of hands on courses, ranging from basic carpentry, metal-working skills and tiling to basic accounting, typing and filing. Where possible, the CYSS group has arranged on the job work experience as part of each course. The aim is not only or even primarily to impart basic skills but to give the participants skills that will be useful in future employment. Equally-and I think this is important-the aim is to provide to participants an insight into employers' expectations and to enhance the confidence and self-esteem of the unemployed who attend CYSS.

An important aspect of the Broadmeadows CYSS program is its Jobsearch element. This teaches participants how to look for employment through classified advertisements, at the Commonwealth Employment Service and through other avenues. It provides a segment where techniques for preparing and submitting job applications are taught and participants practice interview techniques and other aspects of attending interviews. It also introduces the unemployed to a first-hand look at the office or factory environment. It is important also to look at the announcement in the Budget that the Government is establishing a job search training program. I should indicate that this program will be along similar lines to those of the program already in place at Broadmeadows. I welcome the fact that this program, which will provide job search skills, will be open for community bodies such as CYSS projects, technical and further education bodies and other such organisations.

Broadmeadows CYSS also places great importance on support and personal development. This element of the program includes everything from an awareness of diet and health and the uses of appearance and deportment in obtaining and keeping a job to career planning and human relations. Also of interest is the fact that this CYSS group, under the special initiatives funding provisions, gained funding for a job club. I think another announcement made in the Budget speech was that the Government will be providing, on a trial basis, funding for 40 job clubs. I think it is to the credit of the Broadmeadows group that, before the announcement of this project, through the special initiatives funding provisions it will be able to put into practice a job club which will provide more intensive training courses and practical experience in job search skills.

In speaking of special initiatives funding, I note that this valuable source of additional funds for CYSS groups is to be wound down. That perhaps is disappointing, because it is something that the local CYSS groups in my electorate have made good use of through implementing innovative programs.

Many aspects of the Broadmeadows program are clearly designed to facilitate a transition from school or long term unemployment to either further training or to employment. Broadmeadows CYSS has a high record of success in that its participants move on to employment or to training such as TAFE. Its committee has developed good relations with several local employers, including Yakka Pty Ltd and Ford Motor Co. of Australia Ltd, who have commented on the skill and motivation of participants. The importance of this transition role cannot be underestimated.

In many ways, CYSS is a first port of call for young people who are deeply disillusioned and depressed. When we are considering some of the young unemployed people in areas such as the electorate of Scullin, we have to realise that, even to prepare them for the training opportunities that will emanate from a number of the measures announced in the Budget, some of them need to be given assistance to come forward and get proper benefit out of training programs. Unfortunately, because of the environment in which they have been brought up, some of them lack a great deal of self-esteem. Some of them come from families in which the parents are unemployed, making them second-generation unemployed, and have, therefore, lost what is traditionally called the work ethic. That is something on which a great deal of importance has been placed in programs such as Broadmeadows CYSS in order to prepare those young unemployed people to get the maximum benefit out of some of the training programs. I was pleased that continued funding for CYSS was indicated in the Budget. Although the Government has indicated its commitment to ongoing funding for community-based youth support programs which provide structured training and employment related support supplemented by relevant counselling support and advice services for the most disadvantaged job seekers, I am concerned that the program for the proposed integration of CYSS with CTP and CVP is as yet sketchy. In fact, whilst I can see a lot of merit and relevance in integrating CYSS groups and enabling them to take advantage of the community training program, I am suspicious of the ability of the CYSS program to embrace the community volunteer program.

I should also stress that momentum plays an important role in all community-based programs. Over the history of CYSS programs it has been very unsettling for those who have worked with and participated in those programs and for those who have carried out duties on committees of management that in that period there have been many changes in the guidelines. Recently announced changed guidelines will be coming into effect on 1 November. Whilst I have no qualm with the general direction and the labour market focus of those guidelines, I indicate that I hope that in the integration process we are not putting upon the CYSS groups too much change which it will be difficult for them to embrace.

I note that the Department is working on monitoring procedures and indicators of the effectiveness of CYSS programs, such as areas of access, the activities provided and the consequent outcomes of participants. I agree that that is important. Already the morale of CYSS groups in my electorate has been shaken a little by pre-Budget speculation. I welcome the letter that has been sent by the Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs (Mr Holding), who is at the table, which reassures CYSS projects that they will have continued funding. I look forward to the Government's announcement in the near future of a plan for consultation with CYSS management committees regarding their role in an integrated community support program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will reply very quickly to some of the points that were made by some honourable members opposite. I commend all honourable members who have participated in this debate. I undertake that my colleague the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) and I will closely examine what was said by all honourable members. There are a number of points which I believe must be addressed because some of the contributions made by members of the Opposition failed to address the enormity of the problem which the Government faces in regard to the whole question of education, unemployment, training and how we should turn around this economy. The contributions of honourable members opposite, while critical of the Government's performance, were very short on any kind of alternative proposition. They began with the contribution by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton).
—No, Warringah.

—No, the honourable member for Mackellar, who indicated that while he was deeply critical of the state school system-he referred to its somewhat centralist position-he presumed that somehow or other the Government endorsed that position. I assure him that that is not the case. My position, and I am certain that it is the position of my colleague the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, is that we believe there ought to be as much choice as possible for parents in the state school system. Honourable gentlemen opposite belong to parties which are absolutely committed to the concept of States rights. If any area traditionally has been an area occupied by the States, it is the area of education.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members opposite, including the two shadow Ministers-the honourable member for Mackellar and the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack)-failed to address this point: what do they, as supporters of States rights, say is an appropriate point of intervention by the Commonwealth? At what point should we say that we are unhappy about these aspects of State policies? Does one imagine for one moment that if my colleague and I were to indicate that we would intervene at some point because we were unhappy about some aspect of the State school system in Tasmania or Queensland that would be greeted with rejoicing by honourable members opposite? Commonwealth intervention, the overriding power of the Commonwealth, would be greeted with condemnation. We have heard it all before.

I think it is time that honourable gentlemen opposite addressed the matter in a less hypocritical way. I say that with some kindness, because the other aspect is that less than three months ago all of the honourable gentlemen opposite went to the people of Australia and said, `We must give to the States those responsibilities which are theirs and we will see that that occurs under a Howard government by ensuring massive cuts in Commonwealth support for those areas which traditionally belong to the States'. They cannot have it both ways. There is no point coming in here now three months later and saying, `Oh, dear me; think of the funding that should be going into education'. What would the reality have been if we had taken them at their word in terms of the policies they put to the Australian people less than three months ago? Does anybody believe that the logic of their position would not have involved massive cuts at every level of education at which the States operate? That is the fact of the matter.

So it is not appropriate for honourable members opposite to come in here and tell us about their concerns in respect of what we are doing for the consumers of education. I will tell them what we have been doing. There is student choice in schools. The certainty of current school programs implemented by this Government has produced a substantial increase in the number of students who are choosing to stay on in year 12. When we became the government, the honour- able gentlemen who were crying crocodile tears tonight had a school retention rate of 36 per cent. What have we done for the consumers of education in the very short time we have been in office? We have increased significantly the retention rate. We have made it perfectly clear that our long term policy is to get the retention rate up to 80 per cent. That is what we have done.

Similarly, while we have been in office the number of higher education places has increased substantially by around 43,000 positions. There are now 43,000 more places available in tertiary institutions than there were when the Fraser Government left office. That is perfectly true. Honourable gentlemen opposite can say that we still need more places. We agree with that; we do need more. But we have to find the funds if we are to produce that result. Without those funds it becomes increasingly difficult, economically, to increase the number of places.

When we come into this place and seek to implement measures which not merely will broaden the tax base but also will pursue those people who consistently evade paying tax, it is the people opposite who say, `Oh, no, you must not do that'. At the same time as they seek to restrict the capacity of the Commonwealth to raise revenue from some of their friends who persistently dodge and evade paying taxes, they come in here and want to make speeches about how we should be spending more to provide more places. Has there ever been such an exercise in double standards? Has there ever been such an exercise in hypocrisy? It is no wonder that these people failed so miserably and were rejected by the people of Australia at the last election.

Concern was expressed about an unemployment level of 8 per cent. The suggestion was made that somehow or other such a level of unemployment had become part of the concept of this Government. Let me say this: When this Government came to office it inherited from honourable gentlemen opposite an unemployment rate of over 9 per cent. We have reduced that rate. One will not find a Minister or a member on this side of the chamber who will say that the present level of unemployment is still unacceptably high.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have done nothing about it.
—What have we done about it?
—Not a thing.

—If the honourable gentleman can take his silver spoon out of his mouth for long enough to listen, he will know what we have done. I will not apologise to the honourable gentleman. I learnt years ago that one should not argue with people in that sort of situation. But let me say this: We have created over 800,000 jobs. Let me quote the figures to the bellicose gentlemen opposite who are so full of guilt. They are the people who created unemployment.
—What about 1972 to 1975? How many jobs went out of manufacturing?
—Listen to the honourable member. He is not only interjecting when is not in his correct place--
— Order! I call the honourable member for Warringah to order.

—I do not know whether you will be successful, Mr Ruddock, but we will do our best. When this Government came to office it not only had to create new job opportunities but also, at the same time, it had to try to turn the economy around. That has not been easy. It has been increasingly difficult and it has involved making some very hard decisions. Every decision that was made was opposed by honourable gentlemen opposite. The traineeship scheme in Australia is not just another labour market program which the Commonwealth can readily put in place.
—Priority One.

—The problem with honour- able gentlemen opposite is that most of them went to public schools. Most of them inherited the old family property. They graduated from there to the Melbourne Club, having taken a degree on the way, and then inherited a few seats in the Parliament. And they want to lecture us about unemployment. Look at that bunch of sodden silvertails. We are not about to be lectured in terms of their perception of unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me quote the figures in terms of the apprenticeship system and the new concept of traineeship. As at 25 September 1987, we had created over 11,600 traineeship positions. Forty-eight per cent of those were in the private sector. Over 9,500 people had commenced a traineeship, 43 per cent of whom were in the private sector. In conjunction with the trade union movement, 150 industrial agreements have been negotiated. Over 2,500 private sector employers are currently participating in that scheme. There is still a long way to go and the negotiations are continuing. I suppose that at 10 minutes to 11 at night it is asking a bit much to expect honourable gentlemen opposite to comprehend either the significance or the importance of those figures, so I will leave it at that. This Government stands on its record, and I bid you all a fond goodnight.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Progress reported.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Private Forestry-Telecom Australia: Privatisation-Queensland Police Force

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Holding) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take the opportunity tonight on the adjournment to speak for a few moments about a matter that would be of interest to all honourable members, and that is the importance and potential of private forestry. In this nation we seem to have had debates over the last several years about forestry in Tasmania and now in Queensland. In the long term we will have to come to some decisions about renewing our wood resources and utilising them to the best advantage.

SPEECH.PARA: Tasmania, unlike the rest of Australia, is well endowed with forest resources and about one quarter of this valuable resource is owned privately. Tasmania's crown and private forests cover approximately 47 per cent of the State, compared with the Australian average of only 7 per cent. Of Tasmania's commercial forests, 23 per cent are privately owned. Three-quarters of the privately owned forest land is in the hands of farmers and the wood using industries. About 40 per cent of Tasmania's wood resource comes from private land, and that is a significant proportion. As we, as a nation, continue to dedicate more and more of our crown forests to national parks and reserves, which is not a bad thing, the privately owned forest resource will become more important and more valuable in the future.

Tasmania's forests compare favourably with those of the rest of the world. The combination of species type, high rainfall and good soils produce annual growth rates which rank very highly by world standards. A significant proportion of Tasmania's forests represents the top 5 to 10 per cent of the tree growth rates for Australia and New Zealand combined. There is presently little encouragement from the Federal Government to tap this valuable resource on private land. It was disappointing that not more was done in the Budget.
A recent survey conducted in Tasmania, called the Pearce report, was carried out by the Tasmanian Private Forestry Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was rigged.

—I think the honourable member should listen to this debate. The Council examined the potential of farm land for afforestation. The survey found no less than 100,000 hectares complementary to agriculture which could be devoted to forest growth. Roughly 5 per cent of each farm property could be planted to trees for shelter, for aesthetic purposes and for commercial timber values. That is quite significant when taken over the many farms in Tasmania. However, as all of us would know, growing trees is a very long term project. Projects such as Greening Australia are worthy of greater support. Large projects obviously require specialised finance over a very long period. It takes in the order of 35 to 60 years to grow a sawlog, a resource which is rapidly diminishing in our State and indeed in the rest of Australia. So the time for decision making is fast running out.

SPEECH.PARA: The biggest impediment placed on private landowners in developing potential forested land is the pulpwood export restriction imposed on Tasmania's forest industries by the Commonwealth Government. Before there is hysterical reaction, let us consider the reason. Selective logging over the past century has denuded our forests of high quality sawlogs, leaving material suitable only for pulpwood. The sale of this pulpwood for export is critical in the financing of new productive forests. Because of cost economics, private forestry is far more economic than wood production on crown land. The Government needs to review its assistance to private forestry in order to encourage wood production. The Tasmanian Government is leading the way in this regard. It has developed new financial incentive schemes for private forestry which will be a model for the rest of Australia to follow. Environmental protection practices are just now coming into place, and they also lead the nation. The new Forest Practices Bill and the innovative Forest Practices Code have been hailed by those from all sides of the forestry debate around this country. The development of private timber reserves, the new tall trees preservation program and the skyline and streamside reserve requirements are a first within the Commonwealth.

In summary, forestry leaders all around Australia have shown that productive capacity potential and environmental protection can be achieved if there is further development of the private forestry industry. The final point I make is this: Only community support, and support from both sides of this Parliament, will ensure that productive new forests, employment and the continuing availability of timber resources will be met in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Neil Mr L.R.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to put on the record my unequivocal opposition to the privatisation of Australia's Telecommunications network. Privatisation is indeed an ugly word, and it tends to have ugly consequences for political parties that claim it to be the panacea for all our ills. The Leader of the State Liberal Party in South Australia, Mr Olsen, will attest to that fact. It is pleasing that some weeks ago the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) stated that this Government has no intention of privatising Telecom Australia. This continued commitment to the public ownership of Telecom is welcomed, especially by people living in country and rural areas such as my electorate of Grey. Unfortunately, many uninformed people still consider that Telecom, as a whole or in parts, should be sold off to the private sector in the name of efficiency and competition. What they really mean is that Telecom is the jewel in the crown. It is the organisation that the private corporate sector wants most to get its hands on because it has the potential to return huge profits.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a notion that finds great support with our conservative friends, that the sale of a public enterprise which might turn a profit for someone in private enterprise is innately good. If it can make money for someone in private enterprise it must be a good thing. This argument completely ignores the essential economic and social needs of our nation in favour of a rigid ideological dogma. It is a view which totally ignores the effects that privatisation has on those who happen to need a service rather than want a profit. In the case of Telecom, any sell-off to the private sector would result in the new owners concentrating on maintaining and upgrading its profitable services, such as the major subscriber trunk dialling routes and the central business district services. Those services which are unprofitable, or even marginally profitable, would be decimated in the name of efficiency and rationalisation.

The development of Telecom's national network has, in the past, been based on the policy of universal access to the national telecommunications system at a price all consumers can afford. The New Right claims that the privatisation of Telecom would expose it to competitive forces which would act as a spur to greater efficiency. This all sounds very nice for those who do not live in the real world. Those of us who do inhabit the real world realise that if private networks were allowed it is inevitable that their duty to their shareholders would be to make profits by improving services on the profitable routes and removing services on the unprofitable routes.

We all know that Telecom presently cross- subsidises its rural network to the extent of approximately $500m every year. This massive cross-subsidy ensures that telephone subscribers in my electorate are able to afford to have a service installed and maintained. Honourable members would be aware that Grey covers some of the most isolated and remote towns and communities in Australia and the cost of maintaining the telecommunications network in the region runs into millions of dollars. It is estimated that the real cost of installing a telephone service in some areas of Grey could be as high as $20,000 to $30,000. Who would cover this cost in the brave new world of privatisation? Unfortunately, it would be the consumer. People living in rural and regional Australia would be forced to either do without a telephone service or pay the full cost of its installation and maintenance. No right-thinking Australian would accept a system which provided no telephone service to about a third of the people and about 95 per cent of the country, yet this is a distinct possibility if Telecom is privatised.

Many people point to the supposed success of the policy of privatisation in Great Britain under Margaret Thatcher. Instead of looking at the effects of the sale of British Telecom on the consumer, many commentators proudly state that more people in Britain now own shares in public companies than at any other time in history; therefore, privatisation is a success. This nonsense ignores the fact that the British telephone subscriber is now paying a higher price for a poorer service. It is a fact that in Britain the cost of local calls and charges has risen faster than inflation since the sale of British Telecom. Britain now has the world's dearest local call charges and rural areas are being forced to pay the full cost of new telephone services. No wonder private investors want to get their hands on British Telecom shares-they appear to be a licence to print money at the expense of the telephone consumer. One could ask: Why would the sale of Telecom in Australia be any different from the sale of British Telecom? The answer is, of course, that the sale would be no different. Australia's rural and country people would be fleeced to fill the pockets of a few investors.

Another aspect of privatisation which is often overlooked is the massive unemployment and de-skilling that occurs when the motive becomes purely profit and nothing else. Telecom's buy Australian policy has in the past ensured that up to 90 per cent of Telecom's high technology purchases have been made in Australia. In 1985-86 this was valued at $900m spent by Telecom in Australia on high technology goods. Where would this money be spent if Telecom was driven by the profit motive? It would be spent in the factories of Asia rather than in Australia, causing large scale unemployment and adding to Australia's balance of trade problems. The British experience has shown us that this is not merely scare mongering, it is fact. Many thousands of jobs in British industry have been sacrificed on the altar of privatisation already and as many as 45,000 others are at risk.

What then are the benefits of privatisation? A cash injection to the Treasury coffers would assist in paying unemployment benefits to those thrown out of work by the sale of Telecom. In Britain the sale has helped to provide income tax cuts, but these cuts may not even cover the increased costs of telephone services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, last evening I read to the House a letter written by a former policeman in 1981. A Constable Dillon of the Queensland Police Force was applauded for coming forward at the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct. I wish to acknowledge the bravery of this constable who came forward almost six years ago. There was no applause on that occasion. He received vilification from the then Police Minister, Mr Hinze. As a result, corruption in the Queensland Police Force became so ram- pant that a senior member of that force, a self-confessed corrupt officer acting on appointment from the Queensland Government, was able to sit on the National Crime Authority. If only the Bjelke-Petersen Government had taken action in 1981. The Bjelke-Petersen Government could have acted, should have acted, but did not.

SPEECH.PARA: I have now received advice that some of these allegations had been forwarded to the then Attorney-General in Queensland, Mr Doumaney. It took many months before the allegations were forwarded to the then Police Minister, Mr Hinze. The officers involved in making the allegations then appeared on the Nationwide program. The actions of Mr Hinze at the time are interesting in hindsight. Mr Hinze required the officers to meet with him and make sworn affidavits and then he would look into the allegations. In other words, these officers who had already put their jobs on the line had to leave themselves further open so Hinze could see whether or not he would investigate. Yet Hinze is the same Minister who was reassuring the Queensland public a year earlier that no inquiry into illegal casinos and brothels was needed because they did not exist. This similar line was adopted almost six years later by the current Minister for Police, Mr Gunn. In other words, why would honest members of the police force ever bother to come forward when members of the Bjelke- Petersen Government mislead the public?
